metadata.@content: Logunov, A.A.; Folomeshkin, V.N.
Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov. Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij
Does the source energy change when gravitaion waves are emitted in the einstein's gravitation theory
USSR
1977; 25 p; IFVE-OTF--77-101; Submitted to the journal Theor. Math. Phys.
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

It is shown that in the Einstein's gravitation theory the total ''energy'' of a plane gravitational wave calculated with any pseudotensor is equal to zero. The known Einstein's result, according to which the energy of a sourceis decreased when plane weak gravitational waves are emitted, have no place in the Einstein's gravitational theory. The examples are given of exact wave solutions for which the pseudotensor is strictly equal to zero. The energy-momentum of any weak gravitational waves is always equal to zero in the Einstein's gravitation theory. When such waves are emitted the energy of the source cannot change, although these waves are real curvature waves. By the means in the Einstein's gravitation theory the energy, e, is in essenc generated from nothing
January 1977

metadata.@content: Logunov, A.A.; Fomeshkin, V.N.
Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov. Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij
Energy-momentum of gravitational waves in general relativity
USSR
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

It is shown that if the Einstein method of calculating the ''energy flux'' of gravitational fields is followed consistently, and in all cases generally covariant density of the √-gR lagrangian is used, then for the ''energy flux'' of gravitational waves a strictly zero value will be obtained. Thus the Einstein method, that has introduced noncovariant ''pseudotensors'' into the covariant physical theory, brings to a zero the value for the ''energy'' in general relativity
January 1977

      </notes>

      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02169" assignment="indexer">conservation laws</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03112" assignment="indexer">energy</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03251" assignment="indexer">euclidean space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04117" assignment="indexer">gravitational waves</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05272" assignment="indexer">lagrangian function</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03747" assignment="upposted">functions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08554" assignment="upposted">riemann space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">It is shown that if the Einstein method of calculating the ''energy flux'' of gravitational fields is followed consistently, and in all cases generally covariant density of the √-gR lagrangian is used, then for the ''energy flux'' of gravitational waves a strictly zero value will be obtained. Thus the Einstein method, that has introduced noncovariant ''pseudotensors'' into the covariant physical theory, brings to a zero the value for the ''energy'' in general relativity</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Folomeshkin, V.N.; Vlasov, A.A.
Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov. Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij
On gravitational wave energy in Einstein gravitational theory
USSR
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

By the example of precise wave solutions for the Einstein equations it is shown that a standard commonly adopted formulation of energy-momentum problem with pseudotensors provides us either with a zero or sign-variable values for the energy of gravitational waves. It is shown that if in the Einstein gravitational theory a strict transition to the limits of weak fields is realised then the theory gives us an unambiguous zero result for weak gravitational waves. The well-known non-zero result arises due to incorrect transition to weak field approximation in the Einstein gravitation theory
January 1978

metadata.@content: Gladush, V.D. (Dnepropetrovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (Ukrainian SSR))
Static spherically-symmetrical solution for interacting scalar, electromagnetic and gravitational fields
Staticheskoe sfericheski-simmetrichnoe reshenie dlya vzaimodejstvuyushchikh skalyarnogo, ehlektromagnitnogo i gravitatsionnogo polej
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 23(3) p. 74-80; ISSN 0021-3411; Mar 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HAMILTON-JACOBI EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY
CONFIGURATION; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS

A spherically-symmetric case of the unified theory of interacting scalar, electromagnetic and gravitational fields, which was developed in the previous papers, is considered. An effective one-dimensional lagrangian and the corresponding Hamilton-Jakobi equation are found. A solution of the Einstein equation for the original system in the case considered is found using the solution of the latter equation. Some consequences of the found solution are studied. The relationship between the integration constants which ensures the total energy finitness is found
January 1980

metadata.@content: De Felice, F.; Nobili, L. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); Calvani, M. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Astronomia)
Charged singularities: repulsive effects
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(7) p. 2401-2409; ISSN 0305-4470; Jul 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CHARGES; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; KERR METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TEST PARTICLES
BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; METRICS

The repulsive phenomena which a particle experiences in the vicinity of a naked singularity are investigated in the Kerr-Newman space-time. The aim is to extend the knowledge of this fact to charged solutions and to have a direct indication of how, in these situations, the gravitational and electrostatic interactions are competing. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Verdaguer, E. (University Coll., Cardiff (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Astronomy)
Approximate Poincare invariance of the post-Newtonian metric tensor and gauge conditions
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(9) p. 3011-3021; ISSN 0305-4470; Sep 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; FLUIDS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; LORENTZ INVARIANCE; METRICS; POINCARE GROUPS; RECURSION RELATIONS; TENSORS
BASIC INTERACTIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

Imposing an approximate Poincare invariance on the metric tensor in the post-Newtonian scheme of general relativity, a recursive method is found which gives restrictions to the gauge conditions at each order of approximation. Those restrictions are explicitly calculated up to the second post-Newtonian approximation (PNA) for a bounded perfect fluid. At the first PNA the harmonic gauge which satisfies the imposed restrictions is chosen, but at the second PNA the harmonic gauge does not give a Poincare-invariant metric tensor and a modified harmonic gauge is chosen instead. Using these gauges, the gravitational interaction can be described by approximate Poincare-invariant equations of motion in the framework of predictive relativistic mechanics. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Mitskievic, N.V. (Lumumba Peoples Friendship Univ., Moscow (USSR). Dept. of Theoretical Physics); Pandey, S.N. (M.M.M. Engineering Coll., Gorakpur (India). Dept. of Applied Sciences)
On the motion of test particles in the field of a plane gravitational wave
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 12(7) p. 581-583; ISSN 0001-7701; Jul 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MOMENT OF INERTIA; MOTION; SPACE-TIME; TEST PARTICLES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

The motion of test particles in the field of a plane gravitational wave is studied in order to derive some general properties of such motion, especially the possibilities of repeated meetings of two inertially moving particles. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Mostepanenko, V.M. (Leningradskij Inst. Kinoinzhenerov (USSR))
On effect of quantized fields on the space-time metric in cosmology
O vliyanii kvantovannykh polej na metriku prostranstva-vremeni v kosmologii
Russian
USSR
Yadernaya Fizika; v. 31(6) p. 1690-1696; ISSN 0044-0027; 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Journal of Nuclear Physics (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; RENORMALIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; SECOND QUANTIZATION; SELF-CONSISTENT FIELD; SPACE-TIME; SPINOR FIELDS; TENSORS; VACUUM POLARIZATION; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS

The second time quantized scalar, spinor and vector fields in non-stationary external gravitational field are considered. In the class of space homogeneous isotropic space-times all the self-consistent models are found in which the vacuum energy density of quantized fields determines the external gravitational field in accordance with Einstein equations. It is shown that the self-consistent models without singularities exist
January 1980

metadata.@content: Pollock, M.D. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Inst. of Astronomy; Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Extraterrestrische Physik)
On the effect of a variable vacuum energy density upon the spectrum of the cosmological microwave background radiation
United Kingdom
Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society; v. 193(3) p. 825-831; ISSN 0035-8711; Dec 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BACKGROUND RADIATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GRAVITATION; MICROWAVE RADIATION; PLANCK RADIATION FORMULA; SPECTRA; UNIVERSE; VARIATIONS
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIATIONS

According to contempory ideas, the cosmological term Λ admitted by the Einstein equations represents the energy density of the vacuum. Kirzhnits and Linde have pointed out that if the gauge theories with broken symmetry are applicable to the Universe, then this cosmological term is not a constant. Rather, it must vary with temperature, and this causes a violation of the first law of thermodynamics, in its usual form: the vacuum assumes a dynamical role, and interacts with the observable matter, via the gravitational field. One consequence of this interaction is that the spectrum of equilibrium radiation which is decoupled from other matter cannot maintain an initially Planckian shape as the Universe evolves. The magnitude of this effect is determined by the relative size of the cosmological term and how it depends upon temperature, estimates of which have been made by Canuto and Lee, to first approximation, in three different models. Using these estimates, it is found, at least for one of these models, that it is possible to reproduce the distortion to the cosmological microwave background radiation observed by Woody and Richards, if it is assumed that variation of the cosmological term is accompanied by non-conservation of photon number. During the radiation-dominated phase of the Universe, a time-dependence of photon number is equivalent to a time-dependence of the gravitational constant G, whose value at the epoch of helium production would be approximately twice its value today. Such a change is not inconsistent with the theory of helium synthesis and its relation to observations. (author)
production would be approximately twice its value today. Such a change is not inconsistent with the theory of helium synthesis and its relation to observations. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Jafarizadeh, M.A.; Snyder, M.; Tze, H.C. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Quaternionic multi-S4 instantons in general covariant SU(2) Yang-Mills and HP(n) sigma-models
Netherlands
Nuclear Physics. B; v. 176(1) p. 221-242; ISSN 0550-3213; 8 Dec 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; INSTANTONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SIGMA-410 RESONANCES; SU-2 GROUPS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; YANG-MILLS THEORY

BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MESON RESONANCES; MESONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; RESONANCE PARTICLES; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

It is shown that the quaternionic maps xsup(n) = S4 → S4 are realized by the n-instanton solutions of two related types of general covariant field theories in four dimensions. They are, respectively, the Einstein-SU(2) Yang-Mills theory with a cosmological term and the new HP(m) sigma-models. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Tarski, J. (Technische Univ. Clausthal, Clausthal-Zellerfeld (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
Conformally flat spaces and gravitation
Netherlands
Letters in Mathematical Physics; v. 4(4) p. 339-346; ISSN 0377-9017; Jul 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; RIEMANN SPACE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

This article considers the theory of gravity which is defined by R2 as the free Lagrangian. The resulting equations are conformally invariant, and their equivalence to Einstein's equation is demonstrated (provided the stress tensor is traceless). The possibility of adapting this theory to massive point particles on a conformally flat background is discussed. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Narlikar, J.V.; Das, P.K. (Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Bombay 400 005)
Anomalous redshifts of quasi-stellar objects
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 240(2) p. 401-414; ISSN 0004-637X; 1 Sep 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DOPPLER EFFECT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GALAXIES; GALAXY NUCLEI; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MACH PRINCIPLE; QUASARS; RED SHIFT; SPACE-TIME
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HYPOTHESIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

This paper is based on the assumption that the observational evidence to date does point to the possibility that high-redshift quasars are physically associated with low-redshift galaxies. It is first argued that the excess (or anomalous) redshifts of the quasars in such associations are unlikely to be either of Doppler or of gravitational origin. A new source for this excess redshift was suggested by Narlikar on the basis of the Hoyle-Narlikar theory of gravitation which is based on Mach's principle. This idea is applied to the hypothesis that quasars may have been ejected from galactic nuclei. The dynamics of such an ejection and its observable consequences are discussed. In particular, it is shown that quasar alignments and redshift bunching which have been observed recently can be understood within the framework of this theory. Further test of this hypothesis are discussed
January 1980

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11367" assignment="upposted">hypothesis</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">This paper is based on the assumption that the observational evidence to date does point to the possibility that high-redshift quasars are physically associated with low-redshift galaxies. It is first argued that the excess (or anomalous) redshifts of the quasars in such associations are unlikely to be either of Doppler or of gravitational origin. A new source for this excess redshift was suggested by Narlikar on the basis of the Hoyle-Narlikar theory of gravitation which is based on Mach's principle. This idea is applied to the hypothesis that quasars may have been ejected from galactic nuclei. The dynamics of such an ejection and its observable consequences are discussed. In particular, it is shown that quasar alignments and redshift bunching which have been observed recently can be understood within the framework of this theory. Further test of this hypothesis are discussed</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Cosenza, M.; Herrera, L.; Esculpi, M.; Witten, L. (Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela)
Some models of anisotropic spheres in general relativity
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; STAR MODELS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS

A heuristic procedure is developed to obtain interior solutions of Einstein's equations for anisotropic matter from known solutions for isotropic matter. Five known solutions are generalized to give solutions with anisotropic sources
January 1981

metadata.@content: Ward, R.S. (Trinity Coll., Dublin (Ireland). School of Mathematics)
Self-dual space-times with cosmological constant
Germany
Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 78(1) p. 1-17; ISSN 0010-3616; Nov 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COMPLEX MANIFOLDS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; GREEN FUNCTION; RICCI TENSOR; SPACE-TIME; TWISTOR THEORY

It is shown that self-dual solutions of Einstein's equations, with cosmological constant lambda, correspond to certain complex manifolds. This result generalizes the work of Penrose, who dealt with the case lambda = 0. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Ray, J.R. (Clemson Univ., SC (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Neutrinos in cosmological models
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(4) p. 1213-1216; ISSN 0033-068X; Apr 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; NEUTRINOS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

We present a derivation of the solution of the Einstein-Weyl equations in the Bianchi V cosmological spacetime. The solution is derived by using the earlier results for plane-symmetry. In the limit when the anisotropic Bianchi V model goes over into the isotropic model the gravitational field collapses to zero. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Nakamura, Takashi; Miyama, Shoken; Sasaki, Misao (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics); Maeda, Kei-ichi.
General relativistic collapse of an axially symmetric star, 1
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(4) p. 1229-1244; ISSN 0033-068X; Apr 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; AXIAL SYMMETRY; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; HYDRODYNAMICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; STAR EVOLUTION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; SYMMETRY

Using the ADM formalism, we give a method of solving the general relativistic collapse of an axially symmetric star by the numerical calculation. At t = 0, we solve the constraint equations to determine the initial data of the metric tensors and the extrinsic curvatures under given angular momentum distribution and baryon number distribution. An example of the initial data is shown. At later time the evolution equations of the metric and the hydrodynamics equations are solved. The constraint equations are not solved but used to see the accuracy of the numerical calculation. The details of the numerical techniques are shown for the spherically symmetric case. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Wesson, P.S.
Cambridge Univ. (UK)
Galactic astrophysics and self-similar space-times
United Kingdom
1978; 181 p; ;  Available from British Library, Boston Spa, Wetherby, West Yorks. No. D29620/80; Thesis (Ph.D.).
Thesis/Dissertation
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ASTROPHYSICS; BRIGHTNESS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DISTRIBUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; GALAXY CLUSTERS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE-TIME; VELOCITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

The object of this work is to find a mathematical model of a clustered, inhomogeneous distribution of galaxies, and to compare the model with observations. A set of models is derived that represent self-similar solutions to Einstein's equations of general relativity. The simplest example of these self-similar space-times is then taken and compared to observations of the velocity distribution, magnitudes and number-density distribution of the galaxies. (author)
January 1978

metadata.@content: Lake, K. (Astronomy Group, Department of Physics, Queen's University at Kingston, Ontario, Canada)
Local inhomogeneities in a Robertson-Walker background. II. Flux conditions at boundary surfaces
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 242(3) p. 1238-1242; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Dec 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; COSMIC DUST; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION
CONFIGURATION; DUSTS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Energy flux doncitions imposed on spherical boundary surfaces are examined. The zero flux restriction which is the hallmark of the standard ''Swiss cheese'' type construction, is relaxed. We discuss a class of locally inhomogeneous exact solutions to the Einstein equations which admit an effectively Newtonian accretion mode
January 1980

metadata.@content: Obregon, O.; Ryan, M.P. Jr. (Department of Physics, Universidad Autonoma Metropolitana--Iztapalapa, Mexico 13, D. F., Mexico)
Bianchi type IX cosmological models with homogeneous spinor fields
United States
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIRAC OPERATORS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; HAMILTONIANS; SPINOR FIELDS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM OPERATORS

The diagonal and symmetric Bianchi type IX models are coupled to a homogeneous spinor field. An action for the combined fields is constructed, where the orthonormal basis used is given explicitly in terms of the metric. This allows one to vary the action with respect to the metric and the spinor fields only. Next, a Hamiltonian formulation is given, and a qualitative solution for the problem is presented. We also show that the k = +1 FRW (Friedmann--Robertson--Walker) model is not compatible with a homogeneous spinor field, while the more complicated models are
January 1981

metadata.@content: Banerjee, A.; Santos, N.O. (Instituto de Fisica-Ilha do Fundao, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Brazil)
Homogeneous cosmological model in general scalar-tensor theory
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(10) p. 2111-2115; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCALAR FIELDS; TENSOR FORCES; TENSORS; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Some general results on spatially homogeneous cosmological models are obtained in the general scalar-tensor theory proposed by Nordtvedt and Barker. Cosmological equations for a Bianchi type-I empty universe are solved and the behavior of the model is discussed. It is found that the universe expands from the initial singularity of zero volume and then contracts back. There is a significant difference between the nature of the singularity in this model and that in the corresponding Kasner universe in Einstein's theory
January 1981

metadata.@content: Tod, K.P. (Oxford Univ. (UK). Mathematical Inst.)
Curved twistor spaces and H-space
United States
Surveys in High Energy Physics; v. 1(4) p. 299-312; ISSN 0142-2413; Aug 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COMPLEX MANIFOLDS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; TWISTOR THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS

The curved twistor space construction of Penrose for anti-self-dual solutions to the Einstein vacuum equations is described. Curved twistor spaces are defined and it is shown with the aid of an example how to obtain them by deforming the complex structure of regions of flat twistor space. The connection of this procedure with Newman's H-space construction via asymptotic twistor space is outlined. (Auth.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Kundu, P. (Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Rochester, Rochester, New York 14627)
Multipole expansion of stationary asymptotically flat vacuum metrics in general relativity
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; MULTIPOLES; POWER SERIES; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SERIES EXPANSION

A multipole expansion scheme is introduced for a wide class of stationary, asymptotically flat, vacuum solutions of Einstein's equations using the conformal techniques of Geroch and Hansen. An intrinsic choice of the conformal factor and suitable asymptotic flatness conditions enable one to express the rescaled gravitational mass and angular momentum potentials and the rescaled spatial metric as power series in normal coordinates around a point Λ representing the spatial infinity on the conformal manifold. The coefficients of this expansion are certain nonlinear combinations of the Hansen multipole moments. As an example the Schwarzschild metric is discussed in the present framework
January 1981

metadata.@content: Korkina, M.P. (Dnepropetrovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (Ukrainian SSR))
Static configurations with ultrarelativistic equation of state in the center
Staticheskie konfiguratsii s ul'trarelyativistskim uravneniem sostoyaniya v tsentre
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 24(5) p. 87-89; ISSN 0021-3411; May 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; LIQUIDS; MASS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION
CONFIGURATION; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; METRICS

The class of Einstein equations solution for liquid spheres with final values of energy and pressure density in the center is obtained. The 4-th Tolman solution and Adler solution belong to this class. A new solution is given for which lacing with external empty space is made. For ultrarelativistic equation of state in the center configuration parameters are calculated
January 1981

metadata.@content: Moody, M.C.; Ray, J.R. (Department of Physics and Astronomy, Clemson University, Clemson, South Carolina 29631)
Application of energy conditions and algebraic classification in general relativity
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ALGEBRA; EIGENVALUES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; TENSORS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

The application of the ideas of the symmetry classification of space-time, the algebraic classification of the energy-momentum tensor, and the dominant energy conditions for macroscopic matter to the problem of searching for solutions to the field equations of general relativity is discussed. These ideas are then specifically applied to certain space-times of G4 symmetry to demonstrate the ability of this approach to obtain both new and general solutions. For macroscopic matter, G4I1 symmetry is shown to have only one general solution; symmetries G4V, G4VII1, and G4VII2 are shown to allow no solutions whatever; and the method is used to discover a new solution for G4VIII1 symmetry. A similar solution would be expected for G4VIII2 symmetry
January 1981

metadata.@content: Page, D.N.; Geilker, C.D. (Department of Physics, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pennsylvania 16802)
Indirect evidence for quantum gravity
United States
Physical Review Letters; v. 47(14) p. 979-982; ISSN 0031-9007; 5 Oct 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HEISENBERG PICTURE; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; WAVE FUNCTIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

An experiment gave results inconsistent with the simplest alternative to quantum gravity, the semiclassical Einstein equations. This evidence supports (but does not prove) the hypothesis that a consistent theory of gravity coupled to quantized matter should also have the gravitational field quantized
January 1981

metadata.@content: Antonov, V.I.
Bilocal formalism of general relativity theory and the problem of energy-momentum of gravitational field
Bilokal'nyj formalizm obshchej teorii otnositel'nosti i problema ehnergii-impul'sa gravitatsionnogo polya
Russian
USSR
Vestnik Moskovskogo Universiteta, Seriya 3. Fizika, Astronomiya; v. 21(5) p. 14-20; ISSN 0579-9392; Sep - Oct 1980; For English translation see the journal Moscow University Physics Bulletin (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; LOCALITY; NONLOCAL POTENTIAL; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; METRICS; POTENTIALS

The expression for the energy-momentum tensor of the gravitational field is proposed on the basis of the bilocal formalism. The concept of referential transfer realizing the monade method of setting the system of reference in the bilocal formalism. It is noted that in this case the gravitational field energy coincides with the hamiltonian concerning weak equality. The energy-momentum vector of the field system is represented as a sum of two surface integrals having the meaning of the total energy and total momentum. As an example calculated are the total energy and total momentum of the Schwarzschild field in the ''central'' system of reference in relation to the infinitely remote point. The relation of the transfer way type with the space-time symmetry properties is discussed
January 1980

metadata.@content: Eriguchi, Yoshiharu (Tokyo Univ. (Japan). Coll. of General Education)
Rapidly rotating and fully general relativistic polytropes
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 64(6) p. 2009-2020; ISSN 0033-068X; Dec 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DRAG; EIGENVALUES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MASS; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROTATION; SPHEROIDS; STAR EVOLUTION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A technique used in numerical computations of the Newtonian rotating polytropes has been generalized to compute general relativistic polytropes. Full equations for the rotating polytrope in general relativity have been numerically integrated without any approximation. The strength of relativity is measured μ = p sub(c)/epsilon sub(c)c2 where p sub(c), epsilon sub(c) and c are the central pressure, the central energy density and the light velocity, respectively. Rotating sequences with μ = 0.001 (almost Newtonian case), 0.25 (mildly relativistic case) and 0.5 (highly relativistic case) have been obtained for the polytropic index N = 1.5. The largest rotation in each sequence is so rapid that the surface velocity at the equator reaches about one-third of the light velocity for μ = 0.25 and 0.5 cases. (author)
January 1980

Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COHERENT RADIATION; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INTERFERENCE; PHASE SHIFT; SPACE-TIME; SUPERFLUIDITY; YANG-MILLS THEORY
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; RADIATIONS

The phase shift due to gravitational field and all gauge fields in the interference of two coherent beams is obtained. In the case of gravitation, it is shown, for a particle with arbitrary spin, that there exists a phase shift due to the coupling of spin to space-time curvature. This and the corresponding phase shift for gauge fields are analogous to the Aharonov-Bohm effect. The classical limit for particles moving in gravitational and gauge fields is obtained from the phase shift. For gravitation, in the absence of torsion, this is the Mathisson-Papapetrou equation, which is thereby shown to be the classical limit of the Dirac and Bargmann-Wigner wave equations, generalized to curved space-time. In the presence of torsion, a modification of this equation, given by Hehl, is obtained. It is pointed out that gravity is not a pure gauge field and that it must be placed in the more general category of an ''interference field'' which contains both gravity and gauge fields as special cases. The field equations for gauge fields and gravity are obtained from the heuristic assumption that a particle acts on a field in a manner which depends on how it responds to the field via the phase shift. For gauge fields, they contain the Yang-Mills equations as a special case. For gravity, a modification of Einstein's field equations is obtained, which corresponds to the Lagrangian (1/16πK).(2Λ+R) + (1/32πf)Rsub(μνrho)sup(σ) Rsup(μνrho)sub(σ), where the Riemann tensor contains torsion and K, f, Λ are constants (Λ may be zero). The relevance of the phase shift, due to rotation, to the quantization of vortices in superfluid helium is pointed out. This suggests that the curl of the superfluid velocity may obey a system of equations analogous to Maxwell's equations and the analogue of the magnetic monopole for superfluid helium is also introduced. (author)

where the Riemann tensor contains torsion and K, f, Λ are constants (Λ may be zero). The relevance of the phase shift, due to rotation, to the quantization of vortices in superfluid helium is pointed out. This suggests that the curl of the superfluid velocity may obey a system of equations analogous to Maxwell's equations and the analogue of the magnetic monopole for superfluid helium is also introduced. (author)
January 1979

metadata.@content: Drechsler, W. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Muenchen (Germany, F.R.))
Nonlinear wave equation for torsion
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; TORSION; VECTOR FIELDS; WAVE PROPAGATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

Specializing the geometry of a Riemann-Cartan space-time U4 to the case deltaf a completely antisymmetric torsion tensor (axial vector torsion, *Ksub(μ)) a set of nonlinear wave equations and constraints are established relating the torsion of th U4 geometry to an axial vector source current. This current obeys an anomaly relation similar to the axial current in spinor electrodynamics. (orig.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Page, D.N. (Pennsylvania State Univ., University Park (USA). Dept. of Physics)
A periodic but nonstationary gravitational instanton
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; INSTANTONS; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY
BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES

A periodic but nonstationary asymptotically locally flat gravitional instanton with boundary S2 X S1/Z2 is obtained by a limiting procedure from the Einstein metric on K3. It has zero action, four parameters, and no Killing vectors in general. (orig.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Gross, D.J.; Perry, M.J.; Yaffe, L.G. (Department of Physics, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544)
Instability of flat space at finite temperature
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(2) p. 330-355; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jan 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

BLACK HOLES; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; GRAVITONS; INSTABILITY; INSTANTONS; PARTITION FUNCTIONS; PERTURBATION THEORY; PROPAGATOR; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SPACE-TIME; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE

ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; INTEGRALS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MECHANICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

The instabilities of quantum gravity are investigated using the path-integral formulation of Einstein's theory. A brief review is given of the classical gravitational instabilities, as well as the stability of flat space. The Euclidean path-integral representation of the partition function is employed to discuss the instability of flat space at finite temperature. Semiclassical, or saddle-point, approximations are utilized. We show how the Jeans instability arises as a tachyon in the graviton propagator when small perturbations about hot flat space are considered. The effect due to the Schwarzschild instanton is studied. The small fluctuations about this instanton are analyzed and a negative mode is discovered. This produces, in the semiclassical approximation, an imaginary part of the free energy. This is interpreted as being due to the metastability of hot flat space to nucleate black holes. These then evolve by evaporation or by accretion of thermal gravitons, leading to the instability of hot flat space. The nucleation rate of black holes is calculated as a function of temperature
January 1982

metadata.@content: Chao, W.Z. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics)
Self-similar cosmological models
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(7) p. 625-647; ISSN 0001-7701; Jul 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MECHANICS; ROTATION; SYMMETRY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The kinematics and dynamics of self-similar cosmological models are discussed. The degrees of freedom of the solutions of Einstein's equations for different types of models are listed. The relation between kinematic quantities and the classifications of the self-similarity group is examined. All dust local rotational symmetry models have been found. (author)
January 1981

The global existence problem and cosmic censorship in general relativity
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(9) p. 887-892; ISSN 0001-7701; Sep 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GLOBAL ANALYSIS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

Two global existence conjectures for the Einstein equations are formulated and their relevance to the cosmic censorship conjecture discussed. It is argued that the reformulation of the cosmic censorship conjecture as a global existence problem renders it more amenable to direct analytical attack. To demonstrate the facility of this approach the cosmological version of the global existence conjecture is proved for the Gowdy spacetimes on T3 X R. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Westpfahl, K.; Goller, M. (Freiburg Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Fakultaet fuer Physik)
Gravitational scattering of two relativistic particles in post-linear approximation
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 26(17) p. 573-576; ISSN 0024-1318; 22 Dec 1979
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SCATTERING
BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

The problem of two comparable point masses interacting via a weak gravitational field is considered in post-linear approximation. The gravitational field is considered as a small deviation from the Minkowski metrics and Einstein equations are treated in a perturbative approach. (author)
January 1979

metadata.@content: Kalashnikov, O.K.; Klimov, V.V. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Fizicheskij Inst.)
Unified gauge models and the very early Universe
Kalibrovochnye modeli edinogo vzaimodejstviya i ochen' rannyaya Vselennaya
Russian
USSR
Yadernaya Fizika; v. 33(6) p. 1572-1580; ISSN 0044-0027; 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Journal of Nuclear Physics (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COUPLING CONSTANTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; PERTURBATION THEORY; SCHWINGER FUNCTIONAL EQUATIONS; SU-5 GROUPS; ULTRAHIGH TEMPERATURE; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; UNIVERSE
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

For arbitrary grand unification model the thermodynamical potential is calculated for superhigh temperatures, including exchange and correlation terms. The obtained results are written in a more concrete form for the realistic SU(5) model, then they are further improved by means of the renormalization group. The obtained equation of state is applied to describe the expansion of the Universe at very high temperatures. It is found that the temperature of the relict gravitational radiation must be of the order of magnitude of 1 K
January 1981

metadata.@content: Jantzen, R.T. (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica)
Variational principles in cosmology
Italy
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
CLASSICAL MECHANICS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HAMILTONIAN FUNCTION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY GROUPS; VARIATIONAL METHODS; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MECHANICS

The difficulties with the application of Lagrangian or Hamiltonian formulations to spatially homogeneous cosmology are examined from a new point of view and a simple explanation is given for the necessary modifications of those formulations. A rather natural restriction on the shift vector field freedom minimizes the extent of the required modifications, leaving the dynamical Einstein equations in the form of a Lagrangian/Hamiltonian system driven by a nonpotential force. The symmetry group of this classical mechanical system is a representation of the diffeomorphism group corresponding to the restricted class of shift vector fields. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Canuto, V.M. (National Aeronautics and Space Administration, New York (USA). Goddard Inst. for Space Studies; City Coll., New York (USA). Dept. of Physics); Goldman, I. (National Aeronautics and Space Administration, New York (USA). Goddard Inst. for Space Studies)
Atomic and gravitational clocks
United Kingdom
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

ATOMIC CLOCKS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; EQUIVALENCE PRINCIPLE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; QUANTUM ELECTRODYNAMICS; SCALE INVARIANCE; SYNCHRONIZATION; TIME MEASUREMENT; UNITS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELECTRODYNAMICS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

Atomic and gravitational clocks are governed by the laws of electrodynamics and gravity respectively. While the strong equivalence principle (SEP) assumes that the two clocks have been synchronous at all times, recent planetary data seem to suggest a possible violation of the SEP. Past analysis of the implications of an SEP violation on different physical phenomena revealed no disagreement. However, these studies assumed that the two different clocks can be consistently constructed within the framework. The concept of scale invariance, and the physical meaning of different systems of units, are now reviewed and the construction of two clocks that do not remain synchronous-whose rates are related by a non-constant function βsub(a)-is demonstrated. The cosmological character of βsub(a) is also discussed. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Froyland, J. (Institute of Physics, University of Oslo, Oslo, Norway)
Static, spherically symmetric scalar fields with a traceless energy-momentum tensor in general relativity
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(6) p. 1470-1473; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Mar 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; TENSORS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A problem of zero-mass scalar fields coupled to the gravitational field in the static, spherically symmetric case, is completely solved for a traceless energy-momentum tensor. Among the solutions is one with a conformally flat and asymptotically flat metirc with total energy equal to the Schwarzschild mass
January 1982

metadata.@content: Fennelly, A.J. (Space Sciences Laboratory, Marshall Space Flight Center)
Observer reference triad rotation, magnetic fields, and rotation in Euclidean cosmological models
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 252(2) p. 410-417; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jan 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BACKGROUND RADIATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; HYDRODYNAMICS; INTERGALACTIC SPACE; MAGNETIC FIELDS; MAXWELL EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; VORTICES
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; RADIATIONS; SPACE

We show that a cosmological model with Euclidean space sections admits fluid flows if a magnetic field is present. Further, if observer reference frames spin in their response to the universe, a vorticity may exist. We can set limits on any present intergalactic magnetic field of H/sub R/<5.38 x 10-10 gauss
January 1982

metadata.@content: Tod, K.P. (Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, Oxford, England)
Self-dual Kerr--Schild metrics and null Maxwell fields
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DUALITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; KERR METRIC; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SPINORS; TWISTOR THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE
A construction for self-dual solutions of Einstein's equations with metric in Kerr--Schild form from null electromagnetic fields in Minkowski space is described. Two examples are given
January 1982

metadata.@content: Cosenza, M.; Herrera, L.; Esculpi, M.; Witten, L. (Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela)
Evolution of radiating anisotropic spheres in general relativity
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(10) p. 2527-2535; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATTER; METRICS; RED SHIFT; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A method used to study the evolution of radiating fluid spheres is extended to the case of anisotropic spheres. Explicit forms of the equations are written down for two models. One of the models is numerically integrated to display the difference between the isotropic and the anisotropic models for different degrees of anisotropy
January 1982

metadata.@content: Zel'dovich, Y.B.
Vacuum theory: a possible solution to the singularity problem of cosmology
United States
Soviet Physics - Uspekhi; v. 24(3) p. 216-230; Mar 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The present state of the question of the vacuum energy, cosmological constant, and vacuum polarization in a curved non-Euclidean space-time, i.e., in a gravitational field, is discussed. A cosmological model of the early Universe that is a self-consistent solution of the Einstein equations with vacuum polarization on the right-hand side has many attractive features
January 1981

metadata.@content: Porrill, J.; Stewart, J.M. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics)
Electromagnetic and gravitational fields in a Schwarzschild space-time
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 376(1766) p. 451-463; ISSN 0080-4630; 19 May 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

The propagation of electromagnetic fields and linearized perturbations of the vacuum Einstein equations on a Schwarzchild background space-time are discussed, and relations between the asymptotic form of the fields at null infinity and the data are established. Without suitable restrictions on the data, perturbations of a Schwarzschild space-time need not be weakly asymptotically simple. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Dietz, W. (Wuerzburg Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Astronomie und Astrophysik); Hoenselaers, C. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.))
A new class of bipolar vacuum gravitational fields
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 382(1782) p. 221-229; ISSN 0080-4630; 8 Jul 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; TRANSFORMATIONS; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

This paper presents the Ernst potential and the full four-dimensional metric for a stationary axisymmetric solution of the vacuum Einstein equations, which is obtained by application of two rank-zero H.K.X. transformations to the general static Weyl solution. A suitable Ehlers transformation ensures asymptotic flatness. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Durgapal, M.C. (Kumaun Univ., Nainital (India). Dept. of Physics)
A class of new exact solutions in general relativity
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(8) p. 2637-2644; ISSN 0305-4470; Aug 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; STARS

A class of new exact solutions is obtained for spherically symmetric and static configurations by considering a simple relation esup(ν) is proportional to (1+x)sup(n). For each integral value of n the field equations can be solved exactly and a new exact solution is obtained. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Hawking, S.W. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics)
Why is the apparent cosmological constant zero
Unified theories of elementary particles
Germany

Breitenlohner, P.; Duerr, H.P. (eds.); Lecture notes in physics; v. 160; 217 p; ISBN 3-540-11560-9; 1982; p. 167-175; Springer; Berlin, Germany, F.R; Heisenberg symposium; Muenchen, Germany, F.R; 16 - 21 Jul 1981
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUCTUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCALING LAWS; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS; VARIATIONS

The apparent cosmological constant is measured to be zero with an accuracy greater than that for any other quantity in Physics. On the other hand one would expect a large induced cosmological constant unless the various contributions from symmetry breaking, etc., were balanced against each other to better than 1 part in 1040. It is suggested that this puzzle can be resolved by assuming that quantum state of the universe is not chosen at random but contains only states with a very large Euclidean 4-volume. In this situation the actual value of the cosmological constant is unobservable. There are solutions of the Einstein equations with a large cosmological constant which appear nearly flat on large length scales but which are highly curved and topologically complicated on very small length scales. Estimates are made of the spectrum of these topological fluctuations and of their effects on the propagation of particles. (orig.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Ludvigsen, M. (York Univ. (UK))
Angular momentum of isolated systems in general relativity
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(2) p. 135-153; ISSN 0001-7701; Feb 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ANGULAR MOMENTUM TRANSFER; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; ORBITS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; SCATTERING
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; MOMENTUM TRANSFER

Solutions of Einstein's equations which describe isolated scattering systems are discussed and a set of asymptotic boundary conditions, which appear to characterize such solutions, is proposed. These conditions are then used to obtain a canonical definition of the total amount of angular momentum radiated by such a system. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Meinhardt, J. R. (Tel Aviv Univ. (Israel). Dept. of Mathematical Sciences); Leibowitz, E. (Ben-Gurion Univ. of the Negev, Beersheba (Israel))
Stationary axially symmetric vacuum metrics maximality of the local symmetry group
Italy
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; SYMMETRY GROUPS; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY

A detailed proof is given to the previously published result, concerning the local symmetry groups relating distinct solutions of the Einstein equations. The maximal local symmetry group associated with the exterior metric of rotating bodies is proved to be three-parametric. (author)
January 1978

metadata.@content: Espinosa, J.M. (Department of Mathematics and Physics, Texas Woman's University, Denton, Texas 76204)
Heuristic extension of the Schwarzschild metric
United States
American Journal of Physics; v. 50(6) p. 508-513; ISSN 0002-9505; Jun 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

The Schwarzschild solution of Einstein's equations of gravitation has several singularities. It is known that the singularity at r = 2Gm/c2 is only apparent, a result of the coordinates in which the solution was found. Paradoxical results occuring near the singularity show the system of coordinates is incomplete. We introduce a simple, two-dimensional metric with an apparent singularity that makes it incomplete. By a straightforward, heuristic procedure we extend and complete this simple metric. We then use the same procedure to give a heuristic derivation of the Kruskal system of coordinates, which is known to extend the Schwarzschild manifold past its apparent singularity and produce a complete manifold
January 1982

It is known that the singularity at r = 2Gm/c<sup>2</sup> is only apparent, a result of the coordinates in which the solution was found. Paradoxical results occuring near the singularity show the system of coordinates is incomplete. We introduce a simple, two-dimensional metric with an apparent singularity that makes it incomplete. By a straightforward, heuristic procedure we extend and complete this simple metric. We then use the same procedure to give a heuristic derivation of the Kruskal system of coordinates, which is known to extend the Schwarzschild manifold past its apparent singularity and produce a complete manifold</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Linet, B. (Paris-6 Univ., 75 (France). Inst. Henri Poincare)
Absorption of gravitational waves by nearly Newtonian systems
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(5) p. 479-492; ISSN 0001-7701; May 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ABSORPTION; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; DIMENSIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FREQUENCY DEPENDENCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MECHANICS

The formula is determined giving the energy absorbed per unit time by a nearly Newtonian system whose dimensions are small compared with the wavelength of an incident plane gravitational wave. The variation of angular momentum is also indicated. In order to determine them, the nonlinear nature of the Einstein equations must be taken into account. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Cooperstock, F.I. (Equipe de Recherche Associee au C. N. R. S. no533, Laboratoire de Physique Theorique, Institut Henri Poincare, 11, rue Pierre et Marie Curie, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France)
Axially symmetric two-body problem in general relativity. IV. Boundary conditions, time scales, and the quadrupole formula
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(12) p. 3126-3136; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jun 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; RENORMALIZATION; SYMMETRY; TWO-BODY PROBLEM
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MANY-BODY PROBLEM; RADIATIONS

The analysis of the field equations and the conservation laws is extended into the skin boundary region which maintains the initially static configuration of the two fluid spheres. Although this leads to a correction of the gravitational-radiation energy-loss rate from a dependence of Eapprox.α-4rho0-4 to α-6rho0-2, the importance of the nonlinear structure-dependent terms remain and the essential conclusion, that the quadrupole formula does not apply to this problem, is unaltered. The hydrodynamic, stress-breaking, and free-fall time scales are considered. It is shown that insofar as the quadrupole-formula comparison for free-fall is concerned, only the contribution from bulk motion of the fluid spheres need be considered since tidal quadrupole deformation contributes negligibly to the quadrupole formula. With reference to our problem, it is shown that a recent derivation of the quadrupole formula for free-fall is incorrect and it is suggested that certain other derivations may be applicable only to the radiation damping of a single body
January 1982

metadata.@content: Dirac, P.A.M. (Florida State Univ., Tallahassee (USA). Dept. of Physics)
The variation of G and the quantum theory
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 1-6; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; HYPOTHESIS; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The Einstein theory of gravitation has had enormous success. Various tests have been made and every time the Einstein theory has been confirmed and rival theories have been knocked out. The author discusses the Large Numbers Hypothesis within the framework of the Einstein theory. (Auth.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Ray, J.R. (Clemson University, SC (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Spacetimes with null symmetry as models for gravitating systems
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 253-255; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

Spacetimes with null symmetry have been classified by Kruchkovich. He gives a complete classification of the possible types of gravitational fields having null symmetry. In other words, Kruchkovich gives the killing vectors and spacetime metrics in a coordinate chart for these spacetimes. Spacetimes with null symmetry had not been investigated systematically in general relativity until a few years ago. The author discusses the incompatibility between the Einstein equations and the assumption of null symmetry for the spacetime. (Auth.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Kerner, R. (Paris-6 Univ., 75 (France). Dept. de Mecanique)
Cosmology without singularity and nonlinear gravitational Lagrangians
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(5) p. 453-469; ISSN 0001-7701; May 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SINGULARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS

The generalized Einstein equations derived from the Lagrangian which is an arbitrary function of R are investigated. The importance of the saturation phenomenon is underlined, which may replace the role of a cosmological constant. The spherically symmetric homogeneous model is analyzed in more detail, and an approximate solution without singularity is constructed using the method of matched asymptotic expansions. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Paik, H.J.; Chan, H.A. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Experimental examination of the inverse-square law of gravitation
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 567 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 1013-1018; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUIVALENCE PRINCIPLE; ERRORS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAPLACIAN; MASS; POISSON EQUATION; ROTATION
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

A ''source-independent'' null experiment for the inverse-square law of gravitation could be performed with a three-axis gravity gradiometer as a null detector of (del)2phi, the Laplacian of gravitational potential. With a gradient sensitivity of 10-11 s-2Hzsup(-1/2) and an integration time of 106 s, one could resolve the force law to one part in 105 in the range between 102 m and 104 m, employing a mountain or a rock as the gravitating source. In a laboratory experiment one could obtain a resolution of the force law to better than one part in 103 in the range between 1 m and 10 m using a rotating dumbbell of a reasonable size as a source. (Auth.)
January 1982

      <categories>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03154" assignment="indexer">equivalence principle</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03207" assignment="indexer">errors</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04114" assignment="indexer">gravitation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05351" assignment="indexer">laplacian</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05885" assignment="indexer">mass</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07670" assignment="indexer">poisson equation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08599" assignment="indexer">rotation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02642" assignment="upposted">differential equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05906" assignment="upposted">mathematical operators</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="21631" assignment="upposted">partial differential equations</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <qualifiers>
        <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier>
      </qualifiers>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A ''source-independent'' null experiment for the inverse-square law of gravitation could be performed with a three-axis gravity gradiometer as a null detector of (del)<sup>2</sup>phi, the Laplacian of gravitational potential. With a gradient sensitivity of 10<sup>-11</sup> s<sup>-2</sup>Hzsup(-1/2) and an integration time of 10<sup>6</sup> s, one could resolve the force law to one part in 10<sup>5</sup> in the range between 10<sup>2</sup> m and 10<sup>4</sup> m, employing a mountain or a rock as the gravitating source. In a laboratory experiment one could obtain a resolution of the force law to better than one part in 10<sup>3</sup> in the range between 1 m and 10 m using a rotating dumbbell of a reasonable size as a source. (Auth.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

      <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center>

    </administratives>

</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Plebanski, J.F.; Garcia, D. (Centro de Investigacion y de Estudios Avanzados del Instituto Politecnico Nacional, Apartado Postal 14-740, 07000 Mexico, D. F., Mexico)
Multiexponent Weyl metrics
United States
Physical Review Letters; v. 48(21) p. 1447-1450; ISSN 0031-9007; 24 May 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

Three subclasses of stationary axially symmetric diagonal Weyl metrics satisfying the empty-space Einstein equations are presented in an explicit form. These solutions generalize the C metric (mass with constant acceleration) and contain six free parameters. Four of these parameters appear as exponents playing a role similar to delta in the Tomimatsu-Sato solution (mass with quadrupole moment). For integer values of the exponents these metrics are constructed from rational functions only. Special cases include various metrics of physical interest
January 1982

metadata.@content: Nakanishi, Noboru (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Mathematical Sciences)
Indefinite-metric quantum field theory of general relativity, 14
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 66(5) p. 1843-1857; ISSN 0033-068X; Nov 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

DIRAC OPERATORS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; LORENTZ INVARIANCE; METRICS; POINCARE GROUPS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SUPERGRAVITY; SYMMETRY BREAKING
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM OPERATORS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

In the manifestly covariant canonical formalism of quantum gravity, the sixteen-dimensional Noether supercurrents are explicitly calculated in a unified way and are shown to reproduce the generators of the sixteen-dimensional Poincare-like superalgebra. Some fundamental remarks are made concerning the general linear invariance of the theory. The Lorentz generators under which the Dirac field behaves as a world spinor are shown to be obtained as a consequence of the simultaneous spontaneous breakdown of general linear invariance and internal Lorentz invariance. It is emphasized that Poincare invariance should not be regarded as a first principle of the most fundamental theory. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Piran, T. (Texas Univ., Austin (USA). Center for Relativity)
Numerical relativity
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 679-700; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979; 73 refs.
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

BIBLIOGRAPHIES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; HYDRODYNAMICS; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; REGGE CALCULUS; REVIEWS; RICCI TENSOR; SPACE-TIME; WAVE PROPAGATION
DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; TENSORS

There are many recent developments in numerical relativity, but there remain important unsolved theoretical and practical problems. The author reviews existing numerical approaches to solution of the exact Einstein equations. A framework for classification and comparison of different numerical schemes is presented. Recent numerical codes are compared using this framework. The discussion focuses on new developments and on currently open questions, excluding a review of numerical techniques. (Auth.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Nakamura, Takashi (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)
General relativistic collapse of axially symmetric stars leading to the formation of rotating black holes
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 65(6) p. 1876-1890; ISSN 0033-068X; Jun 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

ACCURACY; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; AXIAL SYMMETRY; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; KERR FIELD; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROTATION; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; STAR EVOLUTION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SYMMETRY

Numerical calculations have been made for the formation process of axisymmetric, rotating black holes of 10 M sub(solar mass). The initial density of a star is about 3 x 1013 g/cm3. Numerical results are classified mainly by q which corresponds to +a+/M in a Kerr black hole. For q <= 0.3, the effect of rotation to the gravitational collapse is only to make the shape of matter oblate. For 0.3 <= 1 <= 0.95, although the distribution of matter is disk-like, a ring-like peak of proper density appears. This ring is inside the apparent horizon, which is always formed in the case q <= 0.95. For q >= 0.95, no apparent horizon is formed. The distribution of matter shows a central disk plus an expanding ring. It is found that electromagnetic-like field in the [(2 + 1) + 1]-formalism plays an important role in a formation of a rotating black hole. Local conservation of angular momentum is checked. Accuracy of constraint equations is also shown to see the truncation error in the numerical calculations. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Ehlers, J. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Munich, West Germany)
Isolated systems in general relativity
United States
Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences; v. 336 p. 279-294; ISSN 0077-8923; 1980; 13. Texas conference on relativistic astrophysics; Munich (Germany, F.R.); 14 - 20 Dec 1978; CONF-781245--
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

Some problems regarding the relativistic theory of isolated systems are described. The description of bodies as a whole and the derivation of their overall laws of motion are considered along with the asymptotics of gravitational fields near various parts of infinity. Attention is given to the connection between near-zone and asymptotic energy-momentum balances, and to the meanings of the following terms: asymptotically flat, physically reasonable T(ab), and condition for absence of incident radiation. In addition, an improved version of a weak-field, slow-motion approximation method for constructing relativistic models of isolated systems containing more than one body is outlined
January 1980

metadata.@content: Debever, R.; Kamran, N. (Brussels Univ. (Belgium))
Empty spaces and perfect fluids with homothetic transformation
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(7) p. 637-646; ISSN 0001-7701; Jul 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; TRANSFORMATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; SPACE

A class of Lorentzian metrics in one variable that admits homothetic transformation is introduced. Solutions of Einstein's empty space equations are presented. The case of perfect fluids is discussed. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Barrow, J.D. (California Univ., Berkeley (USA). Dept. of Physics)
General relativistic chaos and nonlinear dynamics
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(6) p. 523-530; ISSN 0001-7701; Jun 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MECHANICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; RANDOMNESS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

How new ideas in dynamical systems theory find application in the description of general relativistic systems is described. The concept of dynamical entropy is explained and the associated invariant evaluated for the Mixmaster cosmological model. The description of cosmological models as measure preserving dynamical systems leads to a number of interconnections with new ideas in non-linear dynamics. This may provide a new avenue of approach to ascertaining the nature of the general solution to Einstein's equations. (author)
January 1982
