metadata.@content: Yilmaz, H. (Hamamatsu TV, Winchester, MA (USA). Applied and Basic Advanced Technology)
Relativity and quantum mechanics
United States
International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 21(10-11) p. 871-902; ISSN 0020-7748; Oct 1981; Dirac symposium; New Orleans, LA (USA); May 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HAMILTON-JACOBI EQUATIONS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; SCHROEDINGER PICTURE; SPACE-TIME; VELOCITY; WAVE PROPAGATION
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

Conditions under which quantum mechanics can be made compatible with the curved space-time of gravitation theories is investigated. A postulate is imposed in the form upsilon=upsilonsub(g) where upsilon is the kinematical H-Jacobi (geometric optic limit) velocity and upsilonsub(g) is the group velocity of the waves. This imposes a severe condition on the possible coordinates in which the Schroedinger form (the coordinate realization) of quantum mechanics can be set up for purposes of calculating observable effects. Some such effects are calculated for a class of theories and are compared with experiments. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Teukolsky, S.A. (Physics Department, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853)
Linearized quadrupole waves in general relativity and the motion of test particles
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(4) p. 745-750; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Aug 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; PERTURBATION THEORY; TEST PARTICLES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

We write out the explicit form of the metric for a linearized quadrupole gravitational wave in the transverse-traceless gauge. We give a collection of formulas which are useful for testing numerical codes to integrate the full nonlinear Einstein equations. We also show that a test particle initially at rest acquires no energy from a linearized gravitational wave
January 1982

metadata.@content: Rothman, A.R.
Texas Univ., Austin (USA)
Microphysics and the evolution of the early universe
United States
1981; 236 p; ;  University Microfilms Order No. 82-17,965; Thesis (Ph. D.).
Thesis/Dissertation
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANISOTROPY; BARYONS; BLACK HOLES; CONSERVATION LAWS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DEUTERIUM; DISSIPATION FACTOR; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HELIUM; LIMITING VALUES; NUCLEOSYNTHESIS; PHOTONS; UNIVERSE

ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; ELEMENTS; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; HADRONS; HYDROGEN ISOTOPES; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NONMETALS; NUCLEI; ODD-ODD NUCLEI; RARE GASES; STABLE ISOTOPES

Four nonstandard cosmological models of the early Universe are investigated. The first considers the effects of anisotropy and dissipative effects on the baryon-to-photon ratio in the context of Grand Unified Theories. A detailed model of an anisotropic universe is developed and the Kolb-Wolfram equations governing baryosynthesis are evolved in this model. Contrary to recent claims of Bond, Kolb, and Silk, no limits are found on anisotropy during this epoch. The second investigation examines the effects caused by evaporating 1010 gm primordial black holes on cosmic nucleosynthesis of the light elements. By requiring that the final deuterium produced by nucleosynthesis not be greater than 5 x 10-5 parts by mass, it is found that rho/sub H//rho/sub b/ less than or equal to 10-7, where rho/sub H/ is the mass density of 1010 gm black holes and rho/sub b/ is the mass density of baryons during nucleosynthesis. In the third chapter limits are placed on G/G by examining the effect a larger value of G in the past would have had on primordial nucleosynthesis. This is done by taking into account the new conservation laws and Einstein equations a variable-G theory would have. Assuming a power law for G, it is found that /G/G/ less than or equal to 1.7 x 10-13 yr-1. This result is approximately a factor of two stronger than limits found in naive models where the new conservation laws are not taken into account. The fourth investigation concerns the effects of anisotropy and dissipation on primordial nucleosynthesis. A detailed numerical model is developed. Contrary to models in which dissipation is not considered it is found that anisotropy in many cases actually lowers the final helium abundance

cerns the effects of anisotropy and dissipation on primordial nucleosynthesis. A detailed numerical model is developed. Contrary to models in which dissipation is not considered it is found that anisotropy in many cases actually lowers the final helium abundance
January 1981

metadata.@content: Hawking, S.W. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics); Page, D.N. (Pennsylvania Univ., Philadelphia (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Thermodynamics of black holes in anti-de Sitter space
Germany
Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 87(4) p. 577-588; ISSN 0010-3616; Jan 1983
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; SPECIFIC HEAT; THERMAL EQUILIBRIUM; THERMAL RADIATION; THERMODYNAMICS
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; EQUILIBRIUM; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RADIATIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

The Einstein equations with a negative cosmological constant admit black hole solutions which are asymptotic to anti-de Sitter space. Like black holes in asymptotically flat space, these solutions have thermodynamic properties including a characteristic temperature and an intrinsic entropy equal to one quarter of the area of the event horizon in Planck units. There are however some important differences from the asymptotically flat case. A black hole in anti-de Sitter space has a minimum temperature which occurs when its size is of the order of the characteristic radius of the anti-de Sitter space. For larger black holes the red-shifted temperature measured at infinity is greater. This means that such black holes have positive specific heat and can be in stable equilibrium with thermal radiation at a fixed temperature. It also implies that the canonical ensemble exists for asymptotically anti-de Sitter space, unlike the case for asymptotically flat space. One can also consider the microcanonical ensemble. One can avoid the problem that arises in asymptotically flat space of having to put the system in a box with unphysical perfectly reflecting walls because the gravitational potential of anti-de Sitter space acts as a box of finite volume. (orig.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Chodos, A.; Detweiler, S. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Gibbs Lab.)
Spherically symmetric solutions in five-dimensional general relativity
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(10) p. 879-890; ISSN 0001-7701; Oct 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES; VECTORS
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; TENSORS

The most general time-independent spherically symmetric (in the usual three space dimensions) solution to the five-dimensional vacuum Einstein equations is found, subject to the existence of a Killing vector in the fifth direction. The significance of these solutions is discussed within the context of a previously proposed extension of the Kaluza-Klein model in which the universe, although (4+1)-dimensional, has evolved over cosmic times into an effectively (3+1)-dimensional one. (author)
January 1982

      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The most general time-independent spherically symmetric (in the usual three space dimensions) solution to the five-dimensional vacuum Einstein equations is found, subject to the existence of a Killing vector in the fifth direction. The significance of these solutions is discussed within the context of a previously proposed extension of the Kaluza-Klein model in which the universe, although (4+1)-dimensional, has evolved over cosmic times into an effectively (3+1)-dimensional one. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Khar'kov, A.A. (Novosibirskij Ehlektrotekhnicheskij Inst. (USSR))
Fermion production in the Friedman cosmological models
Rozhdenie fermionov v kosmologicheskikh modelyakh Fridmana
Russian
USSR
Yadernaya Fizika; v. 34(12) p. 1530-1534; ISSN 0044-0027; Dec 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Journal of Nuclear Physics (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; ISOTROPY; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; SINGULARITY; VACUUM POLARIZATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS

Production of fermion pairs in homogeneous and isotropic cosmological models is investigated. It is shown that a regularization of the fermion energy-momentum tensor(EMT) may be represented in a covariant manner as a renormalization of constants in the Einstein equations. Near the singularity it is possible to separate the contributions to the regularized EMT from the real produced particles and from the vacuum polarization in-- duced by the external field. These contributions are calculated and are found to be of the same order of magnitude
January 1981

metadata.@content: Khar'kov, A. (Novosibirsk Electrotechnical Institute)
Fermion production in the Friedman cosmological models
United States
Soviet Journal of Nuclear Physics; v. 34(6) p. 850-852; ISSN 0038-5506; Dec 1981; Cover-to-cover translation of Yadernaya Fizika (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; PAIR PRODUCTION; RENORMALIZATION; TENSORS; VACUUM POLARIZATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION

The production of fermion pairs in homogeneous, isotropic cosmological models is studied. It is shown that the regularization of the fermion energy-momentum tensor can be represented in a covariant manner as the renormalization of the constants in the Einstein equations. Near the singularity it is possible to unambiguously separate the contributions to the regularized energy-momentum tensor from the real created particles and from the vacuum polarization induced by the external field. These contributions are calculated and found to be of the same order of magnitude
January 1981

metadata.@content: Mukhanov, V.F.; Chibisov, G.V. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Fizicheskij Inst.)
Energy of vacuum and the large-scale structure of the Universe
Ehnergiya vakuuma i krupnomasshtabnaya struktura Vselennoj
Russian
USSR
Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 83(8) p. 475-487; ISSN 0044-4510; Aug 1982; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; FLUCTUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GAUGE INVARIANCE; ISOTROPY; METRICS; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; VARIATIONS

Small longitudinal quantum fluctuations of the metric in cosmological models with metastable vacuum are considered. A Hamiltonian formalism is developed and quantization of the small perturbation system is carried out. Single-loop corrections to the Einstein equations are taken into account. The stability of the models with respect to perturbations of the metric is investigated. The fluctuation spectrum of the metric is calculated. Under certain conditions its amplitude is sufficient to form galaxies in the hydrodynamic stage after decay of polarized vacuum
January 1982

metadata.@content: Ruban, V.A. (AN SSSR, Leningrad. Inst. Yadernoj Fiziki)
The Gauss-Tolman theorem and positivity of the total energy-mass for a nonstatic sphere in general relativity
Teorema Gaussa-Tolmana i polozhitel'nost' polnoj ehnergii-massy dlya nestaticheskogo shara v obshchej teorii otnositel'nosti
Russian
USSR
Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 83(8) p. 460-474; ISSN 0044-4510; Aug 1982; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASS DEFECT; POISSON EQUATION; POTENTIALS; RICCI TENSOR; RIEMANN SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; SPHERES; SYMMETRY
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SPACE; TENSORS

A generalization of the Tolman potential form of the total energy-mass integral for nanstatic central symmetric distributions of matter in R-regions of four-dimensional space V4 is r indicated. The local law of conservation of total energy of gravitational field and matter in the general theory of relativity is discussed on the basis of the quasi-Newtonian Gauss-Tolman theorem. The positivity is demonstrated of the Schwarzschield mass which is an equivalent of total energy in the presence of T-regions in semiclosed models of a ssphere. Consequently, the gravitational mass defect cannot exceed the proper total energy of matter
January 1982

metadata.@content: Nurgaliev, I.S.; Ponomarev, V.N. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR))
Cosmology and torsion of space-time
Kruchenie prostranstva-vremeni i kosmologiya
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 25(10) p. 63-65; ISSN 0021-3411; Oct 1982; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; TORSION; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

It is shown that Einstein-Kartan equations without ν-member admit cosmological solution in the form of stationary de Sitter metrics at a certain value of interspin interaction constant which should be introduced for gauge purposes. It is stated that this solution can serve as a model of before-Friedmann stage of the Universe expansion when the spin-torsion interaction is comparable with energy-momentum curvature interaction. The value of interaction constant (theta approximately equal to 10-20) is obtained under the condition that the de Sitter stage has been realized at quantum densities (1094 g/cm3)
January 1982

        <category type="common" level="secondary" key="A1100" />
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03151" assignment="indexer">equations of state</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10351" assignment="indexer">torsion</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">It is shown that Einstein-Kartan equations without ν-member admit cosmological solution in the form of stationary de Sitter metrics at a certain value of interspin interaction constant which should be introduced for gauge purposes. It is stated that this solution can serve as a model of before-Friedmann stage of the Universe expansion when the spin-torsion interaction is comparable with energy-momentum curvature interaction. The value of interaction constant (theta approximately equal to 10<sup>-</sup><sub>20</sub>) is obtained under the condition that the de Sitter stage has been realized at quantum densities (10<sub>94</sub> g/cm<sub>3</sub>)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

      <input-center type="subj" key="SU">USSR</input-center>

metadata.@content: Guerses, M. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.)); Halil, M. (Middle East Technical Univ., Ankara (Turkey). Dept of Physics)
On the connection for the Brans-Dicke-Jordan theory
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 27(17) p. 562-564; ISSN 0024-1318; 26 Apr 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; RIEMANN SPACE; SPIN; TENSORS; UNIFIED MODEL
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; NUCLEAR MODELS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SPACE

Every Einstein equation with source in the Riemannian geometry (Gsub(μν) = kappa Tsub(μν)) iss shown to be equivalent to vacuum equations (Rsub(μν) = 0) for an asymmetrical Ricci tensor of a non-metric connection with torsion. This procedure extends also the unified field theory model of Eisenhart. In particular the connection of Brans-Dicke theory is calculated. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Gomide, F.M. (Centro Tecnico Aeroespacial, Sao Jose dos Campos (Brazil). Inst. Tecnologico de Aeronautica)
Dirac's relations involving the cosmological constant and no time-varying physical quantities
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 29(12) p. 399-402; ISSN 0024-1318; 22 Nov 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DIRAC COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MACH PRINCIPLE; NUCLEONS
BARYONS; COSMOLOGY; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; HYPOTHESIS

An exact formula derived from Einstein's equations for expanding cosmological models is formally equivalent to Whitrow-Randall's relation. Consequence: the gravitational constant cannot be time varying. Defining the cosmological constant from that formula and combining with a Heisenberg type law, Dirac's relations come forth involving only constant quantities. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Tuohimaa, H. (Oulu Univ. (Finland). Dept. of Theoretical Physics)
A star and a dust shell
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 20(10) p. 361-363; ISSN 0024-1318; 5 Nov 1977
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SUPERMASSIVE STARS
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; STARS

It is shown that, according to Einstein's theory of gravitation, even an extremely thin contracting dust shell can prevent the expansion of a supermassive star. The result gives support to the belief that Einstein's theory breaks down in the case of very strong gravitational fields. (author)
January 1977

metadata.@content: Letelier, P.S. (Brasilia Univ. (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica)
Fluids of strings in general relativity
Italy
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; STRING MODELS; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS

The author's gauge-invariant model of a cloud of strings is generalized by considering a pressure or a tension produced by the strings that form the cloud. The energy conditions for the model are investigated. The general solution to Einstein equations coupled to a ''fluid'' of strings with spherical symmetry is presented. The Petrov-Pirani type, as well as the embedding class of the solution, are studied. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Wanas, M.I. (Cairo Univ., El Mansura (Egypt). Faculty of Science)
Spherically symmetric solution of the Mikhail-Wanas theory
Italy
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SYMMETRY; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

A solution having spherical symmetry for the generalized field theory established recently by Mikhail and Wanas, based on the tetrad space, is obtained. The field equations of general relativity, in free space and written in terms of the tetrad elements, are solved also by using the same tetrad field. The solution obtained from the new theory is found to be identical with that obtained from general relativity. It is shown that the solution obtained represents a pure gravitational field outside a spherically symmetric body. It is found that the new theory, in the absence of electromagnetic field and when the gravitational field is not strong, gives the same results of general relativity in the case of spherical symmetry. This result supports the idea of classification of tetrad vector fields, presented in a recent paper. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Tod, K.P. (Oxford Univ. (UK). Mathematical Inst.)
All metrics admitting super-covariantly constant spinors
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 121(4) p. 241-244; ISSN 0370-2693; 3 Feb 1983; CODEN: PYLBA.
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CHARGED PARTICLES; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SPINOR FIELDS; SPINORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

All solutions of the Einstein equations admitting super-covariantly constant spinors in the sense of Gibbons and Hull are found. There are two classes corresponding to stationary charged dust and plane waves with dust respectively. (orig.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Brown, M.R.; Grove, P.G.; Ottewill, A.C. (Oxford Univ. (UK). Dept. of Astrophysics)
Closed forms for conformally flat Green's functions
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 32(3) p. 78-80; ISSN 0024-1318; 19 Sep 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GREEN FUNCTION; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

A closed form is obtained for the massless scalar Green's function on Rindler space. This is related by conformal transformation to the Green's function for a massless, conformally coupled scalar field on the open Einstein universe. A closed form is also obtained for the corresponding Green's function on the Einstein static universe. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Moncrief, V. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Physics); Isenberg, J. (Oregon Univ., Eugene (USA). Dept. of Mathematics)
Symmetries of cosmological Cauchy horizons
Germany
Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 89(3) p. 387-414; ISSN 0010-3616; Jun 1983; CODEN: CMPHA.
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CAUSALITY; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

We consider analytic vacuum and electrovacuum spacetimes which contain a compact null hypersurface ruled by closed null generators. We prove that each such spacetime has a non-trivial Killing symmetry. We distinguish two classes of null surfaces, degenerate and non-degenerate ones, characterized by the zero or non-zero value of a constant analogous to the ''surface gravity'' of stationary black holes. We show that the non-degenerate null surfaces are always Cauchy heizons across which the Killing fields change from spacelike (in the globally hyperbolic regions) to timelike (in the acausal, analytic extensions). For the special case of a null surface diffeomorphic to T3 we characterize the degenerate vacuum solutions completely. These consists of an infinite dimensional family of ''plane wave'' spacetimes which are entirely foliated by compact null surfaces. Previous work by one of us has shown that, when one dimensional Killing symmetries are allowed, then infinite dimensional families of non-degenerate, vacuum solutions exist. We recall these results for the case of Cauchy horizons diffeomorphic to T3 and prove the generality of the previously constructed non-degenerate solutions. We briefly discuss the possibility of removing the assumptions of closed generators and analyticity and proving an appropriate generalization of our main results. Such a generalization would provide strong support for the cosmic censorship conjecture by showing that causality violating, cosmological solutions of Einstein's equations are essentially an artefact of symmetry. (orig.)
e by showing that causality violating, cosmological solutions of Einstein's equations are essentially an artefact of symmetry. (orig.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Chinea, F. (Departamento de Metodos Matematicos de la Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Fisicas, Universidad de Madrid, Madrid-3, Spain)
New Baaumlcklund transformations and superposition principle for gravitational fields with symmetries
United States
Physical Review Letters; v. 50(4) p. 221-224; ISSN 0031-9007; 24 Jan 1983
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BAECKLUND TRANSFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; O GROUPS; VECTOR FIELDS
DYNAMICAL GROUPS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TRANSFORMATIONS

Vector Baaumlcklund transformations which relate solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations having two commuting Killing fields are introduced. Such transformations generalize those found by Pohlmeyer in connection with the nonlinear sigma model. A simple algebraic superposition principle, which permits the combination of Baaumlcklund transforms in order to get new solutions, is given. The superposition preserves the asymptotic flatness condition, and the whole scheme is manifestly O(2,1) invariant
January 1983

metadata.@content: Markov, M.A. (Institute of Nuclear Research, Academy of Sciences of the USSR)
Limiting density of matter as a universal law of nature
United States
JETP Letters; v. 36(6) p. 265-267; ISSN 0021-3640; 20 Sep 1982; Cover-to-cover translation of Pis'ma v Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATTER; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

It is suggested that the density of matter in nature is always less than or equal to a certain value rho/sub q/, which is constructed from universal constants: rho/sub q/ = c5/kappa2happrox.1094 g/cm3. As an example, a modified Einstein equation is derived which, at a low density of matter, rho<<rho/sub q/' turns out to be a canonical Einstein equation without the #betta# term. With rho = rho/sub q/' the equations describe a de Sitter universe
January 1982

metadata.@content: Mukhanov, V.F.; Chibisov, G.V. (P. N. Lebedev Physics Institute, USSR Academy of Sciences)
Vacuum energy and large-scale structure of the Universe
United States
Soviet Physics - JETP; v. 56(2) p. 258-265; ISSN 0038-5646; Aug 1982; Cover-to-cover translation of Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUCTUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; HAMILTONIANS; METRICS; STABILITY; UNIVERSE; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM OPERATORS; VARIATIONS

Small longitudinal quantum fluctuations of the metric in cosmological models with metastable vacuum are considered. A Hamiltonian formalism is constructed and the system of small perturbations quantized. The single-loop corrections are taken into account in the Einstein equations. The stability of the models with respect to perturbations of the metric is investigated. The spectrum of fluctuations of the metric is calculated. Under certain conditions, the amplitude of the spectrum is sufficient for the formation of galaxies during the hydrodynamic stage after the decay of the polarized vacuum
January 1982

        <descriptor type="valid" key="09410" assignment="indexer">stability</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11532" assignment="indexer">vacuum states</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11425" assignment="upposted">quantum operators</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10799" assignment="upposted">variations</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Small longitudinal quantum fluctuations of the metric in cosmological models with metastable vacuum are considered. A Hamiltonian formalism is constructed and the system of small perturbations quantized. The single-loop corrections are taken into account in the Einstein equations. The stability of the models with respect to perturbations of the metric is investigated. The spectrum of fluctuations of the metric is calculated. Under certain conditions, the amplitude of the spectrum is sufficient for the formation of galaxies during the hydrodynamic stage after the decay of the polarized vacuum</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Letelier, P.S. (Brasilia Univ. (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica)
Left - graviting null fluids
Brazil
Revista Brasileira de Fisica; v. 12(1) p. 61-65; ISSN 0374-4922; Mar 1982

EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MECHANICS

An algorithm for generating solutions to the Einstein equations with a null fluid source, from vacuum solutions, is studied for space-times that admit an Abelian group of motions G2 that acts orthogonally transitively. (Author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Grishkan, Yu.S. (Rostovskij-na-Donu Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR). Nauchno-Issledovatel'skij Inst. Fiziki)
Evolution of homogeneous Universe with posthydrodynamical energy-momentum tensor of ultrarelativistic medium
Ehvolyutsiya odnorodnoj Vselennoj s postgidrodinamicheskim tenzorom ehnergii-impul'sa ul'trarelyativistskoj sredy
Russian
USSR
Astronomicheskij Zhurnal; v. 59(5) p. 833-843; ISSN 0004-6299; 1982; For English translation see the journal Soviet Astronomy - AJ (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SINGULARITY; TENSORS; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

A covariant expression for energy-momentum tensor of ultrarelativistic medium in posthydrodynamical approximation is constructed. Exact solutions of Einstein equations with the posthydrodynamical energy-momentum tensor are obtained for isotropic Friedmann cosmological models and for the anisotropic model of Bianchi I type. These equations keep asymptotically friedmannian isotropic solutions far from the cosmological singularity. Near the singularity, the Universe evolution is essentially different from the standard Friedmann and Kasner models: the singularity acquires an isotropic character, the temperature of the medium remains finite, the laws of space - time metric evolution near the singularity are changed
January 1982

metadata.@content: Durgapal, M.C.; Bannerji, R. (Department of Physics, Kumaun University, Nainital, India 263001)
New analytical stellar model in general relativity
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 27(2) p. 328-331; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jan 1983
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; NEUTRON STARS; PERTURBATION THEORY; RED SHIFT; STAR MODELS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STARS

A new analytical solution has been obtained for stellar models by solving Einstein's field equation for the spherically symmetric and static case. The variation of density is smooth and gradual. The density remains positive under all conditions. For all finite pressures the configurations are stable under radial perturbations. For dP/drho< or approx. =1, the maximum mass of a neutron-star model is 4.56M/sub sun/, and the surface and the central red-shifts are 0.787 and 2.673, respectively. For an infinite central pressure the surface red-shift is 1.575 which is greater than that for any other analytical solution with varying density
January 1983

metadata.@content: Ludwig, G. (Alberta Univ., Edmonton (Canada). Dept. of Mathematics)
Left-flat spaces with non-diverging null geodesics
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 16(6) p. 1181-1189; ISSN 0305-4470; 21 Apr 1983
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; SPACE-TIME; SPIN; VACUUM STATES
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; TENSORS

One of the two classes of non-diverging algebraically special left-flat spaces found by Fette, Janis and Newman (Gen. Rel. Grav.; 8:29 (1977)) is generalised by allowing the (self-dual part of the) Weyl tensor to become algebraically general. Penrose's conformal approach is used, thereby allowing the desired asymptotic behaviour of the solutions to be prescribed from the outset. The 'solutions' are, however, still subject to some 'reduced equations'. For a specific choice of initial data at conformal null infinity these reduced equations simplify to Plebanski's (J. Math. Phys.; 16:2395 (1975)) second heavenly equation. (author)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Corkill, R.W.; Stewart, J.M. (Cambridge Univ. (UK). Dept. of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics; Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Astrophysik)
Numerical relativity
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 386(1791) p. 373-391; ISSN 0080-4630; 8 Apr 1983
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TIME DEPENDENCE; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

This is the second of a sequence of papers on the numerical solution of the characteristic initial value problem in general relativity. Although the equations to be integrated have regular coefficients, the nonlinearity leads to the occurrence of singularities after a finite evolution time. Some novel techniques are discussed for integrating the equations right up to the singularities. The second half of the paper presents as examples the numerical evolution of the Schwarzschild and certain colliding plane wave space-times. (author)
January 1983

ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; KERR METRIC; NEUTRON STARS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; REVIEWS; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME; SUPERNOVAE
DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS; RADIATIONS; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

The recent development in Numerical Relativity is reviewed. Important problems which numerical relativity should treat are 1) the final structure of space-time, 2) generation of gravitational waves, 3) supernova explosions, 4) formation of supermassive black holes and 5) cosmology. The present status on each problem is discussed in section 1. In section 2, various formalisms of the Einstein equations, coordinate conditions and numerical methods are compared. In section 3, numerical examples of collapse of rotating stars are shown. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Sasaki, Misao; Nakamura, Takashi (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)
Gravitational radiation from a Kerr black hole, 1
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 67(6) p. 1788-1809; ISSN 0033-068X; Jul 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BLACK HOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY SPECTRA; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; INTERACTION RANGE; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC; REGGE CALCULUS
DISTANCE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; RADIATIONS; SPECTRA

A class of new inhomogeneous equations governing gravitational perturbations of the Kerr geometry is presented. It is shown that, contrary to the case of the Teukolsky equation, the perturbation equations have short-range potential and no divergent source terms for large distance. Using one of such equations which seems to be the simplest, we have computed the spectrum and the energy of gravitational radiation induced by a test particle of mass μ falling along the z-axis into a Kerr black hole of mass M(>>μ) and angular momentum Ma(a < M). It is found that the total energy radiated is 0.0170 μc2 (μ/M) when a = 0.99 M, which is 1.65 times larger than that when a = 0, i.e., the Schwarzschild case. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Sorkin, R.D. (Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, New Jersey 08540, and Center for Theoretical Physics, University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland 20742)
Kaluza-Klein monopole
United States
Physical Review Letters; v. 51(2) p. 87-90; ISSN 0031-9007; 11 Jul 1983
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MONOPOLES; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY BREAKING; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

By adding the trivial term -dt2 one can convert the four-dimensional (positive definite) Newman-Unti-Tamburino line element into a static solution of the five-dimensional vacuum Einstein equations. Interpreted a la Kaluza and Klein, the solution describes a monopole with a charge-to-mass ratio of √2 in rationalized Planck units. Although it is a perfectly regular five-geometry it appears singular from a four-dimensional perspective
January 1983

metadata.@content: Anderson, P. (Physics Department, University of California, Santa Barbara, California 93106)
Effects of quantum fields on singularities and particle horizons in the early universe
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 28(2) p. 271-285; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1983
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GREEN FUNCTION; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

The back-reaction problem for conformally invariant free quantum fields in spatially flat homogeneous and isotropic spacetimes containing classical radiation is solved. The solutions depend upon two regularization parameters which we call α and #betta#. Only solutions which at late times approach the appropriate solution to the field equations of general relativity are considered. For all α and #betta# with α>0 there are many such solutions, while for all α and #betta# with α<0 there is only one such solution. For #betta#>3α>0, there is always one solution which undergoes a ''time-symmetric bounce'' and which contains no singularities or particle horizons. For α>0 there is always at least one solution which begins with an initial singularity and which has no particle horizons. For all α and #betta# there is always at least one solution which begins with an initial singularity
January 1983

metadata.@content: Meller, Kh.
Are singularities inevitable in the gravity theory
Neizbezhny li singulyarnosti v teorii gravitatsii
Problems of physics: classical and present day state
Russian
USSR

Treder, G.Yu. (ed.); p. 99-116; 1982; p. 99-116; Mir; Moscow; Speeches and reports on grand meetings of the Einstein Comittee of the Academy of Sciences of GDR; Berlin (German Democratic Republic); 28 Feb - 2 Mar 1979; Translation from English and Germany.
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

An attempt is made to get rid of singularities in general relativity and gravity theories by generalizing the classical Einstein theory. It is shown that it is possible to construct gravity theories without singularities only in the case when gravitational lagrangian has the form L=Lsup((0))+lambdaLsup((4)), where Lsup((n)) is homogeneous function of the fourth power, and lambda is a constant having the dimensions of length squared. The case of homogeneous Universe, from which it is seen that lambda has to be negative for setting rid of singularity of ''great explosion'', is examined. At the same time it follows from the carried out study that almost all the results obtianed within the limits of the Einstein theory, even concerning large systems in the cosmological scales, remain true, except the results directly connected with the presence of singularities
January 1982

metadata.@content: Aichelburg, P.C. (Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
Vienna Univ. (Austria)
Identification of trivial solutions in supergravity
Austria
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; RIEMANN SPACE; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The problem of when a given solution to the supergravity field equations can be transformed to an Einstein vacuum solution by a supersymmetry gauge transformation is considered. It is shown that the conditions that infinitesimally gauge-related solutions are required to fullfill depend on the algebraic structure of the Riemann tensor. For general Petrov type I, type II and type D, these conditions are not only necessary but also sufficient and the explicit transformation can be given. (Author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Centrella, J.; Wilson, J.R.
Texas Univ., Austin (USA). Relativity Center; Illinois Univ., Urbana (USA). Dept. of Astronomy; Lawrence Livermore National Lab., CA (USA)
Planar numerical cosmology. I. The differential equations
United States
Aug 1982; 17 p; UCRL--90253; ;  Available from NTIS, PC A02/MF A01 as DE84006710
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; HAMILTONIANS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; MECHANICS; QUANTUM OPERATORS; SIMULATION

This paper is the first in a series describing a method for evolving planar cosmological models on a computer. In this paper we set forth our coordinate conditions and variables, and discuss the way our special gauge simplifies the numerical evolution. We write down the Einstein equations that govern the gravitational field in our cosmologies, as well as the hydrodynamical equations for the fluid souces. Later papers in this series will present the differencing of these equations, tests of the code, and evolutions of dynamical inhomogeneous cosmological models. 25 references
January 1982

metadata.@content: Soares, I.D.
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro
On the stability of the Einstein universe
Brazil
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; PERTURBATION THEORY; STABILITY; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

It is shown sthat the Einstein Universe is stable by a large class of exact perturbations, which are made starting from a detailed exam of the topology of the model, and which include perturbations of the type considered by Lemaitre. The problem is reduced to the one-dimensional motion of a particle, in a potential well whose minimum corresponds to the configuration of the Einstein Universe. (Author)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Maia, M.D. (Brasilia Univ. (Brazil). Dept. de Matematica; Trieste Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica Teorica)
Brasilia Univ. (Brazil). Dept. de Matematica
Geometry of Kaluza-Klein theory. 2. Field equations
Brazil
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ALGEBRA; DYNAMICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MASS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS; MECHANICS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The field equations for a Kaluza-Klein Theory with the 4-dimensional space-time embedded in a 4+n dimensional flat space are examined. The integrability conditions for the existence of the embedding, together with Einstein's equations are tentatively interpreted as the field equations for a low energy observer. On the other hand the dynamics for an observer with high energy probes is described by Einstein-Hilbert action. The behaviour of fermion masses is also examined at distinct gravitational field configurations. (Author)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Li, K. (Center for Theoretical Physics, Laboratory for Nuclear Science and Department of Physics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139)
Anomalous but consistent gravity in two dimensions
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(8) p. 2292-2297; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Oct 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

CHIRALITY; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; FERMIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LORENTZ INVARIANCE; MASSLESS PARTICLES; SPACE-TIME; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; TENSORS

Two-dimensional gravity coupled to chiral fermions possesses a Lorentz anomaly, but it can be made consistent by allowing the gauge degree of freedom to be physical at the quantum level. The theory has massless excitations or a ghost particle depending on the sign of a counterterm. The possibility of adding the Wess-Zumino term in order to cancel the anomaly is also discussed
January 1986

metadata.@content: Anderson, P.R.; Holman, R. (University of Florida, Physics Department, 215 Williamson Hall, Gainesville, Florida 32611)
Effective potential for the O(N)-symmetric model in static homogeneous spacetimes
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(8) p. 2277-2282; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Oct 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGY; EFFECTIVE RANGE THEORY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; INFRARED DIVERGENCES; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; O GROUPS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIVE CORRECTIONS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY BREAKING; UNIVERSE
CORRECTIONS; DYNAMICAL GROUPS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The effective potential for a scalar theory with O(N) symmetry is calculated in the large-N limit for the Einstein and static hyperbolic universes. For the Einstein universe it is found that spontaneous symmetry breaking via a second-order phase transition cannot occur regardless of the masses or strengths of the couplings of the fields to the scalar curvature. For the static hyperbolic universe spontaneous symmetry breaking can occur and is enhanced if the coupling to the scalar curvature is positive. For both spacetimes the curvature changes the detailed behavior of the effective potential but, with the exception of spontaneous symmetry breaking, its basic properties are the same as in flat space
January 1986

      </categories>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02905" assignment="indexer">effective range theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04749" assignment="indexer">infrared divergences</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05272" assignment="indexer">lagrangian function</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="06866" assignment="indexer">o groups</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07329" assignment="indexer">phase transformations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08123" assignment="indexer">quantum field theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08189" assignment="indexer">radiative corrections</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08816" assignment="indexer">scalar fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09720" assignment="indexer">symmetry breaking</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02255" assignment="upposted">corrections</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="12175" assignment="upposted">dynamical groups</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03747" assignment="upposted">functions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05490" assignment="upposted">lie groups</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The effective potential for a scalar theory with O(N) symmetry is calculated in the large-N limit for the Einstein and static hyperbolic universes. For the Einstein universe it is found that spontaneous symmetry breaking via a second-order phase transition cannot occur regardless of the masses or strengths of the couplings of the fields to the scalar curvature. For the static hyperbolic universe spontaneous symmetry breaking can occur and is enhanced if the coupling to the scalar curvature is positive. For both spacetimes the curvature changes the detailed behavior of the effective potential but, with the exception of spontaneous symmetry breaking, its basic properties are the same as in flat space</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>

    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Brown, J.D.
Texas Univ., Austin (USA)
Lower dimensional gravity
United States
1985; 131 p; ;  University Microfilms Order No. 86-09,468; Thesis (Ph. D.).
Thesis/Dissertation
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; FIELD THEORIES; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; PAIR PRODUCTION; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; PARTICLE PRODUCTION

Several problems involving gravity in fewer than four space-time dimensions are considered. The motivation for studying lower dimensional gravity is the hope that, as a simple model for gravity, it may provide new ideas and insights into four dimensional gravity at both the classical and quantum levels. The asymptotic structure of three-dimensional Einstein gravity with a negative cosmological constant is analyzed, and a nontrivial central charge appears in the algebra of the canonical generators. From this example, it becomes evident that the global charges of any gauge theory may yield a nontrivial central extension of the asymptotic symmetry algebra. The analysis makes use of a general theorem also demonstrated, that in the canonical formulation of field theory on open spaces, the Poisson bracket of two differentiable generators is itself a differentiable generator. In two space-time dimensions, the natural analogue of Einstein gravity is the requirement of constant scalar curvature outside sources. The space time with a singular source is shown to possess an event horizon and Hawking radiation, and is therefore the analogue of a black hole. Also considered in two dimensions is particle pair production by an electric field, and the effects of gravity on the process. The electric field contributes to the space-time curvature as an effective cosmological constant
January 1985

metadata.@content: Ashtekar, A. (Physics Department, Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York, 13244-1130 and Institute for Theoretical Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, California 93106)
New variables for classical and quantum gravity
United States
Physical Review Letters; v. 57(18) p. 2244-2247; ISSN 0031-9007; CODEN PRLTA; 3 Nov 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HAMILTONIANS; PHASE SPACE; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SU-2 GROUPS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM OPERATORS; SPACE; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

A Hamiltonian formulation of general relativity based on certain spinorial variables is introduced. These variables simplify the constraints of general relativity considerably and enable one to imbed the constraint surface in the phase space of Einstein's theory into that of Yang-Mills theory. The imbedding suggests new ways of attacking a number of problems in both classical and quantum gravity. Some illustrative applications are discussed
January 1986

metadata.@content: Jantzen, R.T. (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Cambridge, (USA))
Gauge freedom in perfect fluid spatially homogeneous spacetimes
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 447-460; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LIE GROUPS; MATRICES; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; STRUCTURE FUNCTIONS; UNIVERSE; VECTOR FIELDS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

The class of reference systems compatible with the symmetry of a spatially homogeneous perfect fluid spacetime is discussed together with the associated class of symmetry adapted comoving ADM frames (or computational frames). The fluid equations of motion are related to the four functions on the space of fluid flow lines discovered by Taub and which characterize an isentropic flow. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Herrera, L.; Jimenez, J. (Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas. Dept. de Fisica)
Junction conditions and the propagation of isometries in general relativity
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 889-892; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

The authors present a set of junction conditions to match two solutions of the Einstein equations belonging to two regions of the space-time, separated by a non-null hypersurface. This set of junction conditions is stated in terms of the Newmann-Penrose variables (null tetrads and spin coefficients). As an example the matching of the Schwarzschild metric with an axially and reflection symmetric metric is studied. For this particular example the propagation of the Killing vectors is studied and it is shown how the propagation is conditioned by the fulfillment of the junction conditions. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Deruelle, N. (Institut Henri Poincare, Paris, France)
Gravitational radiation from two compact bodies: the radiative losses at the post linear approximation of general relativity
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 955-958; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; RADIATIONS

Starting from the second order gravitational field and equations of motion of two compact bodies the author deduces the asymptotic expansion of the metric at the post linear approximation of general relativity. The fluxes of energy, momentum and angular momentum at infinity are computed and the quadrupole formulae is recovered. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Wu Yongshi (Institute of Theoretical Physics, Beijing, China); Ge Molin (Lanzhou University, China)
A new approach to the algebraic structure in stationary axially symmetric gravity
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1067-1072; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; POTENTIALS; TRANSFORMATIONS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY

A new parametric infinitesimal transformation to preserve the equation of motion and linearization formulation in Kinnersley-Chitre-Hauser-Ernst formulation of gravity is proposed. Based on the transformation the G x C(t) hidden symmetry algebraic structure is explicitly shown. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Zhang Zhenjiu (Gravitational Theory and Astrophysics Division, Huazhong Teachers College, Wuhan, China)
Behavior of entropy of self-gravitating radiation in collapse
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1289-1293; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RADIATIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

The author begins the investigation by using Einstein constraint equations and examines the behavior of the entropy of spherically symmetric and time symmetric distribution of self-gravitating radiation in dynamical equilibrium in the context of general relativity. He finds the maxima of the entropy of self-gravitating radiation confined to a box of size R with the configurations which are outside their own Schwarzschild radius by at least one proper wavelength. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Ross, D.K. (Iowa State Univ., Ames, IA)
Scale invariance, killing vectors, and the size of the fifth dimension
United States
International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 25(7) p. 663-670; ISSN 0020-7748; CODEN IJTPB; Jul 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETISM; FINE STRUCTURE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALE INVARIANCE; UNIVERSE; VECTORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAGNETISM; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; TENSORS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

An analysis is made of the classical five-dimensional sourceless Kaluza-Klein equations with the existence of the usual α/α/PSI/ Killing vector not assumed, where /PSI/ is the coordinate of the fifth dimension. The physical distance around the fifth dimension D5, needed for the calculation of the fine structure constant α, is not calculable in the usual theory because the equations have a global scale invariance. In the present case, the Killing vector and the global scale invariance are not present, but it is found rather generally that D5 = 0. This indicates that quantum gravity is a necessary ingredient if α is to be calculated. It also provides an alternate explanation of why the universe appears four-dimensional
January 1986

metadata.@content: Krechet, V.G. (K.D. Ushinski Pedagogical Institute, Yaroslav)
Dynamics of continuous medium in space with torsion
United States
Soviet Physics Journal; v. 28(12) p. 957-961; ISSN 0038-5697; CODEN SOPJA; Jun 1986; Cover-to-cover translation of Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; RICCI TENSOR; RIEMANN SPACE; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; TORSION; TWISTOR THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

This paper investigates the general features of the dynamicsof continuous media within the framework of the Einstein-Cartan gravitation theory using a formalism for the description of congruence geometry for the stream lines in the continuous medium. Raichaudkhur-type equations are derived for the space with twisting which are applicable to the investigation of the singularity problem in the gravitation theory. It is demonstrated that the spur of the space-time twisting tensor can directly affect the volumetric divergence of the autoparallel, while the twist pseudospur can affect the rotation of the congruence of the stream lines in the continuous medium. Using the investigated formalism, metrics are found and investigated for the uniform, rotating, nonstationary cosmologic model
January 1986

metadata.@content: Dandash, N.F. (Lumumba People's Friendship Univ.)
Cylindrically symmetric distributions of matter taking into account pressure
United States
Soviet Physics Journal; v. 28(12) p. 977-980; ISSN 0038-5697; CODEN SOPJA; Jun 1986; Cover-to-cover translation of Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MASS DISTRIBUTION; MATTER; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SYMMETRY; UNIVERSE
CONFIGURATION; DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; RADIATIONS; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; TENSORS

This paper considers a non-steady-state cosmological field for describing the distribution of matter with nonzero pressure; the assumption of cylindrical symmetry is taken into consideration. A new class of non-steady-state solutions to the Einstein equations is found. A homogeneous, anisotropic universe and an analog of the Schwarzschild solution are considered as particular cases. The obtained results can be used for describing cylindrical regions in the universe, especially in the vicinity of linear mass ejection from galaxies and quasars and linear super-large-scale structures
January 1986

      </titles>

      <country key="US">United States</country>
      <creators and-others="no">
        <creator type="personal">Dandash, N.F.</creator>
        <creator type="affiliation">Lumumba People's Friendship Univ.</creator>
      </creators>

      </availability>

        <note>Cover-to-cover translation of Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika (USSR).</note>
      </notes>
      <is-part-of>
        <journal>
          <titles>
            <title type="primary">Soviet Physics Journal</title>
            <title type="abbreviated">Sov. Phys. J. (Engl. Transl.)</title>
          </titles>
          <identifiers>
            <identifier type="issn">0038-5697</identifier>
            <identifier type="coden">SOPJA</identifier>
          </identifiers>
          <physical-description>v. 28(12) p. 977-980.</physical-description>
        </journal>
      </is-part-of>
    </publication>
    <classification>
      <categories>
        <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1550" />
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02451" assignment="indexer">cylindrical configuration</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="21731" assignment="indexer">energy-momentum tensor</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11875" assignment="indexer">galactic evolution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04116" assignment="indexer">gravitational radiation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04117" assignment="indexer">gravitational waves</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="23052" assignment="indexer">mass distribution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05913" assignment="indexer">matter</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07895" assignment="indexer">pressure dependence</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="indexer">symmetry</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02148" assignment="upposted">configuration</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02716" assignment="upposted">distribution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08188" assignment="upposted">radiations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09332" assignment="upposted">spatial distribution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">This paper considers a non-steady-state cosmological field for describing the distribution of matter with nonzero pressure; the assumption of cylindrical symmetry is taken into consideration. A new class of non-steady-state solutions to the Einstein equations is found. A homogeneous, anisotropic universe and an analog of the Schwarzschild solution are considered as particular cases. The obtained results can be used for describing cylindrical regions in the universe, especially in the vicinity of linear mass ejection from galaxies and quasars and linear super-large-scale structures</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Hu, B.L. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Finite temperature quantum processes in the early universe
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 415-430; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ADIABATIC APPROXIMATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; UNIVERSE; WAVE EQUATIONS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

Finite temperature quantum field theory is presented here as an approximate theory for the study of quantum statistical processes in the early universe. The author starts with a discussion of the conditions for the establishment of thermal equilibrium in dynamic spacetimes and presents the adiabatic approximation for treating quantum systems in quasi-equilibrium. The method is then used to compute the finite temperature quantum energy densities for scalar fields arbitrarily coupled to the Robertson-Walker universe. The results are then applied to the analysis of the problem of constructing cosmological solutions with back reactions from finite temperature quantum sources, and to the problem of symmetry restoration at finite temperature. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Novello, M.; Rodrigues, L.M.C.S. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro)
Bifurcation in the early cosmos
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 883-887; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; IRREVERSIBLE PROCESSES; METRICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PRIGOGINE THEOREM; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS

Dissipative processes can provoke the appearance of bifurcation in autonomous non-linear differential equations, generating an indeterminacy in the physical system. The authors show that such indeterminacy does exist in the early Cosmos. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Parker, L. (Wisconsin Univ., Milwaukee (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Particle creation and the cosmological constant
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1359-1362; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; GRAVITONS; METRICS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE
ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; RADIATIONS

In view of the fact that vacuum energy can contribute to the value of the cosmological constant it is puzzling that its observed value is so small. There is an interesting connection between particle creation by the expansion of the universe and the value of the cosmological constant. The author recalls and extends his earlier arguments using the basic postulate that the absence of particle creation, in particular, of the creation of minimally coupled massless scalar particles and gravitons, is a kind of equilibrium condition toward which the evolution of the universe tends, and that the classical Einstein equations must be consistent with that condition. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Berger, B.K. (Oakland University, Rochester, MI (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Quantum effects in the Gowdy T3 cosmological model
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1377-1380; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; POLARIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The Gowdy T3 cosmological model possesses a plane symmetry and contains a single polarization of gravitational waves [described by β(θ,t)]. β(θ,t) may be expressed explicitly as a superposition of standing waves. The background spacetime is described by the non-dynamical variable λ(θ,t). The model is a solution to the vacuum Einstein equations. The behavior of this model is discussed. (Auth.)
January 1983

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The Gowdy T<sup>3</sup> cosmological model possesses a plane symmetry and contains a single polarization of gravitational waves [described by β(θ,t)]. β(θ,t) may be expressed explicitly as a superposition of standing waves. The background spacetime is described by the non-dynamical variable λ(θ,t). The model is a solution to the vacuum Einstein equations. The behavior of this model is discussed. (Auth.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Ibanez, J.; Verdaguer, E. (Universitat Mallorca, Spain; Barcelona Universidad Autonoma, Spain)
Finite perturbations on Friedmann-Robertson-Walker models
Of cosmology
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 306 p. 401-410; ISSN 0004-637X; CODEN ASJOA; Jul 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DENSITY; EIGENVALUES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

By dimensional reduction of solutions of Einstein's equations in five-dimensional vacuum, two metrics are derived which can be interpreted as finite cylindrical perturbations of the solitonic type on a radiative Friedmann-Robertson-Walker (FRW) cosmological background. A linear perturbative analysis is performed and is compared with the exact nonlinear results. The metrics are transformed to perfect fluid solutions representing finite soliton perturbations on a FRW background with stiff matter. One metric contains density modes, and the other includes the coupling between density and radiative modes. 30 references
January 1986

metadata.@content: Baranov, M.A.; Roslyi, A.A.; Shuarts, A.S. (Moscow Engineering Physics Institute)
On the connection between gravity and supergravity
United States
Theoretical and Mathematical Physics; v. 64(1) p. 649-655; ISSN 0040-5779; CODEN TMPHA; Jan 1986; Cover-to-cover translation of Teoreticheskaya i Matematicheskaya Fizika (USSR).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GRADED LIE GROUPS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INVARIANT IMBEDDING; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RIEMANN SPACE; SUPERGRAVITY; TRANSFORMATIONS; VECTOR FIELDS
BOUNDARY-VALUE PROBLEMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

This paper analyzes the connection between gravity and supergravity. In particular, it is established that the singularities which arise in the solution of the Einstein equations become weaker on the transition to supergravity. The authors work in the concept of the Special Cauchy-Riemann transformations (SCR). In contrast to the Wess-Zumino formalism, in which a frame field also plays the fundamental role, the frames in the SCR structure are determined, not up to transformations of the Lorentz group but up to transformations of a larger group-the group of SCRs
January 1986

metadata.@content: Gottloeber, S.; Mueller, V. (Akademie der Wissenschaften der DDR, Potsdam. Zentralinstitut fuer Astrophysik)
Vacuum polarization and scalar field effects in the early Universe
German Democratic Republic
Astronomische Nachrichten; v. 307(5) p. 285-287; ISSN 0004-6337; CODEN ASNAA; 1986; 7. seminar on relativistic astrophysics and gravitation; Potsdam (German Democratic Republic); 14-19 Oct 1985
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ACTION INTEGRAL; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; ISOTROPY; LIMITING VALUES; ORIGIN; SCALAR FIELDS; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Homogeneous isotropic cosmological models driven at early times by a coherent scalar field and the vacuum polarization are considered. Both effects can lead to the existence of a finite minimal value of the scale factor and an inflationary stage of expansion. The early as well as the late time behaviour of the cosmological evolution depends critically on the ratio of the contribution from the vacuum polarization and the scalar field. (author)
January 1986
