metadata.@content: MacCallum, M.A.H.; Aaman, J.E. (Queen Mary Coll., London (UK). School of Mathematical Sciences)
Algebraically independent nth derivatives of the Riemannian curvature spinor in a general spacetime
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 3(6) p. 1133-1141; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Nov 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ALGEBRA; ALGORITHMS; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS; TENSORS; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; SPACE; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

Explicit sets of spinor nth derivatives of the Riemann curvature spinor for a general spacetime are specified for each n so that they contain the minimal number of components enabling all derivatives of order m to be expressed algebraically in terms of these sets for n <=m. The minimal sets are defined recursively in a manner convenient for use in the procedures for resolving the 'equivalence problem' of the local isometry of two given spacetimes. The actual numbers of quantities to be calculated are given and the reductions in these arising in special cases such as vacuum and conformally flat spacetimes, and spacetimes with vanishing Bach tensor, are discussed. Finally, the possible relevance of the present results to analytic and numerical methods of solving the Einstein equations are commented on. (author)
January 1986

Generation of gravitational waves in vacuum FRW models
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 3(6) p. 1235-1245; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Nov 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
AMPLITUDES; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; MILNE PROBLEM; RIEMANN SPACE; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; QUASI PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; SPACE

A soliton solution of Einstein's equations is presented which evolves in time towards a Milne universe containing gravitational waves. These waves have cylindrical symmetry and start as gravitational radiation at initial null hypersurfaces, go through a particle-like stage at some finite time and, finally, evolve towards gravitational radiation with decreasing amplitude at future null infinity. In these final stages the solution resembles the final stages of an open Friedman-Robertson-Walker model with gravitational waves. This metric can be extended through the initial null hypersurfaces. The extended metric represents two incoming gravitational waves from past null infinity which collide without a singularity. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Blanchet, L.; Damour, T. (Observatoire de Paris, Section de Meudon, 92 (France); California Inst. of Tech., Pasadena (USA))
Radiative gravitational fields in general relativity
United Kingdom
Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 320(1555) p. 379-430; ISSN 0080-4614; CODEN PTRMA; 3 Dec 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE

A well-defined formal framework is presented together with appropriate mathematical tools, which allow us to implement in a constructive way, and to investigate in full mathematical details, the Bonnor-Thorne approach to gravitational radiation theory. Within this framework it is shown how to construct the general radiative (formal) solution of the Einstein vacuum equations, in harmonic coordinates, which is both past-stationary and past-asymptotically Minkowskian. The structure of the latter general radiative metric (including all tails and nonlinear effects) both in the near zone and in the far zone is investigated. As a side result it is proven that post-Newtonian expansions must be done by using the gauge functions given. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Blanchet, L. (California Inst. of Tech., Pasadena (USA))
Radiative gravitational fields in general relativity
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 409(1837) p. 383-399; ISSN 0080-4630; CODEN PRLAA; 9 Feb 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; MULTIPOLES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE

We prove that Penrose's requirements for asymptotic simplicity are formally satisfied by the general metric, (1), which admits both post-Minkowskian and multipolar expansions, (2), which is stationary in the past and asymptotically Minkowskian in the past, (3), which admits harmonic coordinates, and (4), which is a solution of Einstein's vacuum equations outside a spatially bounded region. The proof is based on the setting up, by using the method of a previous work, of an improved algorithm that generates a metric equivalent to the general harmonic metric of that work but written in radiative coordinates, i.e. admitting an expansion in powers of r-1 for r → infinity and t - r fixed. The arbitrary parameters of the construction are the radiative multipole moments. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Rubin, M.A. (Dept. of Physics, Univ. of Texas, Austin, TX 78712)
Kaluza-Klein cosmology: Techniques for quantum computations
Inner space/outer space. The interface between cosmology and particle physics
United States
Kolb, E.W.; Turner, M.S.; Lindley, D.; Olive, K.; Seckel, D; p. 583-588; ISBN 0-226-45032-5; 1986; p. 583-588; University of Chicago Press; Chicago, IL (USA)
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

COMPACTIFICATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUCTUATIONS; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES; VARIATIONS

The high energy scale associated with excitations of the internal space is also a reason for suspecting that quantum effects will play a significant role. On purely dimensional grounds we expect that quantum corrections to classical gravity should become important at Planckian energies and length scales. Indeed, the ''evidence'' obtained from one-loop (0(h-bar)) quantum-gravitational calculations in simple K-K models confirms our suspicion; the nature of solutions to the equations which determine the spacetime geometry is significantly affected when the lowest-order quantum fluctuations of the gravitational field or other fields are taken into account
January 1986

metadata.@content: Venturi, G. (Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita di Bologna, Via Irnerio 46, 40126 Bologna)
Massless fermions and bound states in Kaluza-Klein theories
Inner space/outer space. The interface between cosmology and particle physics
United States
Kolb, E.W.; Turner, M.S.; Lindley, D.; Olive, K.; Seckel, D; p. 601-603; ISBN 0-226-45032-5; 1986; p. 601-603; University of Chicago Press; Chicago, IL (USA)
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

COMPACTIFICATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPECTATION VALUE; FERMIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The authors consider fermions coupled minimally to Einstein-Cartan gravity in a seven-dimensional background space-time M/sub 4//sup 0/ circle times S/sup 3/ and use coordinates (x/sup μ/, y/sup m/), Greek indices go from 1 to 4 (M/sub 4//sup 0/) and small Latin indices from 5 to 7 (S/sup 3/). The authors only exhibit the ''internal'' component of the contorsion K/sub abc/ which is the only one which can have a non-zero vacuum expectation value (v.e.v.) compatibly with Poincare invariance
January 1986

metadata.@content: Barut, A.O. (Univ. of Colorado, Boulder, CO)
Three lectures on the foundations of quantum theory and quantum electrodynamics
Frontiers of nonequilibrium statistical physics
United States

Moore, G.T.; Scully, M.O; p. 119-128; 1986; p. 119-128; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on nonequilibrium quantum statistical mechanics; Santa Fe, NM (USA); 3-16 Jun 1984
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1110); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

BELL THEOREM; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CORRELATION FUNCTIONS; DIRAC EQUATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM ELECTRODYNAMICS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; REVIEWS; SELF-ENERGY; SPIN

ANGULAR MOMENTUM; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRODYNAMICS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; LEPTONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; WAVE EQUATIONS

This paper presents a series of three lectures on the following topics: models for the EPR-problem; recent advances in the theory of the electron, and the development of quantum electrodynamics based on self-energy. The common feature of the three lectures is to explore the borderline region between classical physics and quantum physics. The correlation functions defined for quantum spins are compared with those for classical spins and the result is that they are exactly the same. It is concluded that the Bell's inequalities do not eliminate the purely classical spin model; they do, however, eliminate mixed models with classical hidden variables but possessing quantum mechanical spin-values
January 1986

metadata.@content: Collins, C.B.; Lang, J.M. (Waterloo Univ., Ontario (Canada). Dept. of Applied Mathematics)
Singularities in self-similar spacetimes
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 3(6) p. 1143-1150; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Nov 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LORENTZ GROUPS; RICCI TENSOR; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; POINCARE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

It is shown that a common feature of all general relativistic self-similar perfect fluids is that every orbit of the similarity group possesses a singularity. This result is given as an application of a more general result in Lorentzian geometry, which holds regardless of dimension, physical fields or field equations. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Maia, M.D. (Universidade de Brasilia, Departamento de Matematica, 70910, Brasilia, D. F. Brazil and Department of Physics, FM-15 University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, 98195)
Geometric space-time perturbation. I. Multiparameter perturbations
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(3) p. 647-650; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Mar 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIMENSIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TRANSFORMATIONS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

The standard definition of space-time perturbation is reexamined. It is seen that the noninvariance of the metric under identification gauge transformations is a consequence of the adopted zero signature in the fifth dimension of the space of space-times. An n-parameter extension of that definition is proposed, with a (4+n)-dimensional flat space of space-times with a nonsingular metric. It is shown that in the vicinity of a point in the background space-time there is a geometrically defined family of perturbations, which are solutions of the Einstein--Yang--Mills equations
January 1987

metadata.@content: Choquet Bruhat, Y. (Dept. de Mecanique, Paris)
Supergravities and Kaluza-Klein theories
Topological properties and global structure of space-time
United States

Bergmann, P.G.; De Sabbalo, V; p. 31-48; 1986; p. 31-48; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on topological properties and global structure of space-time; Erice (Italy); 12-22 May 1985
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

BOSON-FERMION SYMMETRY; BOSONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; GRADED LIE GROUPS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; SPIN; SPINOR FIELDS; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TRANSFORMATIONS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

This paper presents the general definitions and results pertinent to supergravities and Kaluza-Klein theories. Some open mathematical problems are examined. A graded Lagrangian is described as a mapping from the space of differentiable sections of a graded bundle. Variational calculus is considered and the graded Einstein-Cartan theory is explained. Spin 3/2 sources, the integrability condition, and the Kaluza-Klein theory and spinor source model are discussed. Some partial results have been obtained for the reduction of the 11-dimensional C.J.S. theory to an N = 8 (spin 3/2 fields) four dimensional supergravity, with added bosonic fields
January 1986

metadata.@content: Rosen, N. (Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa)
The space-time of the bimetric general relativity theory
Topological properties and global structure of space-time
United States

Bergmann, P.G.; De Sabbalo, V; p. 221-230; 1986; p. 221-230; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on topological properties and global structure of space-time; Erice (Italy); 12-22 May 1985
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STAR MODELS; TOPOLOGY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; METRICS

Previously, the author presented a report on the bimetric general relativity theory. Here he describes recent developments in this theory and discusses the space-time of the theory. The purpose of developing the bimetric general relativity theory is to try to remove some of the singularities that are present in the usual general relativity theory, such as those in cosmological models and in Schwarzschild solution. This is done by incorporating into the foundations of the theory the existence of a fundamental rest-frame in the universe. The author investigates the case of a completely collapsed star by considering the simplest equation of state which corresponds to Schwarzschild's interior solution of Einstein's equations
January 1986

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="18625" assignment="indexer">star models</descriptor>

      </descriptors>

        <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier>
      </qualifiers>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Previously, the author presented a report on the bimetric general relativity theory. Here he describes recent developments in this theory and discusses the space-time of the theory. The purpose of developing the bimetric general relativity theory is to try to remove some of the singularities that are present in the usual general relativity theory, such as those in cosmological models and in Schwarzschild solution. This is done by incorporating into the foundations of the theory the existence of a fundamental rest-frame in the universe. The author investigates the case of a completely collapsed star by considering the simplest equation of state which corresponds to Schwarzschild's interior solution of Einstein's equations</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

metadata.@content: Pekeris, C.L. (Department of Applied Mathematics, The Weizmann Institute, Rehovot, Israel)
Nucleus as a source in Kerr-Newman geometry
United States
Phys. Rev., A; v. 35(1) p. 14-17; ISSN 0556-2791; CODEN PLRAA; 1 Jan 1987
Journal article
ATOMIC AND MOLECULAR PHYSICS (A1210); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ATOMS; DIRAC EQUATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; KERR METRIC; NUCLEI; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME; SPECTRA; SPIN
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; WAVE EQUATIONS

The nucleus is treated as a source in Kerr-Newman geometry, under the assumption that the angular momentum of the source is equal to the intrinsic spin angular momentum of the nucleus. The spin radius a of the nucleus, which figures in the Kerr-Newman metric, is of the order of the Compton wavelength of the nucleus. The radial functions in Chandrasekhar's separated Dirac equation in Kerr geometry, are transformed so as to yield a pair of simultaneous first-order differential equations with real coefficients, as in flat space. The magnetic quantum number m appears explicitly in the differential equations, thus lifting the hyperfine splitting degeneracy of Dirac's equation in flat space
January 1987

metadata.@content: Hosoya, Akio; Jensen, L.G.; Stein-Schabes, J.A. (Fermi National Accelerator Lab., Batavia, IL (USA). Astrophysics Theory Group)
The critical dimension for chaotic cosmology
Netherlands
Nuclear Physics. B; v. 283(3/4) p. 657-668; ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBB; 16 Mar 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; SCALE DIMENSION; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STOCHASTIC PROCESSES; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GEOMETRY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS

Using the ADM formalism for general relativity the approach to a space-time singularity of a general inhomogeneous universe, in an arbitrary number of dimensions, is studied. The question of whether chaotic behaviour is a generic feature of Einstein's equations, in an arbitrary number of dimensions, is explored. We find that models that contain ten or more spatial dimensions are non-chaotic and their approach toward the initial singularity is monotonic, whereas for those with dimensionality between four and nine their approach is chaotic. A clear geometrical picture is constructed whereby this result can be understood. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Nakanishi, Noboru (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Mathematical Sciences)
De Donder condition and the gravitational energy-momentum pseudotensor in general relativity
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 75(6) p. 1351-1358; ISSN 0033-068X; CODEN PTPKA; Jun 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS
BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; TENSORS

It is conjectured that Einstein's gravitational energy-momentum pseudotensor is physically significant under the de Donder condition. The validity of this conjecture is explicitly checked by some simple exact solutions to the Einstein equation. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Letelier, P.S.; Oliveira, S.R. (Departamento de Fisica, Universidade de Brasilia, 70.910 Brasilia-D. F., Brazil)
Exact self-gravitating disks and rings: A solitonic approach
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(1) p. 165-170; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jan 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ACCELERATION; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; INVERSE SCATTERING PROBLEM; RINGS; ROTATION; SOLITONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; QUASI PARTICLES

The Belinsky--Zakharov version of the inverse scattering method is used to generate a large class of solutions to the vacuum Einstein equations representing uniformly accelerating and rotating disks and rings. The solutions studied are generated from a simple class of static disks and rings that can be expressed in a simple form using suitable complex functions of the usual cylindrical coordinates
January 1987

metadata.@content: Deruelle, N. (Paris-6 Univ., 75 (France). Inst. Henri Poincare); Madore, J. (Ecole Polytechnique, 91 - Palaiseau (France). Centre de Physique Theorique)
A smooth oscillating cosmological solution
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 186(1) p. 25-28; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 26 Feb 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; METRICS; OSCILLATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

A metric is given, determined by the field equations derived from the Lovelock lagrangian in a Kaluza-Klein theory of gravity, whose projection onto the observable external space yields a smooth oscillating cosmological solution. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Xanthopoulos, B.C. (Enrico Fermi Institute, University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois 60637 and Department of Physics, University of Crete, and Research Center of Crete, Iraklion, Greece)
Cylindrical waves and cosmic strings of Petrov type D
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(12) p. 3608-3616; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Dec 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAND UNIFIED THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

A three-parameter family of (time-dependent) cylindrically symmetric solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations is obtained. They all are asymptotically flat, they admit a regular axis, and they are free from curvature singularities. For general values of the parameters the solution exhibits an angle deficit in going around the axis and it is interpreted as a cosmic string surrounded by gravitational waves. The angle deficit is eliminated for a two-parameter subfamily, leading to an everywhere-regular Petrov type-D spacetime describing the propagation of nonradiating cylindrical gravitational waves. A relationship between the linear mass density of the string and the C-energy of the spacetime is established
January 1986

metadata.@content: Fang, L.Z.; Mo, H.J. (University of Science and Technology, Hefei (China). Center for Astrophysics)
Wavefunction of a rotating universe
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 186(3/4) p. 297-302; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 12 Mar 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; FLUIDS; METRICS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; ROTATION; ROTATIONAL STATES; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; UNIVERSE; WAVE FUNCTIONS
ENERGY LEVELS; EQUATIONS; EXCITED STATES; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MECHANICS
The Hartle-Hawking wavefunction of a homogeneous-isotropic rotating universe has been found. It is shown that the universe with large global rotation is unlikely. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Joshi, P.S. (Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Bombay)
Conformal quantization in singular spacetimes
Topological properties and global structure of space-time
United States

Bergmann, P.G.; De Sabbata, V; p. 109-120; 1986; p. 109-120; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on topological properties and global structure of space-time; Erice (Italy); 12-22 May 1985
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
CAUSALITY; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CONFORMAL MAPPING; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM MECHANICS; SINGULARITY; SMOOTH MANIFOLDS; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY; WAVE EQUATIONS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; MECHANICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

This paper takes into account the perturbations in the metric, i.e., the fluctuations in the spacetime geometry, while considering the problem of spacetime singularities. Since taking into account fully general metric fluctuations in spacetime geometry would be a difficult task mathematically, some aspects of the difficulty of the situation are discussed. Details of a quantization procedure are discussed. After specifying the meaning and characterization of singularities, the author discusses the status of singularities within the quantum conformal framework. It is shown that the quantum conformal fluctuations diverge in the limit of approach to the classically singular epoch, thus rendering the classical conclusions on singularities as no longer inevitable
January 1986

metadata.@content: Patra, A.C. (Darjeeling Government Coll., West Bengal (India). Dept. of Mathematics); Roy, D. (Jadavpur Univ., Calcutta (India). Dept. of Mathematics)
A new solution for a rotating perfect fluid in general relativity
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(1) p. 195-202; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Jan 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME

Solutions obtained by Kramer [1980, Exact Solutions of Einsteins' Field Equations, Camb. Univ. Press] for a rotating perfect fluid in general relativity are generalised. In the process a few results are noted that seem mathematically interesting and may be applicable elsewhere. (author)

metadata.@content: McIntosh, C.B.G.; Lun, A.W.-C. (Monash Univ., Clayton (Australia). Dept. of Mathematics); Halford, W.D. (Massey Univ., Palmerston North (New Zealand). Dept. of Mathematics and Statistics)
Type II and III twisting vacuum metrics and symmetries
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(1) p. 117-123; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Jan 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; SYMMETRY; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

A class of twisting Einstein vacuum metrics, with Weyl tensors of Petrov type II or III, is examined. It is shown that a number of the metrics in this class each admit a two-parameter group of homothetic motions. Since each type III metric of this class is determined by a function which satisfies a linear differential equation, the linear addition of two such functions, each of which determines a metric which admits a homothetic motion, then determines a metric which, in general, does not admit a homothetic motion. The relationship of general type II and III metrics of this class to metrics with homothetic symmetries is also discussed. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Lee, S. (Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan 11529, Republic of China)
Soliton transformations for axially symmetric higher-dimensional gravity. I. Generalized Neugebauer--Kramer transformations
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(4) p. 893-900; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Apr 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; ITERATIVE METHODS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; METRICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SIGMA MODEL; SOLITONS; SYMMETRY; TRANSFORMATIONS
BOSON-EXCHANGE MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; PERIPHERAL MODELS; QUASI PARTICLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The field equations for axially symmetric gravitational fields in 4+K dimensions with K-dimensional toroidal compatification can be reduced to those of a generalized nonlinear sigma model. The dual symmetry of this model is considered first. Then the soliton transformations for these equations are derived using the method of Belinskii and Zakharov consequently generalizing their results to the higher-dimensional case. From the result of one-soliton transformation, a series of discrete symmetries generalizing the Neugebauer--Kramer transformation in the four-dimensional case are obtained. The basic properties of these new transformations are studied
January 1987

metadata.@content: Lee, S. (Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan 11529. Republic of China)
Soliton transformations for axially symmetric higher-dimensional gravity. II. Belinskii--Zakharov N-soliton transformations
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(4) p. 901-904; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Apr 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; ITERATIVE METHODS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SIGMA MODEL; SOLITONS; SYMMETRY; TRANSFORMATIONS
BOSON-EXCHANGE MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; PERIPHERAL MODELS; QUASI PARTICLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The solutions of vacuum Einstein equations in 4+K dimensions with 2+K commuting Killing vectors under the Abelian Kaluza--Klein ansatz are considered. This system admits Belinskii--Zakharov-type soliton transformations. The explicit formulas for general N-soliton transformations are obtained by iterating the formulas for one-soliton transformation
January 1987

metadata.@content: Jantzen, R.T. (Department of Mathematical Sciences, Villanova University, Villanova, Pennsylvania 19085; ICRA, Department of Physics, University of Rome, 00185 Rome, Italy)
Symmetry and variational methods in higher-dimensional theories: Errata and addendum
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 35(6) p. 2034-2035; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Mar 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HAMILTONIANS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; SO GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; VACUUM STATES; VARIATIONAL METHODS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; QUANTUM OPERATORS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The additional conditions satisfied by the generalized Kasner solution of the vacuum Einstein equations in N+1 spacetime dimensions are explicitly shown to have a simple geometric interpretation in the Hamiltonian formulation
January 1987

metadata.@content: Hiscock, W.A. (Montana State Univ., Bozeman (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Semiclassical gravitational effects near cosmic strings
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 188(3) p. 317-320; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 16 Apr 1987; GRANT PHY-85-05484
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; AXIAL SYMMETRY; BOSONS; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EXPECTATION VALUE; FERMIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; QUASILINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALAR FIELDS; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SPINOR FIELDS; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; STRING MODELS; VACUUM STATES; VECTOR FIELDS

BASIC INTERACTIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY; TENSORS

The vacuum expectation value of the stress-energy tensor of an arbitrary collection of conformal massless free quantum fields (scalar, spinor, and vector) in the presence of a static cylindrically symmetric cosmic string is found, up to an undetermined numerical constant. This quantum stress-energy tensor is then used as a source in the linearized semiclassical Einstein equations, which are solved to find the first-order (in ℎ) corrections to the exterior metric of a static, cylindrically symmetric cosmic string. The main result is that, at first-order in ℎ, the (r, φ) two-space is no longer a simple flat cone; to this order the (r, φ) two-space is a (linearized) hyperboloid, which asymptotically approaches the classical surface at large values of r. The asymptotic value of the deficit angle of the cone is unchanged, still being precisely 8πμ. (orig.)
January 1987

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04834" assignment="upposted">invariance principles</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07195" assignment="upposted">particle models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08123" assignment="upposted">quantum field theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="upposted">symmetry</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The vacuum expectation value of the stress-energy tensor of an arbitrary collection of conformal massless free quantum fields (scalar, spinor, and vector) in the presence of a static cylindrically symmetric cosmic string is found, up to an undetermined numerical constant. This quantum stress-energy tensor is then used as a source in the linearized semiclassical Einstein equations, which are solved to find the first-order (in ℎ) corrections to the exterior metric of a static, cylindrically symmetric cosmic string. The main result is that, at first-order in ℎ, the (r, φ) two-space is no longer a simple flat cone; to this order the (r, φ) two-space is a (linearized) hyperboloid, which asymptotically approaches the classical surface at large values of r. The asymptotic value of the deficit angle of the cone is unchanged, still being precisely 8πμ. (orig.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="NL">Netherlands</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Ivanenko, D.; Sardanashvily, G. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR). Fizicheskij Fakul'tet)
Goldstone type (non-Poincare) supergravity
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 75(4) p. 969-976; ISSN 0033-068X; CODEN PTPKA; Apr 1986
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2140)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GOLDSTONE BOSONS; HIGGS BOSONS; POINCARE GROUPS; SUPERGRAVITY; SYMMETRY BREAKING
BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The gauge description of gravity as Higgs-Goldstone type fields is extended on supergravity. Following the Poincare gauge version of gravity, contemporary supergravity models are connected with the super (graded) Poincare group. Most of these models are based on gauge coordinate supertranslations in the spirit of Kibble's gravity approach, although graded affine bundles come into play, too. However, Poincare gauge versions of gravity (especially Kibble's one criticized by F. Hehl and others) fail to be quite satisfactory. The Poincare supergravity faces its own additional difficulties. For instance, many authors ignore the fact that by the supertranslation law coordinates Xμ are not real, but represent even elements of a Grassmann algebra. The Poincare gauge versions of gravity lost sight of the fact that not only gauge potentials, but Higgs-Goldstone fields appear in a gauge theory when symmetries are spontaneously broken. Einstein's gravitational field and supergravity turn out to be fields just of this type. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Toimela, T. (Research Institute for Theoretical Physics, University of Helsinki, Siltavuorenpenger 20 C, 00170 Helsinki, Finland)
On the solution of the Tolman--Oppenheimer--Volkov equation with the ultrarelativistic equation of state
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1541-1543; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DENSITY; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; INTEGRALS; NEUTRON STARS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE
ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; STARS

The Tolman--Oppenheimer--Volkov equation is studied in the case of the ultrarelativistic equation of state. The original system of two first-order differential equations is turned into one first-order equation that is independent of the central density, plus an integral. It is shown how the physical solutions are related to the analytically known infinite central density solution. The results are further generalized into the arbitrary γ-law equation of state, p(γ-1)rho. Finally, the case of a nonzero bag constant is briefly discussed
January 1987

metadata.@content: Feinstein, A. (Center for Theoretical Physics, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer Sheva 84105, Israel)
Effective energy of gravitational solitons
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 35(10) p. 3263-3265; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 May 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SOLITONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS; QUASI PARTICLES

The exact solution of the Einstein equations describing a pair of gravitational solitons superimposed on a spatially flat expanding background is considered. Using the high-frequency approximation we show that the soliton-''antisoliton'' pair carries an energy density which might be expressed as a simple function of intrinsic solitary parameters: ε = (m2/16πt) ln(λ2+l2)/λ2, where m is the solitary amplitude, λ is the width of each soliton, and l denotes the initial spatial separation of the pair
January 1987

metadata.@content: Ivanov, G.G. (Kazanskii Gosudarstvennyi Universitet, Kazan, USSR)
Isotropization in spatially homogeneous, two-component cosmological models
United States
Soviet Astronomy; v. 30 p. 129-131; ISSN 0038-5301; CODEN SAAJA; Apr 1986; Cover-to-cover translation of Astronomicheskij Zhurnal (USSR).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COLLISIONLESS PLASMA; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ISOTROPY; RELATIVISTIC PLASMA; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION
DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PLASMA

Exact solutions of the collisionless Vlasov equation, compatible with the Einstein equations containing the energy-momentum tensor (Tik) of collisionless gas, are obtained for anisotropic models of Bianchi types I and IX. The evolution of small disturbances of spatially flat and closed Friedman models is investigated for a mixture of ultrarelativistic collisionless gas and a nonrelativistic perfect fluid. During the nonrelativistic phase of the cosmological expansion the tensor perturbations will interact with the collisionless component, producing in the metric and Tik a residual anisotropy. 7 references
January 1986

metadata.@content: Koikawa, T.; Yoshimura, M. (National Lab. for High Energy Physics, Oho, Ibaraki (Japan))
Dilation fields and event horizon
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 189(1/2) p. 29-33; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 30 Apr 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INSTABILITY; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; STRING MODELS; SUPERSYMMETRY; TIME DEPENDENCE; VECTOR FIELDS
CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SYMMETRY; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The no-hair theorem precludes the existence of black holes with a scalar charge. We explicitly construct static spherically symmetric solutions of the Einstein equation in the presence of massless dilaton and gauge fields, relevant to higher-dimensional Kaluza-Klein and superstring theories. Except the special case of the wormhole solution, all non-trivial solutions contain naked singularities not covered by an event horizon. Time-dependent perturbation, however, shows the instability of these solutions, caused by the dilaton field. (orig.)
January 1987

        <descriptor type="valid" key="20118" assignment="indexer">supersymmetry</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10231" assignment="indexer">time dependence</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10807" assignment="indexer">vector fields</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03337" assignment="upposted">extended particle model</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07195" assignment="upposted">particle models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08123" assignment="upposted">quantum field theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09719" assignment="upposted">symmetry</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The no-hair theorem precludes the existence of black holes with a scalar charge. We explicitly construct static spherically symmetric solutions of the Einstein equation in the presence of massless dilaton and gauge fields, relevant to higher-dimensional Kaluza-Klein and superstring theories. Except the special case of the wormhole solution, all non-trivial solutions contain naked singularities not covered by an event horizon. Time-dependent perturbation, however, shows the instability of these solutions, caused by the dilaton field. (orig.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

metadata.@content: Nishino, Hitoshi (Brandeis Univ., Waltham, MA (USA). Dept. of Physics); Gates, S.J. Jr. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Calabi-Yau manifold compactification in the heterotic string and N=1 supersymmetry in four dimensions
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 189(1/2) p. 45-51; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 30 Apr 1987; GRANT PHY-83-13243; PHY-84-16030
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

COMPACTIFICATION; CORRECTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GRAND UNIFIED THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LOCALITY; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SCALAR FIELDS; SMOOTH MANIFOLDS; STRING MODELS; SU-3 GROUPS; SUPERSYMMETRY

EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

We examine whether a torsion-free Calabi-Yau manifold with the SU(3) holonomy group embedded in E8xE8 satisfies the classical field equations with O(α'3) heterotic string corrections. In general, the torsion-freedom is lost and the exact embedding condition is modified at O(α'3), but the N=1 supersymmetry in four dimensions is still preserved even at O(α'3). Allowing some local field redefinitions, however, we can restore the exact embedding of the SU(3) holonomy into E8xE8 → E6xSU(3).E8, maintaining also the D=4, N=1 supersymmetry. Our results are based on the dual (type IB) superspace formulation, which guarantees the on-shell closure of supersymmetry. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Lima, J.A.S. de.
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro
Szekeres spacetimes with heat flow
Brazil
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HEAT FLUX; METRICS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A new class of inhomogeneous exact solutions of Einstein field equations is given. They generalize the dust-filled models found by Szekeres. In the course of time a subclass of models present a friedmannian phase.(Author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Castagnino, M.; Domenech, G.; Noriega, R.J.; Schifini, C.G. (Instituto de Astronomia y Fisica del Espacio (CONICET), Casilla de Correo 67, Suc. 28, CP 1428, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto de Fisica de Rosario (CONICET-UNR), Av. Pellegrini 250, CP 2000, Rosario, Pcia, de Santa Fe, Argentina; Departmento de Matematicas, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y)
On a Weyl-type theorem for higher-order Lagrangians
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(8) p. 1854-1857; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Aug 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; QUANTIZATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SUPERGRAVITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

Weyl's theorem is extended making use of the theory of concomitants to obtain a Lagrangian density for the massless bosonic fields without dimensional constants. It turns out to be quadratic in the gravitational field and encompasses all the theories that usually appear in the literature. It is shown that the gauge invariance of the Lagrangian follows from the invariance of the field equations
January 1987

metadata.@content: Jain, L.C. (Govt. Post Graduate College, Chhindwara)
Principle-theoretic approach of kondo and construction-theoretic formalism of gauge theories
Gravitational radiation and relativity
United States
Weber, J.; Karade, T.M; p. 271-282; ISBN 9971-978-88-1; 1986; p. 271-282; World Scientific Pub. Co; Teaneck, NJ (USA)
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

CORRELATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; MAPPING FIBRATION; ORGANIZING; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TOPOLOGY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICS; TRANSFORMATIONS

Einstein classified various theories in physics as principle-theories and constructive-theories. In this lecture Kondo's approach to microscopic and macroscopic phenomena is analysed for its principle theoretic pursuit as followed by construction. The fundamentals of his theory may be recalled as Tristimulus principle, Observation principle, Kawaguchi spaces, empirical information, epistemological point of view, unitarity, intrinsicality, and dimensional analysis subject to logical and geometrical achievement. On the other hand, various physicists have evolved constructive gauge theories through the phenomenological point of view, often a collective one. Their synthetic method involves fibre bundles and connections, path integrals as well as other hypothetical structures. They lead towards clarity, completeness and adaptability
January 1986

metadata.@content: Evans, M.; Ovrut, B.A. (Pennsylvania Univ., Philadelphia (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Hyperkaehler metrics from (4,0) superspace
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 190(1/2) p. 63-68; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 21 May 1987; CONTRACT DOE-AC02-76ER03071
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1140)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COMMUTATION RELATIONS; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRADED LIE GROUPS; METRICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; RIEMANN SPACE; SIGMA MODEL; SMOOTH MANIFOLDS; STRING MODELS; SUPERSYMMETRY; VACUUM STATES

BOSON-EXCHANGE MODELS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; PERIPHERAL MODELS; SPACE; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS

We construct (4,0) supersymmetric non-linear sigma models using the superspace formalism. An explicit expression for hyperkaehler metrics in terms of quaternionic structures results. These metrics are vacuum solutions to Einstein's equation, satisfy the tree level equations of motion of the superstring and are analogs of the Calabi-Yau manifolds favored for superstring compactification. (orig.)
January 1987

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We construct (4,0) supersymmetric non-linear sigma models using the superspace formalism. (orig.)</abstract>

metadata.@content: Modak, Bijan (Presidency Coll., Calcutta (India). Dept. of Physics)
Inflation in a universe with viscosity
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(3) p. L47-L49; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 May 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; UNIVERSE; VISCOSITY
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

An exact spatially inhomogeneous solution of Einstein's equations is obtained where the energy stress tensor is that due to a viscous fluid and the false vacuum. The solution undergoes an exponential expansion with homogenisation, isotropisation and the 3-space section becomes flat in the timescale (Λ/3)sup(-1/2) as in the case of homogeneous models reported by previous workers. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Hanquin, J.L.; Demaret, J. (Liege Univ. (Belgium). Inst. d'Astrophysique)
Abelian anisotropic cosmological models in 11-dimensional supergravity
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(3) p. L51-L58; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 May 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SUPERGRAVITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The geometrical theory of finite incidence structures is used to classify the possible configurations of the bosonic field, characteristic of 11-dimensional supergravity, as well as to solve the corresponding field equations, in the case of Abelian anisotropic spatially homogeneous cosmological models. Solutions with different splittings of the ten spatial dimensions are discussed in connection with the time behaviour of both the spatial volume associated with the directions along which the bosonic field lives and the complementary volume. This behaviour depends clearly on the type of configuration of the bosonic field as well as on the amount of anisotropy of the models. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Varela, V. (Universidad Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venezuela)
General relativity, the massless scalar field, and the cosmological constant
United States
International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 26(1) p. 91-96; ISSN 0020-7748; CODEN IJTPB; Jan 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; POWER SERIES; SCALAR FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SERIES EXPANSION; TIME DEPENDENCE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; TENSORS

For gravity coupled to a neutral, massless scalar field, Wyman suggested a method of solution in power series valid provided the scalar field depends only on time. In this work they generalize his approach to nonzero cosmological constant
January 1987

EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTEGRALS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; TENSORS

A possible classical route conducting towards a general relativity theory with higher-derivatives starting, in a sense, from first principles, is analysed. A completely causal vacuum solution with the symmetries of the Goedel universe is obtained in the framework of this higher-derivative gravity. This very peculiar and rare result is the first known vcuum solution of the fourth-order gravity theory that is not a solution of the corresponding Einstein's equations.(Author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Ivanenko, D.D.; Krechet, V.G. (Yaroslavskij Gosudarstvennyj Pedagogicheskij Inst. (USSR))
On the rotation of the Universe
O vrashchenii Vselennoj
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 30(3) p. 12-16; ISSN 0021-3411; CODEN IVUFA; Mar 1987; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ANGULAR VELOCITY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; MASS; ROTATION; SPINOR FIELDS; TORSION; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; VELOCITY

Problem of the possible rotation of the observed Universe (metagalaxy) from positions of the gravity general relativity theory using the concept of hierarchial structure of reality based on the existence of Eddington-Dirac ''Large numbers'' is investigated. Formulae for angular momentum and angular velocity ω of the metagalaxy rotation, which give evaluations for a value ω coinciding in order with the observed one, are derived from the Einstein equations in the Landau Raichaudkhuri form. By means of formulae derived using the hierarchy relation (''Large number'' relation) the Stanyukovich formula (S ∼ N3/2) connecting the number of nucleons N in the metagalaxy and its angular momentum S has been derived. It is shown that angular velocity can decrease inverse proportionally to a scale factor which can explain its low value in the contemporary epoch. It is shown that space-time torsion induced with spin of fermion matter can be the rotation source in cosmology
January 1987

metadata.@content: Embacher, F.
Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik
Machian effects in general relativity
Austria
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MACH PRINCIPLE; ROTATION
FIELD THEORIES; HYPOTHESIS

As a consequence of Mach's principle, rotating matter should cause local inertial frames or gyroscopes in its vicinity to undergo a small rotation which is not present in the Newtonian picture. H. Thirring and J. Lense were the first to derive similar predictions from the field equations of general relativity. Since these early days of relativity, a lot of exact and approximate solutions to Einstein's equations have been examined under this point of view. The qualitative features of Machian effects are most easily demonstrated in the cylinder symmetric case, where some exact results are available. For example, space-time is flat inside a uniformly rotating matter shell, and the rotation of this interior with respect to 'infinity' (the distant stars) has a clear meaning. In the more realistic case of what happens near a massive rotating star, one is forced to perform certain approximations. In modern language, Machian effects are described in terms of the twist of timelike killing vector fields. In the linearized theory, the equations that determine the Machian structure generated by a given matter distribution, resemble to some extent those of classical electrodynamics. This correspondence provides a pedagogical approach how to compute the quantitative extent of inertial frame 'dragging'. 6 refs., 5 figs. (Author)
January 1988

metadata.@content: Mansouri, R.
Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik
Gravitational field of static domain walls
Austria
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1520)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; DOMAIN STRUCTURE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

A static solution of Einstein's equations representing a planar domain wall in an anisotropic background is found. The solution matches in the weak-field region to the linearized solution of Vilenkin. The wall is repulsive to particles but perfectly transparent to light. 13 refs. (Autor)
January 1989

metadata.@content: Bokhari, A.H.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
A comment on anisotropic spheres admitting one parameter group of conformal motions
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANISOTROPY; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; RICCI TENSOR; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; METRICS; TENSORS

An earlier solution of the Einstein field equations for spherically symmetric distributions of anisotropic matter (principle stresses unequal) is modified, assuming the existence of a one parameter group of conformal motions. It is shown that the modified solution yields a more general expression of the spacetime metric which includes the earlier metric as a special case. The solution is matched across a separating hypersurface with the Schwarzschild solution. It turns out that the expression for the line element corresponding to the induced metric on the boundary, from the inside, makes geometry look significantly different from the one obtained earlier. (author). 2 refs
January 1989

metadata.@content: Mikhail, F.I. (Ain Shams Univ., (Egypt). Dept. of Mathematics); Wanas, M.I. (Cairo Univ., Cairo (Egypt). Astronomy Dept.); Hindawi, A. (International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)); Lashin, E.I. (Ain Shams Univ. (Egypt). Dept. of Physics)
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Energy-momentum complex in Moeller's tetrad theory of gravitation
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GRAVITATION; METRICS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; TENSORS

Moeller's tetrad theory of gravitation is examined with regard to the energy-momentum complex. The energy-momentum complex as well as the superpotential associated with Moeller's theory are derived. Moeller's field equations are solved in the case of ''general'' spherical symmetry. Two different solutions, giving rise to the same metric, are obtained. The energy associated with one solution is found to be twice the energy associated with the other. An avenue out of this inconsistency is suggested. (author). 20 refs, 1 tab
January 1991

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Moeller's tetrad theory of gravitation is examined with regard to the energy-momentum complex. The energy-momentum complex as well as the superpotential associated with Moeller's theory are derived. Moeller's field equations are solved in the case of ''general'' spherical symmetry. Two different solutions, giving rise to the same metric, are obtained. The energy associated with one solution is found to be twice the energy associated with the other. An avenue out of this inconsistency is suggested. (author). 20 refs, 1 tab</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="XA">International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Marrakchi, A.E.L.; Tapia, V.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Fourth-rank cosmology
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
CAUSALITY; COSMOLOGY; FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; MATTER
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Some cosmological implications of the recently proposed fourth-rank theory of gravitation are studied. The model exhibits the possibility of being free from the horizon and flatness problems at the price of introducing a negative pressure. The field equations we obtain are compatible with kobs=0 and Ωobs<0.18 for our present day universe; they imply -p/ρ<0.055 which corresponds to an almost pressureless perfect fluid. Furthermore, there is no horizon problem for t>tclas approx. 1020tPlanck approx. 10-23s. When interpreted at the light of General Relativity the treatment is shown to be almost equivalent to that of the standard model of cosmology combined with the inflationary scenario. Hence, an interpretation of the negative pressure hypothesis is provided. (author). 8 refs
January 1992

metadata.@content: Marrakchi, A.L.; Tapia, V.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Fourth-rank gravity and cosmology
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

We consider the consequences of describing the metric properties of space-time through a quartic line element. The associated ''metric'' is a fourth-rank tensor Gμυλπ. In order to recover a Riemannian behaviour of the geometry it is necessary to have Gμυλπ = g (μυgλπ). We construct a theory for the gravitational field based on the fourth-rank metric Gμυλπ. In the absence of matter the fourth-rank metric becomes separable and the theory coincides with General Relativity. In the presence of matter we can maintain Riemmanianicity, but now gravitation couples, as compared to General Relativity, in a different way to matter. We develop a simple cosmological model based on a FRW metric with matter described by a perfect fluid. For the present time the field equations are compatible with kOBS = O and ΩOBS <0.18 and they imply p/ρ<0.038 which corresponds to an almost pressureless perfect fluid. Therefore, the flatness problem is solved. However, our approach is valid only for p/ρ<0.236. Therefore, we consider an early universe in which the state equation of matter is p/ρ=0.236 rather than p/p=1/3. There is no violation of causality, no horizon problem, for t>tCLAS approx. 1020t PLANCK approx. 10-23s. Our final and most important result is the fact that the entropy is an increasing function of time. When interpreted at the light of General Relativity the treatment is shown to be almost equivalent to that of the standard model of cosmology combined with the inflationary scenario. (author). 16 refs, 1 fig
ogy combined with the inflationary scenario. (author). 16 refs, 1 fig
January 1992

metadata.@content: Manoff, S. (Institute for Nuclear Research and Nuclear Energy, Department of Theoretical Physics, Sofia (Bulgaria)); Kolarov, A. (Faculty of Physics, University of Sofia, Sofia (Bulgaria)); Dimitrov, B. (Bogolyubov Laboratory of Theoretical Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna (Russian Federation))
Bogolyubov Laboratory of Theoretical Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna (Russian Federation)
(Ln-bar, g)-spaces. General relativity over V4-bar - spaces
English
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; RIEMANN SPACE; TENSOR FIELDS; VECTOR FIELDS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; SPACE; TENSORS

The results from the considerations of differentiable manifolds with contravariant and covariant affine connections and metrics are specialized for the case of (Ln bar, g)-spaces with metric transport (∇ξ g = 0 for all ξ is T (M), gij;k = 0 and fji = eφ · gji (the s.c. (pseudo)Riemannian spaces with contravariant and covariant symmetric affine connections). Einstein's theory of gravitation is considered in (pseudo)Riemannian spaces with different (not only by sign) contravariant and covariant affine connections ((Vn bar)-spaces, n = 4). The Euler-Lagrange equations and the corresponding energy-momentum tensors (EMT-s) are obtained and compared with the Einstein equations and the EMT-s in V4-spaces. The geodesic and autoparallel equations in V4 bar -spaces are found as different equations in contrast to the case of V4-spaces
January 1998

metadata.@content: Konopleva, N.P. (All-Russian Scientific Research Institute of Electromechanics, Moscow (Russian Federation))
Bogolyubov Laboratory of Theoretical Physiscs, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna (Russian Federation)
Hyperbolical instantons and gauge fields vacuum structure
English
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2100)
CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INSTANTONS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUASI PARTICLES; SPACE; TENSORS

Problems of application of nonperturbative quantization methods in unified theories of gauge fields and gravity are discussed. Vacuum conceptions in these theories and instantons role in the vacuum structure are analyzed. The vacuum solutions of Einstein's equations are used for definition of nontrivial gauge field vacuum. General Relativity and SO (3, 1)-gauge gravity theory are regarded as particular cases of the non-abelian gauge field theories. It is shown that all vacuum solutions of GR equations are hyperbolical instantons and determine the vacuum structure of each gauge field equally the gravity and QCD
January 1998

metadata.@content: Sakalli, I.; Halilsoy, M. (Department of Physics, Eastern Mediterranean University, G. Magosa, N. Cyprus, Mersin 10 (Turkey)), E-mail: izzet.sakalli@emu.edu.tr, E-mail: mustafa.halilsoy@emu.edu.tr
Chaos in Kundt Type-III Spacetimes
English
China

Chinese Physics Letters; v. 28(7); ISSN 0256-307X; CODEN CPLEEU; Jul 2011; [4 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0256-307X/28/7/070402; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
CHAOS THEORY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; NUMERICAL ANALYSIS; SPACE-TIME; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICS

We consider geodesic motion in a particular Kundt type-III spacetime in which the Einstein-Yang-Mills equations admit the solutions. On a particular surface as constraint, we project the geodesics into the (x, y) plane and treat the problem as a two-dimensional one. Our numerical study shows that chaotic behavior emerges under reasonable conditions. (general)
January 2011

metadata.@content: Ying-Qiu, Gu (School of Mathematical Science, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433 (China)), E-mail: yqgu@fudan.edu.cn
The series solution to the metric of stationary vacuum with axisymmetry
English
China
Chinese Physics. B; v. 19(3); ISSN 1674-1056; Mar 2010; [11 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1674-1056/19/3/030402; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
APPROXIMATIONS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MOMENTS METHOD; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SYMMETRY; TENSORS
CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

The multipole moment method not only conduces to the understanding of the deformation of the space–time, but also serves as an effective tool to approximately solve the Einstein field equation with. However, the usual multipole moments are recursively determined by a sequence of symmetric and trace-free tensors, which is inconvenient for practical resolution. In this paper, we develop a simplified procedure to generate the series solutions to the metric of the stationary vacuum with axisymmetry, and show its validity. In order to understand the free parameters in the solution, we propose to take the Schwarzschild metric as a standard ruler, and some well-known examples are analysed and compared with the series solutions in detail
January 2010

metadata.@content: Volkov, Mikhail S (Laboratoire de Mathématiques et Physique Théorique CNRS-UMR 7350, Université de Tours, Parc de Grandmont, F-37200 Tours (France); Institut des Hautes Etudes Scientifiques (IHES), F-91440 Bures-sur-Yvette (France)), E-mail: volkov@lmpt.univ-tours.fr
Self-accelerating cosmologies and hairy black holes in ghost-free bigravity and massive gravity
English
United Kingdom

Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 30(18); ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRDG; 21 Sep 2013; [18 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/18/184009; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ACCELERATION; ANTI DE SITTER GROUP; ANTI DE SITTER SPACE; BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; TIME DEPENDENCE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

We present a survey of the known cosmological and black hole solutions in ghost-free bigravity and massive gravity theories. These can be divided into three classes. First, there are solutions with proportional metrics, which are the same as in General Relativity with a cosmological term, which can be positive, negative or zero. Secondly, for spherically symmetric systems, there are solutions with non-bidiagonal metrics. The g-metric fulfils Einstein equations with a positive cosmological term and a matter source, while the f-metric is anti-de Sitter. The third class contains solutions with bidiagonal metrics, and these can be quite complex. The time-dependent solutions describe homogeneous (isotropic or anisotropic) cosmologies which show a late-time self-acceleration or other types of behavior. The static solutions describe black holes with a massive graviton hair, and also globally regular lumps of energy. None of these are asymptotically flat. Including a matter source gives rise to asymptotically flat solutions which exhibit the Vainshtein mechanism of recovery of General Relativity in a finite region. (paper)
January 2013

metadata.@content: Penrose, R. (Department of Mathematics, Birkbeck College, London (United Kingdom))
On Gravitational Collapse
Contemporary Physics: Trieste Symposium 1968. Vol. I. Proceedings of the International Symposium on Contemporary Physics
English
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)

International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna (Austria); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 592 p; Jul 1969; p. 545-556; International Symposium on Contemporary Physics; Trieste (Italy); 7-28 Jun 1968; ISSN 0074-1884; 19 refs., 5 figs.
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; ROTATION; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SURFACES; TRAPPING
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MOTION

The gravitational collapse of a spherically symmetrical body, to within its Schwarzschild radius, is discussed in qualitative terms. The concept of a ''trapped surface'' is presented, in order to deal with asymmetrical cases. The effect of rotation is illustrated by reference to the Kerr solution. Two cases, namely of ''small'' and ''large'' angular momentum, are contrasted. In the latter case no trapped surface (and no event horizon) arises. A new theorem, due jointly to S.W. Hawking and the present author, is described, which effectively incorporates and generalizes the previous theorems predicting space-time singularities. In particular, if a physically acceptable space-time contains a trapped surface (or, alternatively, if it is spatially closed), then on the basis of Einstein's equations (with λ = 0), it must possess a singularity. (author)
January 1969

        <category type="common" level="primary" key="S79">ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY</category>
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="00410" assignment="indexer">angular momentum</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04115" assignment="indexer">gravitational collapse</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="31383" assignment="indexer">mathematical solutions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08599" assignment="indexer">rotation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08873" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild radius</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09152" assignment="indexer">singularity</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09363" assignment="indexer">spherical configuration</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09691" assignment="indexer">surfaces</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10412" assignment="indexer">trapping</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02148" assignment="upposted">configuration</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="06304" assignment="upposted">motion</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <qualifiers>
        <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier>
      </qualifiers>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The gravitational collapse of a spherically symmetrical body, to within its Schwarzschild radius, is discussed in qualitative terms. The concept of a ''trapped surface'' is presented, in order to deal with asymmetrical cases. The effect of rotation is illustrated by reference to the Kerr solution. Two cases, namely of ''small'' and ''large'' angular momentum, are contrasted. In the latter case no trapped surface (and no event horizon) arises. A new theorem, due jointly to S.W. Hawking and the present author, is described, which effectively incorporates and generalizes the previous theorems predicting space-time singularities. In particular, if a physically acceptable space-time contains a trapped surface (or, alternatively, if it is spatially closed), then on the basis of Einstein's equations (with λ = 0), it must possess a singularity. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

    </administratives>

metadata.@content: Neill, Duff (Center for Theoretical Physics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139 (United States)); Rothstein, Ira Z. (Department of Physics, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213 (United States))
Classical space–times from the S-matrix
English
Netherlands

Nuclear Physics. B; v. 877(2); ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBBO; 11 Dec 2013; p. 177-189; S0550-3213(13)00479-3; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nuclphysb.2013.09.007; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FEYNMAN DIAGRAM; FUNCTIONS; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; RECURSION RELATIONS; S MATRIX; SPIN; TEST PARTICLES; UNITARITY; YANG-MILLS THEORY
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; DIAGRAMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INFORMATION; MATRICES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

We show that classical space–times can be derived directly from the S-matrix for a theory of massive particles coupled to a massless spin two particle. As an explicit example we derive the Schwarzchild space–time as a series in GN. At no point of the derivation is any use made of the Einstein–Hilbert action or the Einstein equations. The intermediate steps involve only on-shell S-matrix elements which are generated via BCFW recursion relations and unitarity sewing techniques. The notion of a space–time metric is only introduced at the end of the calculation where it is extracted by matching the potential determined by the S-matrix to the geodesic motion of a test particle. Other static space–times such as Kerr follow in a similar manner. Furthermore, given that the procedure is action independent and depends only upon the choice of the representation of the little group, solutions to Yang–Mills (YM) theory can be generated in the same fashion. Moreover, the squaring relation between the YM and gravity three point functions shows that the seeds that generate solutions in the two theories are algebraically related. From a technical standpoint our methodology can also be utilized to calculate quantities relevant for the binary inspiral problem more efficiently then the more traditional Feynman diagram approach
January 2013
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nuclphysb.2013.09.007
