metadata.@content: McInnes, Brett; Teo, Edward, E-mail: matmcinn@nus.edu.sg, E-mail: eteo@nus.edu.sg
Generalized planar black holes and the holography of hydrodynamic shear
English
Netherlands

Nuclear Physics. B; v. 878; ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBBO; Jan 2014; p. 186-213; S0550-3213(13)00577-4; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nuclphysb.2013.11.013; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HEAVY ION REACTIONS; PHASE DIAGRAMS; QUARK MATTER; QUARKS; STRING MODELS; STRING THEORY
COMPOSITE MODELS; DIAGRAMS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INFORMATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; M-THEORY; NUCLEAR REACTIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUARK MODEL

AdS black holes with planar event horizon topology play a central role in AdS/CFT holography, and particularly in its applications. Generalizations of the known planar black holes can be found by considering the Plebański–Demiański metrics, a very general family of exactly specified solutions of the Einstein equations. These generalized planar black holes may be useful in applications. We give a concrete example of this in the context of the holographic description of the Quark–Gluon Plasma (QGP). We argue that our generalized planar black holes allow us to construct a model of the internal shearing motion generated when the QGP is produced in peripheral heavy-ion collisions. When embedded in string theory, the bulk physics is in fact unstable. We find however that this instability may develop too slowly to affect the evolution of the plasma, except possibly for high values of the quark chemical potential, such as will be studied in experimental scans of the quark matter phase diagram
January 2014
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nuclphysb.2013.11.013

metadata.@content: Mazharimousavi, S.H.; Kerachian, M.; Halilsoy, M. (Eastern Mediterranean University, Department of Physics, North Cyprus (Turkey))
A scan of f(R) models admitting Rindler-type acceleration
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-10; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2795-5
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ACCELERATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC

DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

As amanifestation of a large distance effect Grumiller modified Schwarzschild metric with an extraneous term reminiscent of Rindler acceleration. Such a term has the potential to explain the observed flat rotation curves in general relativity. The same idea has been extended herein to the larger arena of f(R) theory. With particular emphasis on weak energy conditions (WECs) for a fluid we present various classes of f(R) theories admitting a Rindler-type acceleration in the metric. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Falciano, F.T.; Vitenti, S.D.P.; Pinto-Neto, N. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas (CBPF), Rio de Janeiro, RJ (Brazil))
Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica (SBF), Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)
Validity conditions for linear cosmological perturbations
English
Brazil

2013; [1 p.]; 34. Brazilian national meeting on physics of particles and fields; 34. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos; Passa Quatro, MG (Brazil); 26-30 Aug 2013; ;  Available in abstract form only;  full text entered in this record
Miscellaneous
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; MASS DISTRIBUTION; METRICS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; UNIVERSE
DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATTER; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION

Full text: One of the main issues concerning back-reaction in cosmology is to validate the use of linear order perturbation to evolve the large-scale metric despite the presence of structure formation. After the appearance of cosmic structure such as galaxies, cluster and voids, the local dynamics becomes extremely non-linear and the local mass density can become 30 order of magnitude higher than the average mass density of the universe. Thus, it is certain that the matter evolution in small-scales is far from linear. Notwithstanding, at the same time the large scale metric perturbations are still perturbatively small. The LCDM model and the need for dark energy rest in the fact that the departure from FLRW metric is small and the linearized Einstein equations are the correct system to evolve them. However, it is still an open question whether or not the small-scale clumpiness can affect the evolution of the large-scales. We shall consider the validity conditions that could support the use of a homogeneous and isotropic metric to describe the universe in the large and show that the arguments found in the literature generally do not justify its applicability. We also stress that our treatment is covariant and gauge independent which allow to immediately compare with different approaches such as the 3+1 covariant approach first introduced by Hawking, Ehlers and Ellis. (author)
January 2013

        <conference key="">
          <titles>
            <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">34. Brazilian national meeting on physics of particles and fields</title>
            <title type="original" xml:lang="">34. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos</title>
          </titles>
          <locations>
            <location>Passa Quatro, MG (Brazil)</location>
          </locations>
          <dates>
            <date value="2013-08-26/2013-08-30" sici-chronology="20130826/20130830">26-30 Aug 2013</date>
          </dates>
        </conference>
      </conferences>
    </publication>
    <classification>
      <categories>
        <category type="common" level="primary" key="S79">ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY</category>
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03899" assignment="indexer">gauge invariance</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="23052" assignment="indexer">mass distribution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="23139" assignment="indexer">nonluminous matter</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02716" assignment="upposted">distribution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04834" assignment="upposted">invariance principles</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05913" assignment="upposted">matter</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09332" assignment="upposted">spatial distribution</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <qualifiers>
        <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier>
      </qualifiers>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Full text: One of the main issues concerning back-reaction in cosmology is to validate the use of linear order perturbation to evolve the large-scale metric despite the presence of structure formation. After the appearance of cosmic structure such as galaxies, cluster and voids, the local dynamics becomes extremely non-linear and the local mass density can become 30 order of magnitude higher than the average mass density of the universe. Thus, it is certain that the matter evolution in small-scales is far from linear. Notwithstanding, at the same time the large scale metric perturbations are still perturbatively small. The LCDM model and the need for dark energy rest in the fact that the departure from FLRW metric is small and the linearized Einstein equations are the correct system to evolve them. However, it is still an open question whether or not the small-scale clumpiness can affect the evolution of the large-scales. We shall consider the validity conditions that could support the use of a homogeneous and isotropic metric to describe the universe in the large and show that the arguments found in the literature generally do not justify its applicability. We also stress that our treatment is covariant and gauge independent which allow to immediately compare with different approaches such as the 3+1 covariant approach first introduced by Hawking, Ehlers and Ellis. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="BR">Brazil</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Wu, Bin (Nankai University, School of Physics, Tianjin (China)); Xu, Wei (Nankai University, School of Physics, Tianjin (China); Huazhong University of Science and Technology, School of Physics, Wuhan (China))
New class of rotating perfect fluid black holes in three dimensional gravity
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(8); ISSN 1434-6044; Aug 2014; p. 1-7; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-3007-z
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; IDEAL FLOW; METRICS; REST MASS; ROTATION; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID FLOW; INCOMPRESSIBLE FLOW; MASS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MOTION; RELATIVITY THEORY; STEADY FLOW; TENSORS

We obtain a new class of rotating black holes for Einstein theory with perfect fluid source in (2 + 1) dimensions. We conclude that these black hole solutions only depend on the variable of the angular velocity m(r). Some examples of these black holes are given explicitly. In particular, an unknown static black hole in this special background is obtained. In addition, the general properties including the horizon structure, energy conditions and equation of state, mass, and angular momentum are explained in detail. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Hindmarsh, Mark; Litim, Daniel; Rahmede, Christoph (Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Sussex, Brighton BN1 9QH (United Kingdom)), E-mail: m.b.hindmarsh@sussex.ac.uk, E-mail: d.litim@sussex.ac.uk, E-mail: c.rahmede@sussex.ac.uk
Asymptotically safe cosmology
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(07); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jul 2011; p. 019; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/07/019; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVOLUTION; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; POTENTIAL ENERGY; RENORMALIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; ULTRAVIOLET RADIATION; UNIVERSE
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RADIATIONS

We study quantum modifications to cosmology in a Friedmann-Robertson-Walker universe with and without scalar fields by taking the renormalisation group running of gravitational and matter couplings into account. We exploit the Bianchi identity to relate the renormalisation group scale with scale factor and derive the improved cosmological evolution equations. We find two types of cosmological fixed points where the renormalisation group scale either freezes in, or continues to evolve with scale factor. We discuss the implications of each of these, and classify the different cosmological fixed points with and without gravity displaying an asymptotically safe renormalisation group fixed point. We state conditions of existence for an inflating ultraviolet cosmological fixed point for Einstein gravity coupled to a scalar field. We also discuss other fixed point solutions such as 'scaling' solutions, or fixed points with equipartition between kinetic and potential energies
January 2011

metadata.@content: Hojjati, Alireza; Pogosian, Levon (Department of Physics, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, V5A 1S6 (Canada)); Zhao, Gong-Bo (Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Portsmouth, PO1 3FX (United Kingdom)), E-mail: alireza_hojjati@sfu.ca, E-mail: levon@sfu.ca, E-mail: gong-bo.zhao@port.ac.uk
Testing gravity with CAMB and CosmoMC
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(08); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Aug 2011; p. 005; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/08/005; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ASTROPHYSICS; C CODES; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CORRELATIONS; COSMOLOGY; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; M CODES; MASS; NEUTRINOS; SCALARS; SUPERNOVAE; TENSORS
BINARY STARS; COMPUTER CODES; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; PHYSICS; SIMULATION; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

We introduce a patch to the commonly used public codes CAMB and CosmoMC that allows the user to implement a general modification of the equations describing the growth of cosmological perturbations, while preserving the covariant conservation of the energy-momentum. This patch replaces the previously publicly released code MGCAMB, while also extending it in several ways. The new version removes the limitation of late-time-only modifications to the perturbed Einstein equations, and includes several parametrizations introduced in the literature. To demonstrate the use of the patch, we obtain joint constraints on the neutrino mass and parameters of a scalar-tensor gravity model from CMB, SNe and ISW data as measured from the correlation of CMB with large scale structure
January 2011

metadata.@content: Koster, Rik; Postma, Marieke (Nikhef, Science Park 105, 1098 XG Amsterdam (Netherlands)), E-mail: rikkost@nikhef.nl, E-mail: mpostma@nikhef.nl
A no-go for no-go theorems prohibiting cosmic acceleration in extra dimensional models
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(12); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Dec 2011; p. 015; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/12/015; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ACCELERATION; ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; METRICS; TRANSIENTS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

A four-dimensional effective theory that arises as the low-energy limit of some extra-dimensional model is constrained by the higher dimensional Einstein equations. Steinhardt and Wesley use this to show that accelerated expansion in our four large dimensions can only be transient in a large class of Kaluza-Klein models that satisfy the (higher dimensional) null energy condition [1]. We point out that these no-go theorems are based on a rather ad-hoc assumption on the metric, without which no strong statements can be made
January 2011

metadata.@content: Brustein, Ram (Department of Physics, Ben-Gurion University, Beer-Sheva, 84105 Israel (Israel)); Riotto, Antonio (CERN, PH-TH Division, CH-1211, Genève 23 (Switzerland)), E-mail: ramyb@bgu.ac.il, E-mail: Antonio.Riotto@cern.ch
Evolution equation for non-linear cosmological perturbations
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(11); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Nov 2011; p. 006; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/11/006; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

APPROXIMATIONS; ASTROPHYSICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGY; DEGREES OF FREEDOM; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVOLUTION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MEAN-FIELD THEORY; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; POTENTIALS; PROPAGATOR; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; RENORMALIZATION
CALCULATION METHODS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICS

We present a novel approach, based entirely on the gravitational potential, for studying the evolution of non-linear cosmological matter perturbations. Starting from the perturbed Einstein equations, we integrate out the non-relativistic degrees of freedom of the cosmic fluid and obtain a single closed equation for the gravitational potential. We then verify the validity of the new equation by comparing its approximate solutions to known results in the theory of non-linear cosmological perturbations. First, we show explicitly that the perturbative solution of our equation matches the standard perturbative solutions. Next, using the mean field approximation to the equation, we show that its solution reproduces in a simple way the exponential suppression of the non-linear propagator on small scales due to the velocity dispersion. Our approach can therefore reproduce the main features of the renormalized perturbation theory and (time)-renormalization group approaches to the study of non-linear cosmological perturbations, with some possibly important differences. We conclude by a preliminary discussion of the nature of the full solutions of the equation and their significance
January 2011

metadata.@content: Cheoun, Myung-Ki; Miyatsu, Tsuyoshi; Ryu, C. Y. (Department of Physics, Soongsil University, Seoul 156-743 (Korea, Republic of)); Deliduman, Cemsinan (Department of Physics, Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University, Bomonti 34380, Istanbul (Turkey)); Güngör, Can; Keleş, Vildan (Istanbul Technical University, Faculty of Science and Letters, Physics Engineering Department, Maslak 34469, Istanbul (Turkey)); Kajino, Toshitaka (National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, 2-21-1 Osawa, Mitaka, Tokyo 181-8588, Japan and Department of Astronomy, Graduate School of Science, University of Tokyo, Hongo 7-3-1, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-0033 (Japan)); Mathews, Grant J. (Center for Astrophysics, Department of Physics, University of Notre Dame, IN 46556 (United States))
Possible ambiguities in the equation of state for neutron stars
English
United States

AIP Conference Proceedings; v. 1594(1); ISSN 0094-243X; CODEN APCPCS; 2 May 2014; p. 414-419; OMEG12: 12. international symposium on origin of matter and evolution of galaxies; Tsukuba (Japan); 18-21 Nov 2013; (c) 2014 AIP Publishing LLC; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ASTROPHYSICS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLAVOR MODEL; GRAVITATION; HYPERONS; INTERSTELLAR MAGNETIC FIELDS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MEAN-FIELD THEORY; NEUTRON STARS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; SU-3 GROUPS; SU-6 GROUPS

BARYONS; COMPOSITE MODELS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; LIE GROUPS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; PARTICLE MODELS; PHYSICS; QUARK MODEL; STARS; STRANGE PARTICLES; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

We addressed possible ambiguities on the properties of neutron stars (NSs) estimated in theoretical sides. First, roles of hyperons inside the NS are discussed through various relativistic mean field (RMF) theories. In particular, the extension of SU(6) spin-flavor symmetry to SU(3) flavor symmetry is shown to give rise to the increase of hyperon threshold density, similarly to the Fock term effects in RMF theories. As a result, about 2.0 solar mass is obtained with the hyperons. Second, the effect by the modified f(R) gravity, which leaves a room for the dark energy in the Einstein equation to be taken into account, is discussed for the NS in a strong magnetic field (MF). Our results show that the modified gravity with the Kaluza-Klein electro-magnetism theory expanded in terms of a length scale parameter may reasonably describe the NS in strong MF, so called magnetar. Even the super-soft equation of state is shown to be revived by the modified f(R) gravity
January 2014

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We addressed possible ambiguities on the properties of neutron stars (NSs) estimated in theoretical sides. First, roles of hyperons inside the NS are discussed through various relativistic mean field (RMF) theories. In particular, the extension of SU(6) spin-flavor symmetry to SU(3) flavor symmetry is shown to give rise to the increase of hyperon threshold density, similarly to the Fock term effects in RMF theories. As a result, about 2.0 solar mass is obtained with the hyperons. Second, the effect by the modified f(R) gravity, which leaves a room for the dark energy in the Einstein equation to be taken into account, is discussed for the NS in a strong magnetic field (MF). Our results show that the modified gravity with the Kaluza-Klein electro-magnetism theory expanded in terms of a length scale parameter may reasonably describe the NS in strong MF, so called magnetar. Even the super-soft equation of state is shown to be revived by the modified f(R) gravity</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Kummer, Janis
Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron (DESY), Hamburg (Germany); Hamburg Univ. (Germany). Dept. Physik
The cosmological constant in theories with finite spacetime
English
Germany
Aug 2014; 67 p; DESY-THESIS--2014-018; ISSN 1435-8085; Master Thesis
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EXPANSION; FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; INTEGRAL CALCULUS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; METRICS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; SCALAR FIELDS; SCALE INVARIANCE; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY; UNIVERSE
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; MATTER; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RELATIVITY THEORY

We study the role of the cosmological constant in different theories with finite spacetime. The cosmological constant appears both as an initial condition and as a constant of integration. In the context of the cosmological constant problem a new model will be presented. This modification of general relativity generates a small, non-vanishing cosmological constant, which is radiatively stable. The dynamics of the expansion of the universe in this model will be analyzed. Eventually, we try to solve the emergent problems concerning the generation of accelerated expansion using a quintessence model of dark energy.
January 2014

metadata.@content: Albareti, F.D.; Cembranos, J.A.R.; Dobado, A. (Departamento de Física Teórica I, Universidad Complutense de Madrid, E-28040 Madrid (Spain)); Cruz-Dombriz, A. de la (Instituto de Ciencias del Espacio (ICE/CSIC) and Institut d'Estudis Espacials de Catalunya (IEEC), Facultat de Ciències, Campus UAB, Torre C5-Par-2a, 08193 Bellaterra, Barcelona (Spain)), E-mail: fdalbareti@ucm.es, E-mail: cembra@fis.ucm.es, E-mail: alvaro.delacruzdombriz@uct.ac.za, E-mail: dobado@fis.ucm.es
On the non-attractive character of gravity in f(R) theories
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(07); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jul 2013; p. 009; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/07/009; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
BRANES; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; GRAVITATION; LIMITING VALUES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS; RELATIVITY THEORY

In General Relativity without a cosmological constant a non-positive contribution from the space-time geometry to Raychaudhuri equation is found provided that particular energy conditions are assumed and regardless the considered solution of the Einstein's equations. This fact is usually interpreted as a manifestation of the attractive character of gravity. Nevertheless, a positive contribution to Raychaudhuri equation from space-time geometry should occur since this is the case in an accelerated expanding Robertson-Walker model for congruences followed by fundamental observers. Modified gravity theories provide the possibility of a positive contribution although the standard energy conditions are assumed. We address this important issue in the context of f(R) theories, deriving explicit upper bounds for the contribution of space-time geometry to the Raychaudhuri equation. Then, we examine the parameter constraints for some paradigmatic f(R) models in order to ensure a positive contribution to this equation. Furthermore, we consider the implications of these upper bounds in the equivalent formulation of f(R) theories as a Brans-Dicke model
January 2013

metadata.@content: Pasechnik, Roman (Department of Astronomy and Theoretical Physics, Lund University, SE-223 62 Lund (Sweden)); Beylin, Vitaly; Vereshkov, Grigory (Research Institute of Physics, Southern Federal University, 344090 Rostov-on-Don (Russian Federation)), E-mail: Roman.Pasechnik@thep.lu.se, E-mail: vbey@rambler.ru, E-mail: gveresh@gmail.com
Dark Energy from graviton-mediated interactions in the QCD vacuum
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(06); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jun 2013; p. 011; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/06/011; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

APPROXIMATIONS; CORRECTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; FLUCTUATIONS; GLUON CONDENSATION; GLUONS; GROUND STATES; METRICS; MEV RANGE; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; QUANTUM CHROMODYNAMICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; QUARK MATTER; UNIVERSE
BOSONS; CALCULATION METHODS; ENERGY LEVELS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATTER; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; VARIATIONS

Adopting the hypothesis about the exact cancellation of vacuum condensates contributions to the ground state energy in particle physics to the leading order in graviton-mediated interactions, we argue that the observable cosmological constant can be dynamically induced by an uncompensated quantum gravity correction to them after the QCD phase transition epoch. To start with, we demonstrate a possible cancellation of the quark-gluon condensate contribution to the total vacuum energy density of the Universe at temperatures T < 100 MeV without taking into account the graviton-mediated effects. In order to incorporate the latter, we then calculate the leading-order quantum correction to the classical Einstein equations due to metric fluctuations induced by the non-perturbative vacuum fluctuations of the gluon and quark fields in the quasiclassical approximation. It has been demonstrated that such a correction to the vacuum energy density has a form εΛ ∼ GΛQCD6, where G is the gravitational constant, and ΛQCD is the QCD scale parameter. We analyze capabilities of this approach based on the synthesis between quantum gravity in quasiclassical approximation and theory of non-perturbative QCD vacuum for quantitative explanation of the observed Dark Energy density
January 2013

metadata.@content: Dzhunushaliev, Vladimir (Al-Farabi Kazakh National University, Department of Theoretical and Nuclear Physics, Almaty (Kazakhstan); Al-Farabi Kazakh National University, Institute of Experimental and Theoretical Physics, Almaty (Kazakhstan); Eurasian National University, Institute for Basic Research, Astana (Kazakhstan); Institute of Physicotechnical Problems and Material Science of the NAS of the Kyrgyz Republic, Bishkek (Kyrgyzstan)); Folomeev, Vladimir (Institute of Physicotechnical Problems and Material Science of the NAS of the Kyrgyz Republic, Bishkek (Kyrgyzstan))
Propagation of gravitational waves in the nonperturbative spinor vacuum
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(9); ISSN 1434-6044; Sep 2014; p. 1-8; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-3057-2
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

DAMPING; DIRAC EQUATION; DISPERSION RELATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; PERTURBATION THEORY; PHASE SHIFT; PHASE VELOCITY; SPINOR FIELDS; TENSOR FIELDS; VACUUM STATES; WAVE PROPAGATION
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; VELOCITY; WAVE EQUATIONS

The propagation of gravitational waves on the background of a nonperturbative vacuum of a spinor field is considered. It is shown that there are several distinctive features in comparison with the propagation of plane gravitational waves through empty space: there exists a fixed phase difference between the hyy,zz and hyz components of the wave; the phase and group velocities of gravitational waves are not equal to the velocity of light; the group velocity is always less than the velocity of light; under some conditions the gravitational waves are either damped or absent; for given frequency, there exist two waves with different wave vectors. We also discuss the possibility of an experimental verification of the obtained effects as a tool to investigate nonperturbative quantum field theories. (orig.)
January 2014

      </categories>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="02475" assignment="indexer">damping</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02686" assignment="indexer">dirac equation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02706" assignment="indexer">dispersion relations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04117" assignment="indexer">gravitational waves</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07302" assignment="indexer">perturbation theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07326" assignment="indexer">phase shift</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="14318" assignment="indexer">phase velocity</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="20063" assignment="indexer">spinor fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="26341" assignment="indexer">tensor fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11532" assignment="indexer">vacuum states</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10920" assignment="indexer">wave propagation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02642" assignment="upposted">differential equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="21631" assignment="upposted">partial differential equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10815" assignment="upposted">velocity</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="21500" assignment="upposted">wave equations</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The propagation of gravitational waves on the background of a nonperturbative vacuum of a spinor field is considered. It is shown that there are several distinctive features in comparison with the propagation of plane gravitational waves through empty space: there exists a fixed phase difference between the h<sub>yy,zz</sub> and h<sub>yz</sub> components of the wave; the phase and group velocities of gravitational waves are not equal to the velocity of light; the group velocity is always less than the velocity of light; under some conditions the gravitational waves are either damped or absent; for given frequency, there exist two waves with different wave vectors. We also discuss the possibility of an experimental verification of the obtained effects as a tool to investigate nonperturbative quantum field theories. (orig.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

      <input-center type="subj" key="DE">Germany</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Kar, S.; Bharadwaj, S.; Pal, S. (Department of Physics and Centre for Theoretical Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur (India))
Can modified gravity from extra dimensions explain dark matter effects?
Third advanced research workshop: Gravity, astrophysics and strings at the Black Sea. Proceedings
English
Bulgaria

Fiziev, P.; Todorov, M. (eds.); Joinr Group on Gravity and Asrtophysics, Sofia (Bulgaria); 304 p; ISBN 954-07-2422-8; 2006; p. 254-264; Third advanced research workshop: Gravity, astrophysics and strings at the Black Sea; Kiten (Bulgaria); 13-20 Jun 2005; 30 refs.
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; GALAXY CLUSTERS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL LENSES; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; UNIVERSE; VISIBLE RADIATION; X RADIATION
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; IONIZING RADIATIONS; LENSES; MATTER; RADIATIONS

Observations on galaxy rotation curves and X-ray profiles of galaxy clusters over several decades have shown us that there exists a need for non-luminous (dark) matter. Cosmological observations also point towards the existence of dark components of two kinds - dark matter and dark energy - which, together, seem to be most of what is there the universe. However, for several years, there has been a line of thought which proposes modified gravity as an alternative to dark matter. In this article, we show, how the effective Einstein equations which arise in the context of the currently fashionable warped braneworld models, can explain the effects of dark matter as a manifestation of the consequences of the existence of extra dimensions. Finally, in order to distinguish between the effects of material dark matter and modified gravity, we calculate gravitational lensing in our modified gravity theory and show distinct differences in the deflection angles. If confirmed with observations, our results may shed new light on the existence of extra dimensions and dark matter. (authors)
January 2006

metadata.@content: Kuenzle, H.P.; Savage, J.R. (Department of Mathematics, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada T6G 2G1)
Uniqueness of the equilibrium configurations of slowy rotating relativistic fluids
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; STARS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY

We consider the equations of a general relativistic space-time that is stationary, asymptotically Euclidean, diffeomorphic to R4 and consists of an exterior vacuum solution and an interior perfect fluid in rigid motion. If one requires further that the solution be close to the static spherically symmetric ones (in the sense of a suitable topology on the set of stationary space--time metrics) it is shown that for a given equation of state rho( p) and given total mass m and (small) angular momentum J there are no smooth curves of physically distinct global axially symmetric solutions. In view of a recent result of Lindblom that all such space-times are axisymmetric this result is quite general. The method is a generalization of the one used to prove (in a ''local'' sense) the uniqueness of the spherical solution in the static case
January 1980

metadata.@content: Ogievetskij, V.I.; Sokachev, Eh.S. (Joint Inst. for Nuclear Research, Dubna (USSR))
Equation of motion for axial gravitational superfield
Uravneniya dvizheniya dlya aksial'nogo gravitatsionnogo superpolya
Russian
USSR
Yadernaya Fizika; v. 32(4) p. 1142-1151; ISSN 0044-0027; 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Journal of Nuclear Physics (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF MOTION; RARITA-SCHWINGER THEORY; SUPERGRAVITY; TORSION; TRANSFORMATIONS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; SYMMETRY

The equation of motion for the axial gravitational superfield is obtained by direct variation of the action for N=1 supergravity. The left-hand side of the equation is a certain torsion component, the right-hand side is the supercurrent. The question about the cosmological term in supergravity is discussed
January 1980

metadata.@content: Durgapal, M.C.; Rawat, P.S.; Banerji, R. (Kumaun Univ., Naini Tal (India). Dept. of Physics)
Relativistic star clusters with high central redshift
India
Pramana; v. 15(1) p. 53-63; ISSN 0304-4289; Jul 1980; 14 refs., 4 figures.
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
DISTRIBUTION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FERMI GAS MODEL; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; RED SHIFT; STABILITY; STAR CLUSTERS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUCLEAR MODELS

Collisionless star clusters in dynamical equilibrium are of current interest in general relativity and astrophysics. A step-function distribution is chosen for star clusters. The corresponding equation of state is analogous to a Fermi-gas equation. These clusters are found to be pulsationally unstable for a central redshift of Zsub(c)>=0.54. Further, a model of clusters is developed in which the core has an extremely relativistic equation of state. These structures are unstable for Zsub(c)>=2.55 when we use Chandrasekhar's technique to study their pulsational stability. (auth.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Sakai, Jun-ichi; Kawata, Tutomu (Toyama Univ., Takaoka (Japan). Faculty of Engineering)
Waves in an ultra-relativistic electron-positron plasma
Japan
Journal of the Physical Society of Japan; v. 49(2) p. 747-752; ISSN 0031-9015; Aug 1980
Journal article
PLASMA PHYSICS AND FUSION TECHNOLOGY (A1400)

ALFVEN WAVES; AMBIPLASMA; DISPERSION RELATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRONS; FLOW MODELS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; ION ACOUSTIC WAVES; MAGNETIC FIELDS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; PLASMA MACROINSTABILITIES; POLARIZATION; POSITRONS; RELATIVISTIC PLASMA; WAVE PROPAGATION

ANTILEPTONS; ANTIMATTER; ANTIPARTICLES; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HYDROMAGNETIC WAVES; INSTABILITY; ION WAVES; LEPTONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; PLASMA; PLASMA INSTABILITY; PLASMA WAVES

Basic equations describing a macroscopic behaviour of ultra-relativistic plasma (T >> mc2) are formulated in a covariant form. Waves in an electron-positron plasma are investigated in a frame of two-fluid model equation. Dispersion relations for electrostatic wave, electromagnetic wave and Alfven wave propagating parallel to a constant magnetic field are shown. In the case that both electron and positron gases have same temperature, there does not exist the slow mode which corresponds to the ion acoustic wave. Right and left circular polarized waves propagate with the same dispersion relation which is different from one of the non-relativistic electron-ion plasma. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Macrae, K.I.; Riegert, R.J. (Department of Physics, B-019, University of California, at San Diego, La Jolla, California 92093)
Effect of curvature-squared terms on cosmology
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(10) p. 2555-2560; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Nov 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

We consider the effect on Friedmann cosmology of adding all possible algebraic terms quadratic in the curvature tensor to the usual Einstein-Hilbert action for gravitation. Assuming that the vacuum energy density (cosmological constant) is not extraordinarily large in any phase of the evolution of the universe, we find that the cosmological solutions of this more general theory are indistinguishable from standard Friedmann models all the way from the initial singularity to the present
January 1981

metadata.@content: Calvani, M. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Astronomia)
Effective potential for equatorial motion in the Tomimatsu-Sato space-times
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 21(4) p. 115-118; ISSN 0024-1318; 28 Jan 1978
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; HAMILTON-JACOBI EQUATIONS; KERR METRIC; POTENTIALS; SPACE-TIME
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

January 1978

metadata.@content: Tseytlin, A.A. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Inst. Teoreticheskoj Fiziki)
On the first-order formalism in quantum gravity
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(3) p. L105-L110; ISSN 0305-4470; Mar 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SPINOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

It is shown that quantum gravity in the first-order form is equivalent to the quantised Einstein theory only in the phases where <esub(μ)sup(α)> = esub(0μ)sup(α), det e0 is not equal to 0. If det e0 = 0 one must take into account configurations with non-zero torsion. The analogy with the first-order formulation for gauge theories and the connection-dependent counterterms for the spinor theory are discussed. (author)
January 1982

        <descriptor type="valid" key="20063" assignment="indexer">spinor fields</descriptor>

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">It is shown that quantum gravity in the first-order form is equivalent to the quantised Einstein theory only in the phases where <esub(μ)sup(α)> = esub(0μ)sup(α), det e<sub>0</sub> is not equal to 0. If det e<sub>0</sub> = 0 one must take into account configurations with non-zero torsion. The analogy with the first-order formulation for gauge theories and the connection-dependent counterterms for the spinor theory are discussed. (author)</abstract>

metadata.@content: Dereli, T. (Middle East Technical Univ., Ankara (Turkey)); Tucker, R.W. (Lancaster Univ. (UK))
An intrinsic analysis of neutrino couplings to gravity
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(5) p. 1625-1641; ISSN 0305-4470; May 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LORENTZ GROUPS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; NEUTRINOS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SPACE-TIME
ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LEPTONS; LIE GROUPS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; POINCARE GROUPS; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS

New solutions to the Einstein-Cartan-Weyl system are presented and analysed in the intrinsic language of complex quaternionic exterior forms. The model is set up as a local gauge theory of the Lorentz group for critical sections of the linear frame bundle over space-time. Tentative suggestions are made for the interpretation of these solutions in the framework of a quantised interacting field system. (author)
January 1982

Search for correlations between the University of Maryland and the University of Rome gravitational radiation antennas

Journal article

metadata.@content: Raychaudhuri, A.K.
Theoretical cosmology
United States
1979; 307 p; Oxford University Press; New York, NY
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BACKGROUND RADIATION; BARYONS; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MICROWAVE RADIATION; PERTURBATION THEORY; THERMONUCLEAR REACTIONS; UNIVERSE
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; NUCLEAR REACTIONS; NUCLEOSYNTHESIS; RADIATIONS

Current understandings and unresolved questions in the field of theoretical big bang cosmology are discussed. Following a review of the fundamental assumptions and conventions of standard cosmological theory and of Newtonian gravitation and cosmology, general relativity and relativistic cosmology are introduced, and the analysis of observational data is discussed. Relativistic models not obeying the cosmological principle are considered, and attention is given to the nature and origin of the microwave radiation background, the thermal history of the universe and nucleosynthesis, the cosmological singularity, the gravitational constant as a field variable in the Brans-Dicke cosmology and cosmological models based on the Einstein-Cartan theory. The two-tensor theory of Isham, Salam and Strathdee (1971, 1973) and the conformally invariant theory of Hoyle and Narlikar (1972) are indicated, and the fate of perturbations of isotropic universes, galaxy formation and baryon symmetric cosmologies are considered
January 1979

metadata.@content: Knutsen, H. (Warsaw Univ. (Poland). Inst. Fizyki Teoretycznej)
Some properties of an oscillating fluid sphere in general relativity
United Kingdom
Physica Scripta; v. 26(5) p. 365-369; ISSN 0031-8949; Nov 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ACCELERATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; QUASARS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; STAR MODELS; VELOCITY
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS

Nariai's singularity-free model for a relativistic, oscillating fluid sphere is investigated. It is shown that both density and pressure have negative gradients. Hernandez/Misner's criterium for a trapped surface to exist is not fulfilled, so the surface of the sphere is outside the Schwarzschild surface. The inequalities rho - p > 0 and rho - 3p > 0 will not hold for arbitrary choice of the three parameters e, S1, S2 which specify the degree of non-homogeneity, minimum and maximum size of the pulsating object respectively. If the degree of non-homogeneity is small, however, both the inequalities above are fulfilled. The velocity of the matter has positive gradient and is smaller than the velocity of light throughout the sphere. (Auth.)
January 1982

        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Nariai's singularity-free model for a relativistic, oscillating fluid sphere is investigated. It is shown that both density and pressure have negative gradients. Hernandez/Misner's criterium for a trapped surface to exist is not fulfilled, so the surface of the sphere is outside the Schwarzschild surface. The inequalities rho - p > 0 and rho - 3p > 0 will not hold for arbitrary choice of the three parameters e, S<sub>1</sub>, S<sub>2</sub> which specify the degree of non-homogeneity, minimum and maximum size of the pulsating object respectively. If the degree of non-homogeneity is small, however, both the inequalities above are fulfilled. The velocity of the matter has positive gradient and is smaller than the velocity of light throughout the sphere. (Auth.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="SE">Sweden</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>

</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: De Felice, F. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); Yunqiang Yu (International School for Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy))
Massive neutrinos in strong gravitational fields
Italy
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BLACK HOLES; COSMIC NEUTRINOS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; NEUTRON STARS; TRAPPING
COSMIC RADIATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; IONIZING RADIATIONS; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; NEUTRINOS; RADIATIONS; STARS

The gravitational field interior to condensed objects is able to trap neutrinos. If this phenomenon is consistent, it is argued that the trapped neutrinos can affect significantly the star interior; here we investigate this possibility in the case of massive neutrinos and find that they should contribute to the equation of state at the centre of the star in the extreme phase of collapse before a black hole is formed. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Hajicek, P. (Institute for Theoretical Physics, Sidlerstrasse 5, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland)
Classical action functional for the system of fields and wormholes
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(12) p. 3384-3395; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Dec 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; QUASI PARTICLES

We lay down foundations of the quantum theory of wormholes for the model Einstein-Maxwell system. The generalization of the quantum theory of solitons to wormholes is not straightforward, because the fields are singular at r = 0. We propose to cut away the nonphysical part of the spacetime along the horizons and to impose boundary conditions at the resulting boundary of Cauchy surfaces. The boundary conditions are chosen such that (a) there is an action functional for the fields, (b) Poisson brackets of the boundary-fixed quantities with each other vanish, and (c) the soliton solution is unique. We study the action functional, find the surface terms, and, using the method of Regge and Teitelboim, extract the motion of the soliton. We show how the gauge group of the system is extended and find some properties of the additional gauge conditions. Finally, the soliton solution is written in the form in which all boundary and gauge conditions are satisfied
January 1982

metadata.@content: Selleri, F. (Bari Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); Tarozzi, G. (Perugia Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Filosofia)
Quantum mechanics reality and separability
Italy
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

BELL THEOREM; BOHM CRITERION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HISTORICAL ASPECTS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LOCALITY; NONMEASURABLE VARIABLES; QUANTUM MECHANICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SYMMETRY; WAVE FUNCTIONS; WAVE PACKETS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MECHANICS

For many decades, there has been a debate about which one should be the correct interpretation of Quantum Mechanics. With regard to this question, the Copenhagen-Goettingen interpretation was in conflict with the interpretation given by Einstein and other physicists. The so-called problem of ''completeness'' of the theory in particular was under investigation. The development of this controversial problem, from the Von Neumann theorem up to the discovery of Bell inequality is reviewed in this article and it is discussed how these events marked the beginning of a new era for the researches on Quantum Mechanics. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Halpern, L. (Department of Physics, Florida State University, Florida 32306)
Manifestations of group covariance in a metric theory
United States
Foundations of Physics; v. 13(3) p. 297-310; ISSN 0015-9018; Mar 1983
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GROUP THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; TIME DEPENDENCE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The requirement to present Dirac's Large Number Hypothesis in one system of units in which the resulting modifications to Einstein's theory are exhibited, led to the construction of generalizations of General Relativity based rigorously on the geometry of semisimple groups. The foundations of such a theory are discussed and some of their possible interpretations are presented
January 1983

Rotating fluid spheres
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 16(8) p. 1689-1693; ISSN 0305-4470; 1 Jun 1983
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NEUTRON STARS; ROTATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; STARS

A new exact solution to the 'slow rotation' structure equations is presented. It is briefly compared with the slowly rotating limit of the Wahlquist solution, with which the new solution shares an equation of state. (author)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Perjes, Z.; Lukacs, B.; Sebestyen, A.; Valentini, A.; Sparling, G.A.J.
Tokyo Univ., Tanashi (Japan). Inst. for Nuclear Study
Solution of the stationary vacuum equations of relativity for conformally flat 3-spaces
Japan
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; SYMMETRY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; METRICS

The solution of Einstein's vacuum gravitational equations for stationary space-times with a conformally flat 3-space is presented. There is no other solution of this problem than the Ehlers-rotation generalizations of the three conformastat space-times including the Schwarzschild metric. (author)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Nariai, Hidekazu.
Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics
On the de Sitter and Nariai spacetimes in a generalized theory of gravitation
Japan
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

A possibility of obtaining the de Sitter and Nariai spacetimes in a generalized theory of gravitation (which was in succession proposed by Utiyama-DeWitt, Parker-Fulling-Hu and Gurovich-Starobinski) is examined. It is shown that the generalized theory with a suitable fixation of three parameters admit both spacetimes, just like the general theory of relativity. (author)
January 1985

metadata.@content: Davidson, A.; Guendelman, E.I. (Physics Department, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel)
Gravitational bags
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(10) p. 3264-3267; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Nov 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; SCALAR FIELDS; STRING MODELS
EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; TENSORS

Spontaneous compactification is shown to predict a novel type of localized four-dimensional horizon-free objects. These are cores of scalar fields confined by means of a static domain wall. Their surface area is at most (9/4) the area of an equal-mass black hole. Altogether, they make excellent candidates for Einstein's gravitational bags
January 1986

metadata.@content: Isaacson, R.A. (National Science Foundation, Washington, DC (USA)); Welling, J.S.; Winicour, J. (Pittsburgh Univ., PA (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Exact global radiative solutions to the Bondi initial value problem
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1059-1066; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; AXIAL SYMMETRY; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS; SYMMETRY

The authors discuss the Bondi-type initial value problem for axisymmetric space-times, with a dust source. Choosing vanishing shear, pressure and initial velocity, they have found a class of density distributions for which all the null hypersurface constraint equations, as well as the dynamical equation for the initial time derivative of the shear, can be integrated in closed form. The resulting metric exhibits asymptotic flatness and radiative behavior. Simple expressions for Bondi's mass and news function are obtained. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Vereshkov, G.M.; Grishkin, Yu.S.; Korotun, A.V.; Poltavtsev, A.N.
Physical vacuum decay as a mechanism of the hot isotropic production Universe
Raspad fizicheskogo vakuuma kak mekhanism vozniknoveniya goryachej izotropnoj Vselennoj
Russian
USSR
Problemy Teorii Gravitatsii i Ehlementarnykh Chastits; (no.17) p. 47-66; CODEN PTGEA; 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EXPANSION; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; ORIGIN; QUANTUM GRAVITY; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION; VACUUM STATES
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; TENSORS

In the framework of quasiclassical gravitation theory the problem of the Universe genesis from vacuum is discussed. The simplest model, in which geometric part of gravitation theory equations is einsteinian, and vacuum polarization effects are presented by conformal anomaly of energy-momentum tensor, is considered. The conclusion is made on the existence of three independent evolution branches of the expanding Universe: asymptotic transformation of plane space into the de Sitter-Hoyle space; exponential inflation of the de Sitter-Hoyle Universe and Friedman Universe, modified by quantum gravitational phenomena
January 1986

metadata.@content: Ardalan, F.; Arfaei, H. (International Center for Theoretical Physics, Trieste, Italy and Department of Physics, Sharif University of Technology, P. O. Box 11365-8639, Tehran, Iran)
Quotient of manifolds by discrete groups
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(3) p. 685-689; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Mar 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)

COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; GROUP THEORY; HIGGS MODEL; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; SCALAR FIELDS; SO GROUPS; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY; SYMMETRY BREAKING; TENSORS; TOPOLOGY; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; PARTICLE MODELS; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

The quotient of manifolds by discrete subgroups of their isometry group are considered. In particular, symmetry breaking due to the quotient structure, topological properties, and harmonic analysis of the resultant manifolds are discussed and illustrated by two-dimensional examples. New solutions of d = 11 supergravity and the d = 6 Einstein--Yang--Mills theory are thus obtained, for which alterations in their spectrum and symmetry breaking are discussed
January 1987

      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The quotient of manifolds by discrete subgroups of their isometry group are considered. In particular, symmetry breaking due to the quotient structure, topological properties, and harmonic analysis of the resultant manifolds are discussed and illustrated by two-dimensional examples. New solutions of d = 11 supergravity and the d = 6 Einstein--Yang--Mills theory are thus obtained, for which alterations in their spectrum and symmetry breaking are discussed</abstract>

metadata.@content: Meszaros, A. (Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Charles University, Prague, 150 00 Prague 5, vedska 8, Czechoslovakia)
Cartan's contortion as a pair of massless spin-2 fields
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 35(4) p. 1176-1180; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Feb 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MASSLESS PARTICLES; METRICS; POINCARE GROUPS; SPIN; TENSOR FORCES; VECTOR FIELDS
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; PARTICLE PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY GROUPS

Cartan's contortion is either considered as a nonpropagating field hardly having any physical significance or as a field determined by exotic very massive particles called tordions. In this paper an essentially different alternative is proposed: the contortion is determined, among other extraordinary vector fields, by a pair of standard massless spin-2 fields (V and W fields). It is conjectured that the extraordinary fields are vanishing. The forms of the interactions and self-interactions of the V and W fields are also briefly discussed
January 1987

metadata.@content: Suen, W. (Theoretical Astrophysics 130-33, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125)
Multipole moments for stationary, non-asymptotically-flat systems in general relativity
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 34(12) p. 3617-3632; ISSN 0556-2821; CODEN PRVDA; 15 Dec 1986
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASS; METRICS; MULTIPOLES; POTENTIALS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A formulation of multipole moments generalizing that of Thorne is proposed for the stationary, vacuum region of spacetime surrounding a source of gravity, without assuming asymptotic flatness. In this formalism, such a region of spacetime is characterized by four sets of moments, the internal mass and current moments (those of the internal source) and the external mass and current moments (those of the external universe), which are read out from a de Donder coordinate expansion of the metric density. These moments uniquely determine the vacuum region of spacetime. The interactions between a gravitating body and an external gravitational field can be described in terms of these moments, in close analogy with Newtonian theory. A derivation, using the vacuum Einstein equation alone, is given of the laws of force and torque for an isolated body acted on by an external field. These laws generalize the results of Thorne and Hartle and of Zhang
January 1986

metadata.@content: Shiraishi, Kiyoshi (Tokyo Metropolitan Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics)
The Friedmann universe and compact internal spaces in higher-dimensional gravity theories
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 76(1) p. 321-324; ISSN 0033-068X; CODEN PTPKA; Jul 1986
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2140)
COMPACTIFICATION; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; KALUZA-KLEIN THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

We consider gravity theories in 4 + N dimensions which are governed by the lagrangian written as an extended Gauss-Bonnet density. We can find a naturally generalized Einstein gravity where the maximal symmetric compactification leads to vanishing four-dimensional cosmological constant in the static limit. A later stage in the generalized Kaluza-Klein cosmology is also examined. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Rozga, K. (Pedagogical University, Kielce (Poland). Inst. of Mathematics)
Classes of right-conformally equivalent HH spaces
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(1) p. 109-116; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Jan 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL GROUPS; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; SPINOR FIELDS; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

Right-conformally equivalent hyperheavenly (HH) metrics are defined and the relations between them are established in the form of a system of certain first-order differential equations. An idea of a method that could produce new HH space from algebraically degenerate H spaces is pointed out. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Oezer, M.; Taha, M.O. (Riyadh Univ. (Saudi Arabia). Dept. of Physics)
A model of the universe free of cosmological problems
Netherlands
Nuclear Physics. B; v. 287(4) p. 776-796; ISSN 0550-3213; CODEN NUPBB; 15 Jun 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

CAUSALITY; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DECOUPLING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRONS; ENERGY DENSITY; ENERGY TRANSFER; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; ENTROPY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; IRREVERSIBLE PROCESSES; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; METRICS; NEUTRINOS; PAIR PRODUCTION; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PHOTOPRODUCTION; POSITRONS; SINGULARITY; THERMAL RADIATION; THERMODYNAMICS; UNIVERSE

ANTILEPTONS; ANTIMATTER; ANTIPARTICLES; BASIC INTERACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC INTERACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; TENSORS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

A cosmological model with an additional term Λ(x)gμν in the energy-momentum tensor is introduced. Its structure is specified by the assumption that the energy density of the universe equals its critical value. The model so determined has k=1, is singularity-free and does not possess the horizon, entropy, monopole or cosmological-constant problems of the standard hot bang cosmology. The whole universe is found to be causally connected slightly after Planck time. There exists a period of phase transition during part of which the pressure is negative. The model displays a flow of energy from curvature to matter such that the entropy of matter is not conserved. (orig.)
January 1987

        <descriptor type="valid" key="11507" assignment="upposted">particle production</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="10060" assignment="upposted">thermodynamic properties</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A cosmological model with an additional term Λ(x)g<sub>μν</sub> in the energy-momentum tensor is introduced. Its structure is specified by the assumption that the energy density of the universe equals its critical value. The model so determined has k=1, is singularity-free and does not possess the horizon, entropy, monopole or cosmological-constant problems of the standard hot bang cosmology. The whole universe is found to be causally connected slightly after Planck time. There exists a period of phase transition during part of which the pressure is negative. The model displays a flow of energy from curvature to matter such that the entropy of matter is not conserved. (orig.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Hall, G.S.; Rendall, A.D. (Department of Mathematics, University of Aberdeen, Edward Wright Building, Dunbar Street, Aberdeen AB9 2TY, Scotland)
Uniqueness of the metric from the Weyl and energy-momentum tensors
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(8) p. 1837-1839; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Aug 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; METRICS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; TENSORS

It is shown that for a general space-time in Einstein's theory (with the term ''general'' being precisely defined) the Weyl tensor and energy-momentum tensor determine the metric up to a constant conformal factor. One of the conclusions may be interpreted as a generalization of the well-known Brinkmann theorem characterizing pp waves in vacuo
January 1987

metadata.@content: Weber, J. (Univ. of Maryland, College Park, MD)
Gravitational antennas and the search for gravitational radiation
Gravitational radiation and relativity
United States
Weber, J.; Karade, T.M; p. 1-78; ISBN 9971-978-88-1; 1986; p. 1-78; World Scientific Pub. Co; Teaneck, NJ (USA)
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

ANTENNAS; BACKGROUND RADIATION; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; DETECTION; ELASTICITY; EQUILIBRIUM; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVE DETECTORS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; QUANTUM MECHANICS; SPACE-TIME; SPECIFICATIONS
ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MECHANICS; RADIATION DETECTORS; RADIATIONS

The gravitational radiation antenna measures the spacetime curvature. A number of exact results are available in the theory of the gravitational radiation antenna which include the equations of motion obtained from Einstein's Field Equations, the coupled Maxwell Einstein equations and the directivity. Classical and quantum theories of the antenna are presented. An antenna composed of a large number of small quadrupoles has a cross section determined by the square of the number of quadrupoles. The model, as an ensemble of interacting particles, has a much larger cross section than a classical continuous elastic solid of the same mass and dimensions. Antennas in thermal equilibrium exchange energy with gravitational radiation at a rate proportional to the square of the Riemann tensor. It is shown that the preparation of antennas in correlated quantum states results in energy exchange linear in the Reimann tensor. For such antennas, the heat bath induced fluctuations may be arbitrarily small. Backgrounds were observed during the period 1969-1974 and for an extended period these were not confirmed. During the period 1980 - present, new observations by several research groups have confirmed all of the early Maryland observations
January 1986

metadata.@content: Gaete, P. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro, RJ (Brazil)); Hojman, R. (Chile Univ., Santiago (Chile). Facultad de Ciencias)
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro, RJ (Brazil)
General exact solution for homogeneous time-dependent self-gravitating perfect fluids
Brazil
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; SYMMETRY; TIME DEPENDENCE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A procedure to obtain the general exact solution of Einstein equations for a self-gravitating spherically-symmetric static perfect fluid obeying an arbitrary equation of state, is applied to time-dependent Kantowsky-Sachs line elements (with spherical, planar and hyperbolic symmetry). As in the static case, the solution is generated by an arbitrary function of the independent variable and its first derivative. To illustrate the results, the whole family of (plane-symmetric) solutions with a ''gamma-law'' equation of state is explicity obtained in terms of simple known functions. It is also shown that, while in the static plane-symmtric line elements, every metric is in one to one correspondence with a ''partner-metric'' (both originated from the same generatrix function), in this case every generatrix function univocally determines one metric. (author)
January 1988

metadata.@content: Tapia, V.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Fourth-rank gravity. A progress report
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)

CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGY; FIELD THEORIES; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

We consider the consequences of describing the metric properties of space-time through a quartic line element. The associated ''metric'' is a fourth-rank tensor. After developing some fundamentals for such geometry, we construct a field theory for the gravitational field. This theory coincides with General Relativity in the vacuum case. Departures from General Relativity are obtained only in the presence of matter. We develop a simple cosmological model which is not in contradiction with the observed value Ω approx. 0.2-0.3 for the energy density parameter. A further application concerns conformal field theory. We are able to prove that a conformal field theory possesses an infinite-dimensional symmetry group only if the dimension of space-time is equal to the rank of the metric. In this case we are able to construct an integrable conformal field theory in four dimensions. The model is renormalisable by power counting. (author). 9 refs
January 1992

metadata.@content: Cornish, N.J.; Frankel, N.E.
Melbourne Univ., Parkville, VIC (Australia). School of Physics
A universal mass in (2+1)-dimensions
English
Australia
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HYDROSTATICS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MASS; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

By combining Einstein's field equations in an unconventional way, and invoking the reasonable energy hypothesis, it was proved that all extended structures in hydrostatic equilibrium have the same maximal mass and produce spacetime that are asymptotically cylindrical when local curvature is present. 6 refs
January 1992

metadata.@content: Brandt, Carlos F. Charret; Silva, Maria de Fatima A. da; Rocha, Jaime F. Villas da (Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), RJ (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica Teorica); Chan, Roberto (Observatorio Nacional, Rio de Janeiro, RJ (Brazil). Coordenacao de Astronomia e Astrofisica)
Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica (SBF), Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)
Cosmological model with anisotropic dark energy and self-similarity of the second kind
English
Brazil

2006; 9 p; 27. Brazilian national meeting on particle physics and fields; 27. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos; Aguas de Lindoia, SP (Brazil); 24-28 Sep 2006; INIS-BR--6098; ;  Also available from http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0224-1.pdf; 50 refs.
Miscellaneous
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GEODESICS; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; RELICT RADIATION; UNIVERSE
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; MICROWAVE RADIATION; RADIATIONS

We study the evolution of an anisotropic fluid with self-similarity of the second kind. We found a class of solution to the Einstein field equations by assuming an equation of state where the radial pressure of the fluid is proportional to its energy density (pr =ωρ) and that the fluid moves along time-like geodesics. The equation of state and the anisotropy with self-similarity of second kind imply ω = -1. The energy conditions, geometrical and physical properties of the solutions are studied. We have found that for the parameter α=-1/2 , it may represent a Big Rip cosmological model. (author)
January 2006
http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0224-1.pdf

metadata.@content: Gralla, Samuel E; Herrmann, Frank (Department of Physics, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742-411 (United States)), E-mail: sgralla@umd.edu
Hidden momentum and black hole kicks
English
United Kingdom

Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 30(20); ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRDG; 21 Oct 2013; [13 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205009; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
BLACK HOLES; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; CONFIGURATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; MAGNETIC DIPOLES
DIPOLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MULTIPOLES; SIMULATION

A stationary magnetic dipole immersed in an electric field carries ‘hidden’ mechanical momentum. However, the fate of this momentum if the fields are turned off is unclear. We consider a charge-and-dipole hidden momentum configuration, and turn off the fields by collapsing a null shell onto the system, forming a black hole. In numerical calculations we find that the black hole receives a kick corresponding to 0.1% of the initial stored momentum. When extrapolated to apply to purely gravitational phenomena, this efficiency suggests a role for the hidden momentum kick mechanism in generating the binary black hole ‘superkicks’ observed in numerical simulations of Einstein’s equation. (paper)
January 2013
