metadata.@content: Kausar, H.R. (University of Central Punjab, Centre for Applicable Mathematics and Statistics, Lahore (Pakistan)); Noureen, Ifra (University of Management and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan))
Dissipative spherical collapse of charged anisotropic fluid in f(R) gravity
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(2); ISSN 1434-6044; Feb 2014; p. 1-8; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2760-3
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ADIABATIC APPROXIMATION; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; HEAT FLUX; INSTABILITY; LOCALITY; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; REST MASS; SHEAR
APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MASS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; RELATIVITY THEORY; TENSORS

This manuscript is devoted to the study of the combined effect of a viable f(R) = R + αRn model and the electromagnetic field on the instability range of gravitational collapse. We assume the presence of a charged anisotropic fluid that dissipates energy via heat flow and discuss how the electromagnetic field, density inhomogeneity, shear, and phase transition of astrophysical bodies can be incorporated by a locally anisotropic background. The dynamical equations help to investigate the evolution of self-gravitating objects and lead to the conclusion that the adiabatic index depends upon the electromagnetic background, mass, and radius of the spherical objects. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Basak, Abhishek; Bhatt, Jitesh R. (Physical Research Laboratory, Ahmedabad (India))
A generic constraint on non-minimal coupling
Proceedings of the twentieth DAE-BRNS high energy physics symposium: programme abstracts
English
India
Visva-Bharati, Kolkata (India); 154 p; 2013; p. 82-83; 20. DAE-BRNS high energy physics symposium; Kolkata (India); 13-18 Jan 2013; 1 ref.
Book
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; HIGGS MODEL; PERTURBATION THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS

In this present work we are showing that there will always be a bound on ξ in the Jordan frame (non-minimal coupling with R is explicit) when spectral index is compared with the observed value. In the Einstein frame (non-minimal coupling with R is not present) there will be no bound ξ. The bound on ξ comes specifically from the quantity H2. One has to ensure that 0 < H2 << 1. The condition H2 <<1 is required to have spectral index in the observed range (ns ∼ 1) and the lower bound is required to have accelerated expansion. Along with the above condition one needs to satisfy ε = ϕ2/V << 1 to get negative pressure. All of these things together gives a condition 1< ε < 1 (1 = Hf), where f = 1 + ξϕ2) which gives the bound ξ. In Einstein frame this condition on λ1 can be relaxed so ξ can be unbounded. We also comment on the equivalence between the two frames. (author)
January 2013

        <qualifier key="conference">Conference</qualifier>
      </qualifiers>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">In this present work we are showing that there will always be a bound on ξ in the Jordan frame (non-minimal coupling with R is explicit) when spectral index is compared with the observed value. In the Einstein frame (non-minimal coupling with R is not present) there will be no bound ξ. The bound on ξ comes specifically from the quantity H<sup>2</sup>. One has to ensure that 0 < H<sup>2</sup> << 1. The condition H<sup>2</sup> <<1 is required to have spectral index in the observed range (n<sub>s</sub> ∼ 1) and the lower bound is required to have accelerated expansion. Along with the above condition one needs to satisfy ε = ϕ<sup>2</sup>/V << 1 to get negative pressure. All of these things together gives a condition 1< ε < 1 (1 = H<sub>f</sub>), where f = 1 + ξϕ<sup>2</sup>) which gives the bound ξ. In Einstein frame this condition on λ<sub>1</sub> can be relaxed so ξ can be unbounded. We also comment on the equivalence between the two frames. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="IN">India</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Asgari, Ali A.; Abbassi, Amir H.; Khodagholizadeh, Jafar (Tarbiat Modares University, Department of Physics, School of Sciences, Tehran (Iran, Islamic Republic of))
On the perturbation theory in spatially closed background
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(6); ISSN 1434-6044; Jun 2014; p. 1-11; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2917-0
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ADIABATIC PROCESSES; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FOURIER ANALYSIS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; HUBBLE EFFECT; METRICS; PERTURBATION THEORY; RANDOMNESS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; TENSOR FIELDS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GEOMETRY; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICS

In this article, we investigate some features of the perturbation theory in a spatially closed universe. We will show that the perturbative field equations in a spatially closed universe always have two independent adiabatic solutions provided that the wavelengths of perturbation modes are very much longer than the Hubble horizon. It will be revealed that these adiabatic solutions do not depend on the curvature directly. We also propose a new interpretation for the curvature perturbation in terms of the unperturbed background geometry. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Lee, Bum-Hoon; Lee, Wonwoo (Department of Physics and BK21 Division and Center for Quantum Spacetime, Sogang University, Seoul 121-742 (Korea, Republic of)); Yeom, Dong-han (Department of Physics, KAIST, Daejeon 305-701 (Korea, Republic of)), E-mail: bhl@sogang.ac.kr, E-mail: warrior@sogang.ac.kr, E-mail: innocent@muon.kaist.ac.kr
Dynamics of false vacuum bubbles in Brans-Dicke theory
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(01); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jan 2011; p. 005; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/01/005; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
APPROXIMATIONS; BRANES; BUBBLES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; VACUUM STATES
CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

We study the dynamics of false vacuum bubbles in the Brans-Dicke theory of gravity by using the thin shell or thin wall approximation. We consider a false vacuum bubble that has a different value for the Brans-Dicke field between the inside false vacuum region and the outside true vacuum region. Within a certain limit of field values, the difference of field values makes the effective tension of the shell negative. This allows new expanding false vacuum bubbles to be seen by the outside observer, which are disallowed in Einstein gravity
January 2011

metadata.@content: Gao, Xian (Astroparticule et Cosmologie (APC), UMR 7164-CNRS, Université Denis Diderot-Paris 7, 10 rue Alice Domon et Léonie Duquet, 75205 Paris (France); Laboratoire de Physique Théorique, École Normale Supérieure (LPTENS), 24 rue Lhomond, 75231 Paris (France); Institut d'Astrophysique de Paris (IAP), UMR 7095-CNRS, Université Pierre et Marie Curie-Paris 6, 98bis Boulevard Arago, 75014 Paris (France)), E-mail: xgao@apc.univ-paris7.fr
Conserved cosmological perturbation in Galileon models
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2011(10); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Oct 2011; p. 021; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2011/10/021; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGY; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EXACT SOLUTIONS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHYSICS; TENSORS

We prove the existence of a fully nonlinear conserved curvature perturbation on large scales in Galileon-type scalar field models in two approaches. The first approach is based on the conservation of energy-momentum tensor of the Galileon field, which is also the familiar approach in understanding the conservation in k-essence or perfect fluid models. We show that the fluid corresponding to the Galileon field becomes perfect and barotropic on large scales, which is responsible to the conservation. The difference from k-essence model is that, besides the energy-momentum conservation, the Einstein equation must be employed in order to complete the proof of barotropy. In the second approach, we derive the fully non-perturbative action for the curvature perturbation ζ in Galileon models on large scales, and argue that ζ = const is indeed an exact solution on large scales. This conservation of curvature perturbation is important since it relates the later and the primordial universe
January 2011

metadata.@content: Mora, P.J.; Woodard, R.P. (Department of Physics, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611 (United States)); Tsamis, N.C. (Institute of Theoretical Physics and Computational Physics, Department of Physics University of Crete, GR-710 03 Heraklion (Greece)), E-mail: pmora@phys.ufl.edu, E-mail: tsamis@physics.uoc.gr, E-mail: woodard@phys.ufl.edu
Hartree approximation to the one loop quantum gravitational correction to the graviton mode function on de Sitter
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(10); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Oct 2013; p. 018; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/10/018; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71)
COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; CORRECTIONS; DE SITTER GROUP; DE SITTER SPACE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITONS; HARTREE-FOCK METHOD; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; TENSORS; WAVE PROPAGATION; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY

APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; LIE GROUPS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; POSTULATED PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

We use the Hartree approximation to the Einstein equation on de Sitter background to solve for the one loop correction to the graviton mode function. This should give a reasonable approximation to how the ensemble of inflationary gravitons affects a single external graviton. At late times we find that the one loop correction to the plane wave mode function u(η,k) goes like GH2ln (a)/a2, where a is the inflationary scale factor. One consequence is that the one loop corrections to the ''electric'' components of the linearized Weyl tensor grow compared to the tree order result
January 2013

      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We use the Hartree approximation to the Einstein equation on de Sitter background to solve for the one loop correction to the graviton mode function. This should give a reasonable approximation to how the ensemble of inflationary gravitons affects a single external graviton. At late times we find that the one loop correction to the plane wave mode function u(η,k) goes like GH<sup>2</sup>ln (a)/a<sup>2</sup>, where a is the inflationary scale factor. One consequence is that the one loop corrections to the ''electric'' components of the linearized Weyl tensor grow compared to the tree order result</abstract>
      </abstracts>
